did.head: Collection Summary
did.physdesc: approximately 7873 items
5091 sheets (16.25 linear feet)
832 sound tape reels ; various sizes
760 photographic prints and contact sheets : black and white ; various sizes
1066 negatives : black-and-white original negatives and copy negatives
111 photographs : color transparencies ; 120 mm (slide format)
2 photographs : color transparencies ; 120 mm (slide format, unmounted)
6 photographs : color film negatives ; 35 mm (roll format)
2 photographs : color transparencies ; 35 mm (slide format)
3 drawings

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of over eight hundred sound tape reels, including blues and jazz music and interviews with musicians; several hundred photographs of prominent blues and jazz musicians, primarily from the 1960s and 1970s; manuscript materials about blues and jazz musicians, arranged by the name of performer; and articles, drafts, and notes written by Pete Welding, journalist, record producer, and historian of blues music.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: Processed by Marcia K. Segal. Initial inventory of sound recordings created by Candace Milburn. Sound recording logs created by the following (in alphabetical order): Eli Berdinner, Ying-ting "Serena" Chiu, Natalie Christensen, Marshall Howard Kramer, Cole M. Masaitis, Brittney Meadors, Carolina Restrepo, and Marcia K. Segal. Rob Cristarella, who digitized selected tapes at LC, wrote the LC engineer's notes.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Pete Welding collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Pete Welding Collection (AFC 2011/053), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Pete Welding (1935-1995), an authority on blues and jazz music, worked as a writer and music producer, and was a life-long advocate for traditional blues and avant-garde jazz performers. He wrote regularly for
Down Beat
magazine, wrote liner notes for albums (including releases by Frank Sinatra, Memphis Slim, Nat King Cole, Ian & Sylvia, and the Paul Butterfield Blues Band), and edited books on jazz and blues music. His research for his writings involved interviews of notable figures across music genres, including Signifyin' Mary Johnson, John Lee Hooker, Pete Robinson, Howlin' Wolf, Judy Collins, Thomas A. Dorsey, and others. He founded Testament Records in 1963 as a platform for African American folk, blues, and gospel performers, and produced records by Quicksilver Messenger Service, Big Joe Williams, and Jean-Luc Ponty, to name a few. Twice nominated for a Grammy Award (1973 and 1993), he was posthumously inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame (1996) in the category known (at that time) as Business-Production: Media or Academic. His works continue to be widely-cited resources for music researchers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection of over eight hundred sound tape reels, including blues and jazz music and interviews with musicians; several hundred photographs of prominent blues and jazz musicians, primarily from the 1960s and 1970s; manuscript materials about blues and jazz musicians, arranged by the name of performer; and articles, drafts, and notes written by Pete Welding, journalist, record producer, and historian of blues music.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Pete Welding collection is organized in 10 series:

item.ref:
Series 2: Typed drafts of
Blues Book
and
Jazz Book
, by Pete Welding
Series 4: Articles, reviews, and other writings
Series 6: Materials from sound recording containers, and original containers

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

Documentation on the tape boxes was used to create the inventory for this series. This information was partially transcribed and subsequently edited, including abbreviations that were expanded and names that were normalized. Logged recordings are included here, and the information from them used to correct the inventory. Where possible, the title of the commercial recordings has been documented. When recordings have been digitized, the engineer's notes take precedence over those on the tape boxes; the archivist has edited these notes for clarity. Further details about the recordings appear on the tape boxes and accompanying manuscript materials. Dubbed recordings have been noted as such. Unless otherwise indicated, interviews were conducted by Pete Welding.
During the digitization process, SR215, SR740, and SR810 were found to be blank.

The sound recordings are organized in approximate alphabetical order, given the available information. Works by individual artists are organized by surname and when there are multiple artists by the first surname. If the sound recording is a compilation it is alphabetized by album or project name. Events are alphabetized by the event name.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 00:53:00, Side 2: 00:53:00) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: Pete Welding (PW) interviews Billy Boy Arnold (BBA), a Chicago blues harmonica player. A child's voice can be heard in the background.

row.entry: PW and BBA talk about BBA's background and his interest in blues music.

BBA talks about when he at started playing and his musical influences. His first instrument was harmonica. He talks about getting lessons from Sonny Boy Williamson (SBW). [BBA says he was born in1935.]
BBA talks about musical influences prior to SBW. BBA says that he learned mostly from phonograph records.
BBA says that he saw SBW only twice prior to SBW's death at age 34. BBA talks about SBW's harmonicas.

BBA talks about playing After SBW's death. He learned to play guitar from a man called McGee. (BBA's primary instrument is harmonica). He talks about some of the other musicians with whom he played. He tells about making his first recording, at age 17, for Cool Records.
BBA says his second recordings were for Vee Jay Records. He started performing in clubs. He played frequently with Bo Diddley, and also with other musicians.
BBA and Bo Diddley made recordings for Chess Records. BBA talks about the sessions and specific songs recorded.

BBA, Bo Diddley and Little Walter were making records for VEE Jay, Universal and Chess. This forced decisions, because of various recording contracts, about songs, lead singers, and musical arrangements.

BBA and Bo Diddley went to New Orleans. When they returned to Chicago, BBA put together his first band to lay at a new club called The Bell House. He talks about the band members. He says that the gig was a success and they were booked for 3 months.

BBA discusses the next steps of his career. He was always paid union scale and paid union scale to his band members. He talks about some of his gigs. He says that he was successful playing in the clubs. He says he worked steadily in the 1950s and into the 1960s.

BBA says that Chicago's music scene changed from B.B. King and Muddy Waters to more contemporary (early 1960s) music. He says that in the 1960s Chicago still had an active blues scene in its black community.

BBA talks about the blues musicians active now in Chicago. He says it is primarily the old blues men, but there are not too many opportunities to perform. PW says that the Civil Rights Movement may have been part of the reason for loss of interest in the blues. BBA responds.
BBA says "I think what happened to Chicago is this." He talks about migration of people from the south and changes of musical taste. PW adds to this by talking about changing interest in jazz.

BBA talks about music being played on the radio. PW adds his thoughts. BBA talks about different generations of blues performers. PW talks about the commercial aspect of music. BBA talks about Vee Jay and Chess records and their commercial considerations.

BBA talks about interest in the blues being cyclical and generational. He says that his family is one of the last blues families in Chicago. There are now only a few clubs in Chicago in which blues are played. But if you go to other cities, there will be no blues clubs.

PW asks "Who are the young guys in Chicago (today) who re making any kind of noise?" BBA responds. PW says that most of the new blues record's he's heard in the last ten years "are pretty dull." BBA replies. They discuss this at length. BBA says that there is no more money in playing the blues.

BBA says that black musicians are moving away from the blues into other genres. He says that if, today, you want a blues guitar player or drummer you probably have to hire a white guy. PW expresses concerns that the blues is going to die out. BBA agrees.

PW asks BBA where he performs. BBA says that he does not work around Chicago. He goes over seas once or twice a year. They talk about the amount of money one is paid for playing. BBA talks about the potential and future of the blues.

PW SKS IF THE European scene is good enough to support yourself. BBA says "no," but the Europeans are really dedicated to the music. PW talks about blues fans in the United States. The talk about record promotion and distribution.
BBA talks about the record shops in Chicago when he was young. BBA says that there is no need for blues today. He explains.
BBA talks about segregation and the blues. He says blues are a way of expressing your frustrations.

BBA says that after the rebellions of the 1960s people turned away from the blues. They turned away from the blues of twenty years ago and turned to the blues of Stevie Wonder. BBA says that his grandmother dealt with the blues by singing (humming) gospel songs. BBA and PW talk about the blues and emotions.
PW talks about the commercial pressure on the blues. BBA says that the blues is a universal form of music.

on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:41:40) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: In response to PW's question, TB says he was born in Spartanburg, South Carolina in 1910. He started playing guitar when he was 16 years old and left at age 18 to earn his living playing music. He first started to play piano, then moved to guitar. He had 3 brothers and 5 sisters. During his growing up years, his family sang mostly religious music.

He says, as a kid, he heard lots of blues: Bessie smith, Lonnie Johnson, and Tampa Red (among others). He heard their records. His family had mostly records of sacred music. He was attracted the blues when he was around 12 years old.
TB talks at length about why he was attracted to the blues.
TB talks about switching from piano to guitar. He talks about Pink Anderson and Blind Simmie Dooley who he heard in Spartanburg. He talks about a fiddle player named Blind Roland Martin.
PW asks TB how he learned to play guitar. He answers that he is basically self-taught. The first song he learned to play through was "John Henry."
TB says he went to Chicago in 1933. He heard Big Bill Broonzy and Tampa Red. Prior to moving he worked as a barber. He went on the road in 1928.
PW asks about the period from 1928 to 1933. TB answers. He says he worked on a medicine show and talks about it.

TB says that after he left the medicine show he went to Knoxville. Where he met Carl Martin, Howard Armstrong and Bill Ballanger. They travelled and did radio broadcasts. TB talks, at length, about this group. They played mostly in Taverns and private homes.

PW asks what happened when the band got to Chicago in 1933. TB answers. They were booked into theaters, mostly doing variety shows. He mentions some of the other musicians playing around Chicago at this time.
TB talks about making records with Louie Blue [Hill Louis] in 1934. They cut 4 numbers. TB talks about other records he made.
TB talks about playing around Chicago. Then he went into the Army. When he got out, after WWII, he worked in plants in Detroit. They talk about Howard Armstrong.
TB talks about some songs he has written. He talks about Joe McCoy. They made some records together.
TB talks about touring with several other musicians in 1951. He lived in Dayton, Ohio, then returned to Chicago in 1953.

Logger's note: A man named Joe is also present at the interview.

row.entry: PW starts by asking JB several questions about himself and his family.

PW asks JB how he first got started in music. JB replies that he started with guitar then switched to violin. A man named Bob Jones started him playing violin when he was 22 years old. They discuss where JB played and the music he played.
JB left Mississippi and went to St. Louis. They talk about the music JB learned from records. JB did mostly construction work to earn his living.
JB says that he worked construction in St. Louis. They discuss where he played in St. Louis. JB says he played mostly guitar.
JB and Joe talk about meeting and playing together.

PW asks WLH several questions about himself and his musical background. WLH says that when he was four years old his sister took him from Mississippi to St. Louis. He talks about the work he did n St. Louis.
PW asks WLH about playing music in St. Louis. WLH answers.
PW asks WLH when he first took up the harp (i.e., the harmonica). WH responds. JB, WLH and Joe have worked together over the years. The discuss this.
PW and WLH talk about how WLH learned to play the harp. They talk about where WLH learned the songs he played. WLH also wrote some songs.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 01:04:24) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: Interview location: Palo Alto, California. Continued on
SR218
.

row.entry: PW asks AC a number of "obvious questions." AC says he was born in Leona, Texas, about 125 miles from Houston, on October 1, 1932. In about 1939 his family moved to Houston. When he was 11 or 12 years old, he started to get interested in music. He started to play piano in High School, then switched to guitar.

AC says that, at age 14 or so, he learned to play guitar from his cousin. Willow (?) Young. When he was about 16 years old, he started to play with bands in clubs. He also learned from T-Bone Walker and several other musicians.
His first guitar was a home-made from a cigar box. Later he was given a home-made guitar that he did work for. This guitar was made from an oak tree. He started playing in clubs on the weekends.

PW asks if AC had a "church background." He answers that his mother was deeply religious so was not pleased that he was playing blues. He talks about when he really could play guitar at a professional level.

AC talks about the music he played in the clubs when he was 16 years old. He says he played a lot of Lightning Hopkins's music. They talk about Lightnin' Hopkins records. They discuss the blues style differences between Lightning Hopkins and T-Bone Walker, and how AC was influenced by them.
They talk about AC playing in a tavern for about a year. AC added a bass player to the band. AC started playing electric guitar.
PW asks about the music scene in Houston in the late 1940s. AC responds. He says that he was also listening to records.
PW asks if there were other bands around at that time which were stating to record. AC replies. He says he added horns to the band, it was now 7 pieces. He cut his first record around this time.
PW asks about changes to the music in 1950 so. AC says that he did not hear any of the Chicago musicians. They talk about Texas bands.
They talk about when AC added horns to his band. They talk about the bands and musicians AC heard and those that he did not hear.
PW asks about the style AC was playing. AC answers and talks about developing his own style.
They talk about AC returning to Houston in 1954. AC had day jobs. He played music nights and weekends. He managed to keep his band together during this time.
They discuss AC cutting a record in 1958. AC talks, in detail, about the musicians on the record.
PW asks if there was any immediate results from the recording. AC answers that he got more bookings, but kept his day job for about 6 more months. He says he cut another record in 1960.
PW asks what AC thinks is the most difficult things about living the life of a musician. AC answers. The talk about there being a continuing interest n the blues.
PW asks about the differences between modern blues and older blues. AC answers. They talk about blues guitar styles. They segue into discussing church music, soul music, and modern jazz.
They discuss guitar tunings. AC demonstrates on a guitar.
PW asks where AC learned the tune he was playing (to demonstrate guitar tunings). AC replies. The continue discussing guitar tunings.
PW asks why AC has stuck to the blues since the mid-1940s. AC answers. PW asks about the (musical) differences between the blues and rock-and-roll. AC answers.
PW asks which blues musicians have been the most influential on AC. He responds. They talk about B.B. King. The talk about "working a crowd."
PW asks how AC feels about performing. AC answers. They talk about getting the band together (musically). They talk about musical arrangements.
They talk about AC's most recent album. AC talks about the musicians on the album.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:06:15) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Continued from
SR092
.

row.entry: PW and AK discuss the resurgence of blues
PW and AK talk about how AK just plays the blues, not other genres
PW and AK talk about how the sounds of blues have gotten louder and bigger. AK discusses how he's been influenced by this.
PW and AK talk about the guitar and amplifier AK uses

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Side 1: 00:32:20, Side 2: 00:36:09) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
LC engineer's note: In-depth interview with Judy Collins, focused on her 1962 LP,
Golden Apples of the Sun
. She is interviewed by Pete Welding.

row.entry: PW and JC discuss the song "Golden Apples of the Sun." She learned it from Will Holt. It is based on a poem by William Butler Years. The melody is by Richard Dyer Bennet.
They discuss "Bonnie Ship the Diamond" which she first heard on an album by Ewan MacColl and A.L. Lloyd. She sings a bit of a whaling song.
They discuss "Little Brown Dog." She learned it from Logan English. It is included in a book by Ruth Crawford Seeger, "Animal Songs."

They discuss "Twelve Gates to the City." JCV in not sure where she learned it, she's heard so many people perform it. She once played it on to of the Arch in Washington Square Park, New York City, for a television program.

They discuss "Christ Child Lullaby." She heard it on an Isla Cameron recording. They talk about the dearth of Christmas songs in the Afro-American (the use the term Negro) tradition. PW talks about some Alan Lomax recordings Alan Lomax collected and two books he wrote. PW talks about his interest in collecting Afro-American music.
They discuss "Great Selkie of Shule Skerry." JC says she got this song from the research of Kenny Goldstein. She tells the story of the song and its context. She sings a bit of the song.
JC speaks about the significance of the songs on the album, in terms of human uncertainty and knowledge.
JC talks about the Polish song, "Tell Me Who I'll Marry."
JC talks about the song "Crow on the Cradle."
JC talks about the song "Lark in the Morning."
JC talks about the song "Sing Hallelujah."

JC talks about the song "Minstrel Boy" (not on the album). PW talks about a six-part suite called "Day in the City," by Don Friedman, based on the theme of "Minstrel Boy." He gives her his own copy of the record.
JC talks about the song "Shule Aroon." PW looks through (perhaps) books for references to the song, while JC speaks. He puts on a record that has a version of the song, sung by an unidentified woman.
JC talks about urban folk music, and the five-banjo playing in folk music.

JC talks about her music background, and lacking a particular grounding in any culture, though she had classical music training. She talks about her family's Irish and Protestant background. She talks about her interest in the music of other geographic regions (Israel, France).
JC talks about errors in the transmission of her own story, and other folk musicians who are not quite honest about their own background. The recording cuts off abruptly (end of the tape).

row.entry: PW asks LD background questions: where he had lived, family life, when he started playing.
PW asks LD whom he learned to play from.
Discussion of LD's arrival in Chicago in 1941 and the music scene there.
PW asks LD about his first recordings. Tampa Red and Roosevelt Sykes are mentioned.
Discussion shifts to LD's move to New York City, the music scene, and recording there.
PW brings up Sykes and Red again, they discuss LD's relationship with Red.
PW asks what sort of non-musical work LD did in New York City.
PW asks LD when he started recording in New York City; Jade and Sittin' In recording companies are mentioned.
PW asks about rehearsing before recording sessions, LD talks about Brownie McGhee.
LD states he hasn't done any recording since 1948.
LD: "Before I met you, I almost gave it [music] up."
PW asks LD why he plays the blues, follows up by asking how LD goes about writing a piece. LD refers to his songs as poems.
PW asks about the pieces LD had played for him earlier that day.
PW asks if LD has met any other famous people. LD Mentions Big Joe Williams.
LD: "A man who writes a song, has a photograph mind."
LD mentions recording the TV Blues for PW earlier that day [specifically "tonight"].
PW asks about musical activity in Memphis when LD was a kid. This leads LD to talk about his early music career.
PW asks about catching freight trains.

PW and LD discuss LD's singing and playing style. PW asks about other guitarists LD has met who he enjoyed or might have influenced him. LD mentions Georgia Slim, Stick McGhee, and Big Joe Williams [calling him Joe Lee Williams].
[Phone rings and PW answers it. Someone, probably LD, can be heard lightly playing a guitar]
[Tape jumps] PW asks where LD met Joe Williams.
PW asks LD where he learned the older songs that he had played for PW earlier that day.

did.unittitle:
Blind Teddy Darby interview / Pete Seeger dub recording,
October 9, 1964
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Darby: 01:16:17; Seeger: 00:16:13, 00:16:41) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, quarter track, stereo ; 5 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: Interview location: Chicago, Illinois. Collector's original number: 170.

LC engineer's note: "Tape is predominately a Blind Teddy Darby interview in full track mono format, but after 01:16:17 interview is cut off and tape goes into the 4-track stereo format and contains a recording of the commercially released LP
Gazette Vol. 2
by Pete Seeger (Folkways FN 2502, 1961)."

row.entry: PW asks TD several questions. TD say that his name is Theodore Darby and he was born in Henderson, Kentucky on March 1, 1906. He had no brothers or sisters. He did not come from a musical family. His mother played a couple of songs on guitar, which TD discusses.

TD's family moved to St. Louis when he was sever years old, because his father got a job there. TD went to sixth grade in school, then was sent to reform school for fighting. He was in reform school from March, 1921 to May, 1922. He went blind in 1926, from glaucoma.

PW asks what happened when TD lost his sight. He had some money saved in the bank from when he was working. He decided to make his living as a blues player. He says he really learned to play the blues in the city work-house in 1927. TD explains what he did which caused him to go to the work-house. He asked his mother to bring him a guitar. He taught himself to play four pieces.

TD says he got out of the work-house in June 1928. He went home and lived a normal life. He played and sang at house parties. He says there was a Syrian neighborhood in which he often played. He also played in a "smoke shop" that sold whiskey and had two back rooms used for gambling. This was in 1931.

PW asks how TD got to make his records in 1929 for Paramount. TD answers. They talk about Paramount going out of business, then restating in 1948. TD talks about some of the musicians at the 1929 recording session: Henry Brown, Roosevelt Sykes, and Davey James.

PW asks if Henry Brown recorded at the same time. TD responds the Henry Brown just play piano for other musicians. TD talks about how much he was paid to record in 1931. TD says he recorded two numbers for Victor. He explains. They were composed by himself and recorded in Chicago.

PW says TD's next records were made in 1935. He asks TD what he was doing between 1931 and 1935. TD responds. He met the woman to be his wife in East St. Louis during this time. In 1939 TD started getting a "blind pension."

PW asks about the records TD made in 1935 for (Vocalin). TD responds. They discuss the songs in that session. They talk about "The Pokino Blues." TD says that Pokino was a popular card game. He also talks about a church song he composed in the work-house, "God Moved in the Wind." He sings it.

TD says he has an excellent memory. He know about 125 telephone numbers. He talks about his time in the Army in 1922. They talk about "The Decoration Day Blues" which he recorded. His mother taught him to play in Spanish tuning.
PW asks if there was much music back in Kentucky when he was a kid. TD answers. They talk about a number of songs of that time.
PW asks about when TD was young. Were there any naught or dirty songs the guys would sing among themselves. TD answers and gives some examples.
PW asks about a man named Tommy Webb. TD says Tommy Webb was his cousin. He was killed over two cigarettes in about 1951.
TD and PW played together in East St. Louis starting in 1930. TD talks about some records they made together in 1933.
TD says the last records he made were in 1937. He cut four numbers. They discuss the songs.

PW asks TD what he has been doing since he last recorded in 1937. TD says that he has been playing around East St. Louis. TD talks about getting his blind pension. He says that he has been a church member for ten years and so has not played the blues in that time.
PW asks if TD made any records between 1930 and 1954. TD replies. He talks about making a living with his handicap.
PW asks TD what he thinks the blues are. TD responds at length.
PW asks what makes a good blues song. TD responds and gives some examples. They talk about many blues songs being about women.
TD says that he got married in 1938. His wife died in 1958. HE talks about how he met the woman he married.
They talk about most blues songs being written about women.
PW asks why there is such a strong separation between blues songs and church songs. TD answers at length. He talks about the need for love in the world.
PW says that many blues songs are written about love, physical love. TD has been talking about "love in the heart." TD talks about this.
PW ask how TD goes about composing a blues. TD replies. They talk about some songs he recorded for Decca.
TD talks about being blind and his life. He talks about moving around when he was young.
PW asks TD if he enjoyed making records. TD responds. They talk about a recording session scheduled for tomorrow.
PW asks TD if was a wild guy when he was young. TD replies. TD says he's been married three times.
"The Dying Miner" (the first part of the song is missing)
"When a Fellow is Out of a Job"
"I Come and Stand at Every Door"

Blind John Davis with Billy Boy Arnold,
April 15, 1962
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:49:05) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Collector's original ID number: 175.

Logger's note: Blues songs performed by Blind John Davis and Billy Boy Arnold, and an interview conducted by Pete Welding (PW). The recording starts off with performed songs, and at 22:49 the interview begins. The song titles are based on notes from the tape box.

row.entry: "How Long Blues" begins to play (with Billy Boy Arnold)
"Someday, Baby" [this song might also be called "No Mail Today" based on the lyrics]
"How Long Blues" [the tape case has this labeled as "different bass styles"]
"Listen to Mama" (according to the tape case); this song may be called "How Long Blues"]
They talk about the previous song and how long John has been in Chicago.
They talk about when John first started playing music and some aspects of his recording career, including when he started and who he recorded with.
They talk about John's procedure for recording in studios and who helped him set up these recording sessions.
They discuss when John first started playing piano professionally. They discuss the "Chicago house rent party scene" and how he came to be involved in them.
PW asks John if he can play the typical music you might hear at one of these house parties. PW suggests a "boogie tune."
Starts playing an instrumental jazz song - a boogie tune you might hear at a house party.
PW asks him to explain the different kinds of basses that would be used in a boogie woogie?
John plays a demo of a rolling bass
John plays a demo of a walking bass
PW asks if there are any other kinds, and John starts playing another demo. (He says this one is mostly one of his - no special name for this one.)
John is playing some piano while the interviewer and another man talk. The guys joke around with each other and laugh.
John introduces "Sweet Patootie." [He doesn't play the song - maybe the recording gets cut off?]
PW asks if there are any pianists when he was working in the '30s whose work he especially liked and if he tried to pattern his work after anyone?
John shares an anecdote from his childhood about why he started playing piano.
John names the main people who helped him learn to play
John talks more about his background and musical relationship with an artist named Tampa.
John discusses his relationship with Sonny Boy Williams
John discusses some bass players he has played with
PW asks John what he thinks of the blues singers today compared with the boys he recorded with.
John talks about playing with Dr. Clayton.
John talks about his relationship with Billy Boy Arnold (who is in the room and who was presumably playing another instrument during the recordings).

row.entry: "Rainin' on the Ocean" (a Ma Rainey song)
TD talks about his early days. He learned to play the organ. He is the son of a minister.
TD and his family lived in a suburb of Atlanta. He got most of his training at the Chicago Music College. He talks about playing the organ and the piano.

TD says he saw Bessie Smith perform in about 1912. He also saw Bud Lamee (?) [a bluesman] and Ma Rainey. The theater bug bit him. HE talks about "hip shake" parties. He talks about "song plugging" to sell sheet music.

PW asks how TD heard songs aimed at the "colored market." TD responds. They talk about ragtime music. They talk about church music and performance music. TD talks about two performers named Blind Broom and Blind Tom.
"Nearer My God to Thee" (the first song that TD played.
TD says that music was "a gift." He loves all kinds of music.
PW and TD talk about other songs. They talk about getting music written down on paper so that it is not lost. They talk about ragtime and ragtime composers. They talk about Negro spirituals.

did.unittitle:
Thomas A. Dorsey interview, #2,
June 30, 1962
,
July 7, 1962
did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:45:25) : analog, 7 1/2 ips; half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW asks about the music being played at parties when TD was getting started, about 1912. TD replies and plays pieces of several songs.
They continue the conversation about old songs. PW asks about musicians, in the early days, who TD admired. TD responds. He learned the walking bass from Ed Butler. He plays a sample.
PW asks when boogie woogie style music came in. TD says he first noticed it in about 1912. He plays sample.
TD says he was about 12 or 13 when he started playing at parties and in public. In 1914 Ed Haywood Sr. started playing in the Atlanta area.
PW asks if TD knows any simple folk songs, not blues or church songs. TD replies and plays "Sawdust."
They discuss this song. They talk about when TD raveled and played in the lumber camps, about 1923. TD talks about a show he played in the hills of Kentucky.
They talk about a book TD wrote and another that he is writing.
They talk about a piano called "long boy" that was owned by TD's aunt. She sold it in 1928. She ran a fish stand in Atlanta.
The Rollin' Mill is Done Gone (1)
The Rollin' Mill is Done Gone (2)
TD says he wrote this song. They discuss it.

PW asks if TD wrote or knew any other songs about local events. TD plays part of a song and the spiritual that uses the same melody. They talk about work songs. TD plays part of a "water boy song." After talking with PW he plays several more verses.
TD says he left for Chicago when he was 16. His mother came to live with him in 1935. He talks about "buffet flats" and house parties.
A Good Man is Hard to Find

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:36:00) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: TD talks about the opening of a Ma Rainey show at the Grand Theater in 1921. (The city is not identified.)
TD talks about Ma Rainey's band. He identifies, and talks about, members of the band and other musicians.
TD talks about a venue called The Weekend Lifesaver, where he and the band played on Sundays. He talks about a singer called William Franklin.
PW asks if TD was the musical director of MR's band. TD responds.

TD talks about playing piano in movie theaters for silent films, in 1913 or 1914. He says that people who wanted to be around music, or learn music, or learn the latest songs hung around the movie theater. Some of these people went onto become great artists.

TD says that after a week at the Grand Theater, Ma Rainey and the band went to Kansas City. That's where he met Teetna (sic) Palm. Pa Rainey was diseased by then. MR and the band were on a six-month tour. He names some of the cities where they played.

PW asks what MR did with all of her money. TD responds "That's what the world wants to know." In 1961 TD visited MR's brother in Columbus, Georgia. He was told the "Ma made a lot of money, but her weakness was young men." TD expands on this.
PW asks how MR worked up her material. TD responds.
PW asks how MR paid her musicians. TD responds. He says he earned enough money to get married.
The following season, TD "took ill" after 2 shows, so he left the tour and he band. The last time TD talked with MR about her show was 1929.
TD talks about the experience and musical education he got from working and touring with MR.
TD describes a "typical" MR show. It was during vaudeville days. The show ran for about an hour and fifteen minutes.
TD talks about MR being "the mother of the blues."
TD talks about being on MR's recording dates. He was with MR for about 3 seasons.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:46:11) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW asks TD to talk about his recording during the 1920s and 1930s after he let Ma Rainey. TD responds.
TD talks about recording with Tampa Red. He did not have an exclusive recording contract, so he recorded for several recording companies.
PW asks how TD prepared new material for recording. TD responds at length.
PW asks if TD and Tampa Red worked together outside of the recording studio. TD responds.
TD says that in about 1930 "the blues began to start on the wane." He talks about a group called The Hokum Boys.
TS says "deep down in me I had these gospel songs..." ..."When the blues left town, I concentrated on the gospel songs."
TD talks about gospel singing groups and blues singing groups.
PW asks about the condition of Negro religious music around 1930. TD responds.
PW asks about hymn style music transitioning to gospel music. TD responds. He says that he "coined the words gospel songs" and "gospel singers."
TD says that he wrote one of the first gospel songs which became popular. He sings it, then talks about it.
TD says that gospel singers have become big business. He talks about publishing gospel music. He talks about "1 sheet" music and selling copies for 10 cents each.
PW asks what makes a gospel song and how does it differ from other forms of Negro music? TD answers and gives several examples. He mentions the Fisk Jubilee Singers.
TD says this music is a "great American heritage." The music totally evolved in America. He talks about minstrel shows.
TD talks about where and when gospel music has become.

PW asks to go back to what differentiates gospel songs from the others. TD says he came along at a time when America needed gospel music. He discusses this at length and gives (e.g., sings) examples. He mentions W.C. Handy.
TD says that right now gospel singing is at its height.
PW asks how gospel music differs musically from its predecessor. TSD responds. He mentions the blues.
PW talks about gospel music and folk music of the Negro. TD responds.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:21:47) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW and TD discuss gospel music as folk music. They also talk about folk singers

TD talks about the place of music in the world. He calls it one of the "heavenly things." They talk about composed songs and how they are changed by the "folk process." They talk about music written down on paper.
They talk about influential, individual performers and groups doing gospel music.
PW asks TD what or whom he considers to be the first legitimate singer or group of gospel singers. TD responds. The first person he mentions is (Sister) Rosetta Tharpe.
PW asks about the Universal Singers and what other gospel groups TD might have heard. TD responds.
They talk about gospel singers and gospel choirs in church.
PW asks what dozen songs, of all the songs TD has written, would be a representative collection of his work. TD responds.

row.entry: Interview of Phil Edwards (PE). PE talks about he was born in 1990 and moves to Virginia in an early age. He also talks about famous bands and band players of the time. Musicians mentioned include Fat Waller, Russell Smith, Joe Smith, John Kirby, Eddie Cole, Benny Carter, Eubie Blake, Noble Lee Sissle, Willie The Lion Smith, Buster Bailey, Johnny Green, Louis Armstrong, Don Raymond and more.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate; 01:00:15) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: Static and comments about songs being good and condenser mic quality.
DE discusses coming out to Los Angeles and starting a band. DE mentions an earlier band, The Hindustani Jazz Sextet, and exploring rhythms and gospel sounds with a big band.
DE talks about the quality of the Musicians Union practice space in L.A., the accomplishment of getting band members to practice at 10 am on Wednesdays, and adding multiple basses to the group.

DE mentions going back to New York and working with Lucas Foss in a big band, as well as forming a smaller group to play around Buffalo (New York). This smaller group had two drummers and to basses. Upon returning to L.A. DE wanted to form a big band with a large rhythm section: five drummers and four basses.

PW asks what brought DE to this "rhythmic investigation." DE gives background on his previous experimentations with rhythms, and then discusses studying Indian music with Harihar Rao and discovering new rhythms.
DE's "all-consuming passion" to develop himself rhythmically.
DE's background as a composition grad student at UCLA, and where he first met Harihar Rao.

DE mentions the rising prominence of the sitar in rock music and jazz, and Ravi Shankar's upcoming visit to the United States. DE states that the rock groups "take the easy way out" by just using the sitar drone sound and not the more complex Indian rhythms.

PW introduces the subject of semi-tones in Indian music, and different scale systems, suggesting that the difference between Indian and Western music is greater than just rhythms. DE gives a somewhat ambiguous reply, asserting that equal temperament rhythms are abominable, and eventually coming around to the power of intonation in blues music.

PW restates the subject, asking if "tonal ambiguity" isn't just as "excitement inducing" as the rhythms. PW brings up bottle neck slide playing in blues guitar as an example. DE reasserts that, compared to the Indian scale system, Western music is only just scratching the surface. DE goes on to mention his development of a quarter tone trumpet, and how it enables him to explore different sounds and pitches.
PW and DE discuss exploring tonality in the "massed sound of the orchestra."
PW asks when DE reorganized or actually formed his current band, if there are any issues with keeping the band working, and how often they play.

DE discusses the makeup of the band, that not all of the players are professional musicians, and auditioning his rhythm section. DE gives names and background information about the bass players and drummers in his band.
PW and DE discuss the public interest in the Indian/Western music crossover via jazz and the Beatles.
PW mentions The Byrds coining "raga rock" and the Beatles' "Norwegian Wood."

DE talks about Harihar Rao coming to the States to work with jazz musicians, and whether or not American jazz musicians were interested in Indian music at that time. DE asserts that, like jazz, you have to study Indian music to fully appreciate it.

DE discusses audience reactions and PW circles back to DE's assertion that the rhythms were the crucial part of the music. PW asks how DE maintains the synthesis of Western and Indian music. This leads into a discussion of the differences between the two types of music and their development.
DE discusses how he goes about combining Eastern and Western music.
PW asks how long it took the other musicians to play DE's compositions with ease and proficiency.
PW asks who else in the band is contributing musical arrangements.
PW and DE talk about an upcoming release on Liberty Records, recorded live at Monterey, and another recorded at the Pacific Jazz festival.
PW asks about recordings done for Irving Mills/Mills Music. DE explains that Mills was a financial backer that fell through and tried to stop DE from releasing his own recordings.
PW asks what jobs are available for a big band these days.
PW asks about Ellis Music Enterprises.
PW lays out how DE could reach a more specific audience by advertising in the MENC journal and self-publishing a method book.

26. One note plays and gets cut off
Announcer tells the audience that the band will go on to tour South Africa, and introduces who is playing which instrument.

The announcer [or a band member] announces that they will now hear from their "lovely" vocalist, Marty Grosz. The audience laughs. Marty [presumably] says, "This is one of the nicest transvestite bands I've ever played with. First couple of weeks were rough because of the garter belt chaff, but we've conquered that problem."
The announcer/band member starts talking about the album Soprano Summit and that they will now perform "Stealin' Away" ["Steal Away Blues"].

The announcer/band member says they would like to perform another song - one that is associated with a singer from Duke Ellington's band, Ivy Anderson. He says, "But we have our own Ivy Anderson - Marty Grosz!" The song is, "Rose of the Rio Grande."
The announcer/performer does a run-through of who is playing what instrument, while they play music in the background.
They go from announcing who's who and playing music into their next song, which an instrumental: "C-Jam Blues"
Some music plays - not a song, just some random notes. People in the audience are chatting.
The next song is an instrumental work: "I Got Rhythm"

Announcer/band member explains that the arrangement they just played [name unintelligible on recording] was something that Bob took from original 1911 sheet music from a John [last name unintelligible] orchestra. He then explains that the next song is a piece called, "I Had It, But It's All Gone Now." Sidney Bechet wrote it in 1923 and Bob [Wilber] and him recorded it together in 1958.
Instrumental song, "I Had It, But It's All Gone Now."
The next song is announced: Marty Grosz and George Duvivier play "Swing 39"
Next unidentified and instrumental song starts playing. Unidentified and instrumental. You can hear faint chattering in the background.
The recording ends and the announcer/performer calls out, "Bob Wilber!"

Logger's note 1: Both tape sides were recorded at The Big Horn, Ivanhoe, Illinois. Side 1 was recorded on November 12, 1972, through Side 2 to the song "That's a-Plenty." The balance of Side 2 was recorded on March 1, 1975 (four songs, beginning with "Just You, Just Me," and on May 28, 1973 (from "In a Sentimental Mood" to the end of the tape.

Logger's note 2: Personnel for the show on November 12, 1972 - Russ Whitman, clarinet and bass saxophone, Bob Wright, piano, Rail Wilson, bass, Don DeMicheal, drums. Personnel for the June 1, 1975 show: Ralph Sutton, piano; George Duvivier, bass; Barett Deems, drums. Personnel for the May 28, 1973 show: Bob Wright, piano; Marty Gross, guitar; Dan Shapera, bass; Hilliard Brown, drums.

did.unittitle:
John Lee Henley interview and songs,
November 30, 1965
did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:37:50) : analog, 3/4 ips (for interview) and 7 1/2 ips (for songs), half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW asks when JLH was born and when, JLH responds and mentions he started playing harmonica when he was young, but really became polished in his early 30s.
PW asks what made him start playing the harmonica. JLH responds and mentions his musical influences, and that he liked hearing it as a kid.
PW asks what harmonica music JLH recalls from his childhood and if he can still play them.
PW asks if JLH had any siblings and if they played, JLH responds that he didn't. Then asked about his parents, JLH said they didn't either but his father farmed and played baseball as a pitcher.
PW asks what the nearest big town was, JLH responds and mentions that his grandfather didn't want to let him play music.
PW asks why JLH thinks many people, especially religious, are against the blues. JLH responds and mentions his grandfather was a preacher and considered it sinful if it wasn't religious music.

PW asks "he didn't approve of you playing the harp at all?," JLH talks about how his dad left when he was young, he never got a guitar because it was too big and easy to find, but he could hide his harmonica in the house easily and would play it whenever his grandfather left the house. He says eventually his grandfather heard from others that he could play very well.

PW asks how JLH learned to play harp, and how long it took him. JLH responds, and explains it took him a long time, and that he figured out a lot of the harp positions by himself, and learned by ear, as well as learning from the artist Sonny Boy.

PW asks JLH if other than teaching himself, if there were any other artists that he learned from, and if there were any other players he knew played well near him. JLH responds and mentions Rice Miller.
PW asks when JLH remembers seeing Rice Miller for the first time. JLH responds 1938 and talks about Rice's career and how he used to imitate Sonny Boy Williams and lie about being him.

PW asks about when he was living in Canton (spelling?), his hometown if he remembered much music being played, places to go to hear, good players, or people who recorded. JLH responds and mentions that most recorded music he heard growing up he didn't know who they were, but there were good players.
PW asks if JLH could hear much blues on the radio growing up. JLH responds no, but mentions several on record.

PW asks if there was much musical activity in Canton where he grew up, or if there were parties and places he could hear a lot of music. JLH responds that there were many. PW then asks if there were many people from around Canton that were skilled that played nearby and if the house parties occurred at any particular time of the year. JLH responds with a few artists, and says they were year-round.
PW asks if JLH played at many of these events, and if he played with anyone. JLH responds and mentions playing with Buddy Carr (Carl?)
PW asks when JLH came to Chicago. JLH responds (1943), around when he found Sonny Boy. He brings up musicians he was familiar with some he knew personally, Walter, Muddy Waters and more.

PW asks if JLH ever started working professionally as a musician. JLH responds, and says only really around 1953 he had a lot going on semi-professionally. PW mentions a man named Spires, Willy Smith, and a record JLH played on.

PW asks if JLH recalls how many numbers were on the previously mentioned record with Spire. JLH responds. PW talks about record companies hand picking songs to put on a record during this time period out of a set list, to figure out how many songs were cut from the record they are discussing.
PW asks how Melrose heard about JLH. He responds.
PW asks if there were any musicians JLH worked with around town other than Spires. He responds.
PW asks how JLH ended up making his first record. JLH responds and talks about the band members and recording in 1948.
PW asks if anything happened with the aforementioned record. JLH responds that it didn't get out of the city they were in.
PW asks how much JLH got paid for making the session. JLH responds that he never saw any money.

PW recalls JLH saying he wasn't interested in doing music professionally. JLH responds that he would have if he got a break. PW says "he was smart enough to not have too much depend on music," JLH says he would have if it got the chance, and that records makes the careers, and that he saw it as more than a hobby. They talk about selling record, and it making it big having to do with more than just good music, but it being the right time as well.
PW mentions that musical fads and trends come out and they sell, and sometimes selling music is about it being the right time for the music being played.
Interview cuts out - JLH performs a song on harmonica.
They discuss FM's new job, driving a tractor.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks John Lee Hooker (JLH) a series of questions, such as - his age, where he was born, when he started playing guitar and when he got his first guitar. He responds and also talks about working on a farm with his father.
PW asks JLH for information on when and where he was born, as well as how he first became interested in music. He responds.

PW asks when JLH first started learning to play guitar, and if he used the same G tuning as his father and if he played in open tuning as well. JLH responds and talks about his father's musical style and what he learned from him.

PW asks about what made JLH switch from spirituals to the blues. He responds and talks about spirituals being very influential to the blues and them being very similar in certain ways, making it sound like not a huge leap. He mentions he feels that he can express himself more through the blues.
PW asks how JLH's stepfather earned a living. He responds.
PW asks if playing came easy to JLH. He responds talking about how he doesn't have many problems competing with others because he's not playing music that everyone plays, so it helps set him apart.

PW asks if JLH knew if other players had similar styles around him and/ or used the same G tuning his father shared with him. He responds talking about playing house parties and such with other musicians he grew up around.

PW asks JLH what kind of music was played at the house parties and dances he mentioned, if there were bands, and if any well-known blues players came through to these events. He responds, and also mentions that he was doing it as more than a hobby and put everything he had in music.

PW asks JLH if he was playing any music before he played blues and spirituals/ religious music. He responds mentioning that he started playing around 12 and around 13 switched to spirituals, then blues shortly after.

PW asks JLH if he played many things his stepfather played when he was learning, if his stepfather had many pieces he played a lot, and if he played at many of the house parties mentioned earlier before JLH did/ if he had a reputation as a great local musician. He responds, and mentions that he plays very similarly to his stepfather but also changes it up by keeping his music modern and having music all age demographics would enjoy.
PW asks how most people around him growing up earned a living. JLH responds and says that most people were farmers and he wasn't interested so he ran away to Memphis around the age of 14-15.

PW asks if JLH was playing much when he was in Memphis, how far he went with school, and when he realized he had a great musical talent/ gift. He responds and talks about his life in Memphis and moving to Detroit.
PW asks when JLH moved to Detroit, and about his life there. JLH responds talking about it being easy to live and make money during the war time and that he married while he lived there.

PW asks if 1948 is around when he cut his first record, and how he came to write his first record. JLH responds talking about playing around Detroit with bands, saving a lot of money making it easier to write and record music and how a recording label approached him about going into the studio because he liked him and was well received around town was well.

PW asks if these were his first hits, and about recording several other popular tunes the same day he first went into the studio with the record label that invited him into their studio, and if he recorded with others on those first tunes. He responds and mentions that being well received really helped his musical confidence and that he recorded solo for that first time.

PW asks if after his first hits if he found himself being booked in many different places, and if he ended up working with bands. JLH responds mentioning he started working with a 4-piece for around 9 years.

Interview partner Mike (last name?), asks if JLH would play his earlier solo hits with the full band if the crowd requested the songs or if he would play with the band to make it easier to dance to, and if he remembered playing with many other musicians when playing gigs that he fit well with, and if they made any records. JLH responds.

Mike mentioned JLH having an incredibly original sound, and asks if he ever considered or played in the predominant blues style for fun like "BB King style," and that he heard BB King recordings with JLH's name mentioned on it but wondered if was actually on the record. JLH responds and tells him it was and that he doesn't really like the style.

Mike asks when JLH first got an electric guitar, and if he preferred one or the other. JLH responds and tells them about how he loved playing acoustic as well because it's not such a rowdy and loud crowd as the bar, everyone sits quietly and listens.
PW asks JLH how he goes about arranging and writing his music, and if he had to write a story. He responds.
PW mentions that he noticed JLH would sing songs about audience members, and Mike asks if he ever wrote lyrics on the spot for records. JLH answered that he did both of these things quite a lot.
Mike asks JLH if he had trouble adapting covers to his style. He responds.
PW asks is JLH is recording any music in town since he's there for the interview as well. He responds.
Mike asks who JLH's favorite blues singer is. He responds.
Mike asks if JLH ever wanted to work with a big band. He responds and mentions he has a tune written for a big band style.
JLH pulls out guitar to play song (not included in this recording)
PW asks about the background story behind some of the records on JLH's early records. He responds and mentions some names he used were due to record contract guidelines.

PW asks what the blues scene is like in Detroit, and about the clubs there. JLH responds and mentions Detroit not providing enough financially for his music so he doesn't do much there anymore. They talk about there being a lot of younger players still around that area, and big record companies there recording them.

PW mentions "There is a lot of talk about old-style blues are going to die," and asks about the country style dying out as well. JLH responds and mentions that it's still alive and well, and that interestingly, all the college and younger kids seem to be very into both styles.
PW mentions JLH seems to be playing more ballads during this time period. JLH agrees and mentions that a colleague told him he does well at reaching several fields like pop, folk, blues. Etc.
PW asks who is responsible for helping JLH coming up with some album concepts and how he writes for a more widespread audience then just one genre.

PW mentions it seems that JLH selects his material differently depending on the location of the gig. JLH strongly agrees, and mentions the need to adapt to the audience and location. Mike, PW, and JLH talk about reaching Muddy Waters since JLH is in town.

Mike mentions Muddy being asked about his thoughts on a lot of young white kids are learning country-blues and some of them getting a lot of attention for it, and if the young colored kids were still interested in the blues anymore. JLH says that younger colored kids like the blues but they feel they shouldn't listen to it because it pulls them back towards reminders of oppression and slavery and how the blues originated, so they push it away.

[Unknown person] asks if he thinks young colored kids are ignoring the blues and acting too cool. JLH agrees and thinks they are embarrassed of the roots of the blues, and that white kids are incredibly into the music.
Mike asks if JLH has an idea why white kids are so into the music and learning it. JLH responds.
PW asks JLH "What makes the blues so different, so distinct from other kinds of music." JLH responds and mentions "It's a feeling," as well as talks about how emotionally involved the music is.

PW says that a lot of songs do this, so what is so different about the blues than other music that emotes similarly. JLH responds, he said the blues is "your broke, disgusted, owe bills, losing your car, girlfriend, not having money and happiness"
PW acknowledges that blues come out of sadness, but asks if there is happy blues too. JLH agrees and says happy blues is "soul blues, and soul blues is sorry."
Mike asks what about boasting music in blues. JLH responds, then continues to talk about qualities of blues.

[Unknown person from before] asks if younger people seem to be too restricted and act to cool and can't seem to fully get out their emotions and feelings in the blues or other styles in the same way because they don't want to be vulnerable and "wear their hearts on their sleeves." JLH agrees and says the young kids love the blues, but are ashamed and don't want to own the blues, and that the blues have gotten bigger than ever as the years went by.

Mike mentions he heard someone said "There hasn't been a good or in his opinion significant younger blues singer in 20 years" and asks about what happens when JLH, Muddy, and other greats retire. JLH says he wants to write a book about himself and other blues singers to let the younger generation know about them so that it lives on.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:18:35) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Interview location: Chicago, Illinois.
Logger's note: This recording comes in on an ongoing interview. I could not find the other part(s) of the interview. Most of the SR center on PW asking about Robert Johnson (RJ).

row.entry: PW asks WH when he first met Robert (Johnson). WH answers that the met in 1930 in Memphis, which was WH's hometown. He was 13 years old; RJ was 18 years old. He says that RJ was born in Colma (?) Arkansas. They talk about RJ.
PW asks what kind of person RJ was. WH answers at length. They talk about the records RJ made. They talk about RJ's family. PW asks if RJ was "a ladies man."
They talk about RJ playing slide guitar. WH says that RJ taught Muddy Waters to play slide guitar. WH talks about the places he played in 1940/41. He says he moved to Chicago in 1950.

They talk some more about RJ. WH says that RJ was "a church going man" before he started playing the blues. They talk about RJ and WH playing together. WH says this was for about 8 years. The talk about RJ's records.
They talk about Robert Lockwood. PW asks about Lockwood meeting RJ.
PW asks WH what else he can tell him about RJ. WH answers and say, among other things, that RJ was kicked by a mule when he was young.

1966 or before
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:23:19) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: Interview with Joshua Barnes Howell (Peg Leg Howell) before his death in 1966.

Logger's note: An unidentified person (UP) interviews Peg Leg Howell (PLH). An unidentified woman is also present and speaks on occasion. She may be Howell's wife. At the end of the tape (time 20:40) the interviewer "speaks a letter" to Pete Welding, rather than writing it.

row.entry: PLH answers questions about himself, such as name, date of birth, where he was born, etc. He talks about working on his father's farm, then working at a fertilizer plant.
PLH left the farm, in 1912, because he lost his leg to a gun shot.
PLH was about 35 years old when he moved to Atlanta. He learned to play guitar n1909. He was self-taught. He made a record for Columbia in 1927. They talk about the songs on the record.
PLH spent time in prison for selling whiskey.
they talk about how much PLH as paid for his first record. They talk about who PLH recorded with and some of the songs he recorded.
they talk about some songs that PLH wrote and some records that he made.
PLH talks about some of the other (blues) sings he knew. He talks about what he did after he stopped recording, in the earl 1930s.
PLH says he lost his other leg in 1950. He talks about why he stopped playing and singing.
PLH talks about a new record of his that is coming out after all these years.
the interviewer "writes a letter" to Pete Welding, rather than actually writing it.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:32:59) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track (one direction only), mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: This is the first part of a two-part interview Pete Welding conducted with Howlin' Wolf [Chester Arthur Burnett]. The interview was conducted in Chicago, Illinois. Part 2 of this interview is on SR002.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) says he want to ask a couple of basic and general questions: "Where were you born, and when and how did you get started playing?" Howlin' Wolf (HW) answers.
HW says he heard Charlie Patton play.
HW came to like Blind Lemon's music.
HW talks about some of the other musicians he heard.

Discussion about Charlie Patton: HW says Charlie Patton taught him to play. HW can play his music. They talk about Charlie Patton, his music, and where he played. They talk about various guitar tunings Charlie Patton used.
HW talks about the Mississippi Sheiks.
They talk about HW's progress on the guitar and the music he preferred. He mentions Dick Banks.
HW talks about the work he was doing on the plantation. They talk about Charlie Patton's death and where he is buried.
PW asks about the other musicians Charlie Patton played with.
HW talks about when he started playing professionally and the places he played. They talk about the music HW played and where he learned it.
They talk about HW starting to play harmonica. He learned from Rice Miller, who married HW's sister. [Alex "Rice" Miller, a.k.a. Sonny Boy Williamson II]
HW says he played with Robert Johnson and other musicians. They discuss Robert Johnson, his music and his death.
They talk about the kind of person Robert Johnson was.
HW says that Muddy Waters may have known Robert Johnson. Muddy Waters learned to play from Son House. They talk about Willie Brown. They talk about playing for dances.
They talk about the music of Son House. Son House and Willie Brown played together. PW as if Robert Johnson might have learned from Son House or Willie Brown.
PW asks about the music Dick Banks played.
PW asks who were the musicians Howlin' Wolf most admired and got the most from. HW says he got the most from Charlie Patton and Lemon Jefferson. They discuss other musicians HW heard.

PW asks when HW thinks he got something of his own going with the music. HW talks about his first band. Some people called HW "the foot," others called him "the bull cow." HW tells how he came to be called Howlin' Wolf.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:32:52) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track (one direction only), mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: This is the second part of a two-part interview Pete Welding conducted with Howlin' Wolf in Chicago, Illinois. The first part of this interview is on SR001.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Howlin' Wolf (HW) "where did you play with that band?" HW responds and also says that he was doing some "radio work" during this time.

PW asks when HW switched over to electric guitar. HW responds and also says that he went into the army in 1941. He considers himself and entertainer rather that a professional musician. After the army, he went back to farming.
They talk about HW's radio program. HW says that the first record he cut was on the Sun label.
PW asks when HW started recording for Chess. HW says that he also recorded for RPM.
PW asks when HW moved to Chicago. They discuss his experiences, e.g., recording and paying clubs.
PW asks about people in the bands HW played with, as well as other people he played with.

PW asks HW what he thinks about the interest in the blues that came "with the folk music thing." HW responds. They discuss HW records for Chess. HW says he went to Chicago Music School "to learn his position." They discuss how HW uses a bass line in his recordings. HW likes to have "his sound" different than that of other players.
PW asks HW if he was much of a "church goer." PW talks about Tommy Johnson. They talk about John Lee Hooker. PW asks why the blues are so popular.
An unidentified third person asks HW about work songs. They discuss work songs on the farm.
PW asks if it was Sonny Boy who started HW playing "the harp."
PW asks when HW got his first guitar. HW says that his father bought it for him.
PW asks HW how much time he spent in Memphis. PW asks "what do you think the blues are?" HW introduces his wife, Lily, who has walked in.
PW asks if HW sings for himself or for other people. PW asks how HW goes about "working-up" a song.
The unidentified person asks HW if he ever came into contact with the Chicago blues piano players. He responds that he got to Chicago after that music passed. They talk about jazz and the blues.
HW says that he has travelled around the world. PW asks how his music was received in Europe and elsewhere. They talk about a tour HW did in 1964.
PW asks about a jazz festival in Washington D.C., in 1952, where HW was the only blues musician on the program. PW asks if HW has played other large festivals. PW asks about HW playing at colleges.
PW asks how HW "works-up a song now-a-days." PW asks about HW's family and children.

odd.p: The first two songs are the conclusion of the Key Largo performance; see notes for Side 1. The balance of Side 2 is Howlin' Wolf's performance at Big Duke's, Chicago (beginning with the song "Decoration Day"). Date: June 20, 1970. Musicians: Howlin' Wolf (harmonica, guitar, vocals), Hubert Sumlin (guitar), Lucky Lopez (guitar), Willie Young (tenor), Calvin Jones (bass), Burl Cassell (drums). Johnny Littlejohn replaces Sumlin on "Decoration Day" and "Chicken Shack," and replaces Lucky Lopez on "Bad Bad Whiskey," "Hard Luck Blues," and "You Don't Know."

row.entry: The interviewer asks when JH first heard of the song. JH answers it was way back in about 1902, when he was 10 years old. He mentions a blues harp player named Rufus Hank who strummed the harp. JH says he picks the guitar and doesn't strum it, and talks about Spanish tuning.
JH says he can't remember the whole song and then sings a fragment of an unidentified song.
The interviewer asks if JH can play something else with the opening tuning.
The interviewer asks if JH uses any other tuning of the guitar.
JH tunes the guitar to different pitches.
JH sings "If You Don't Want Me" again.
The interviewer asks if the tuning has a name. JH says it is called an open tuning.
JH mentions he remembers "Four O'Clock Blues."
The interviewer talks about "Avalon Blues." JH says he composed the song.
The interviewer asks if JH knows any songs about cocaine and drinking.
The interviewer asks if JH remembers any songs about shooting.
The interviewer asks who Louis Collins is. JH says Louis Collins is a peaceful man and talks about the shooting incident.
The interviewer asks if JH has a favorite song he would like to play.
"Trouble, I've Had It All My Days"
The interviewer asks if JH knows any songs about jail. JH says he can't remember.
The interviewer asks if JH knows any songs in the same tuning/key.

The interviewer asks if JH first heard "Stack O' Lee." JH said he was about 12 years old when he learned the song from his cousin, who passed away now. His name was John T. Arnold. The interviewer asks if JH can play "Stack O' Lee" in his cousin's tuning. JH then talks about who Stack O' Lee is.

The interviewer asks if JH can sing "Four O'Clock Blues."

The interviewer mentions the song "I Got Mine."
The interviewer asks if JH can play any railroad songs and mentions the song "Won't You Come Home Bill Bailey." JH said he does not know the song.
JH plays some unidentified fragment on the guitar.

JH talks about Jim Canaan is a good times place near Memphis. JH tunes the guitar.
The interviewer asks if JH remembers "When the Train Comes Along" and "Alabama Bound."
The interviewer asks if JH can play "Looking this Way."
The interviewer asks if JH remembers "I am a Poor Boy" and "God's Unchanging Hands."

,

scopecontent.p: Collector's original ID number: 125.

row.entry: The interviewer asks JH play the song again the other way.

The interviewer announced: Recorded on the stage of the Coolidge Auditorium, Library of Congress, July 15 and 23, 1963, with Richard K. "Dick" Spottswood, JH's discoverer, recorder and personal friend. Interviewers Richard Spottswood and Joseph Hickerson; Engineers John Howell and Robert Carneal.
"The interviewers ask JH about his birth place and his nick name. They talk about "Avalon Blues" and the story of Tom Hoskins discovered JH.
"The interviewers ask JH how he composed "Avalon Blues" and recorded in 1928. JH said the first blues he ever heard was from Joe Turner.
The interviewer asks if Joe Turner is a real person from Avalon. JH says he first heard of the blues at a hot joint.
"JH first heard of Hot Joint when he was eight, the time he first played the guitar.

JH talks about William Henry Carson and his guitar. JH tells the story of playing Carson's guitar while he stayed over JH's house. JH talks about the story of when his mom bought him a second-hand guitar. Then JH mentions he has 7 brothers. One of the brothers moved away with JH's guitar.
The interviewer asks JH if he remembers the song he picked up from William Henry Carson
The interviewers ask if that's same version as William Henry Carson played. They ask if JH can play "Richland Woman Blues."

The interviewers ask about the contracts of JH's recordings for the Okeh Records. JH talks about how he met Willie Narmour and got started with recording for Okeh Records. When Narmour won first place in a 1928 fiddle contest and got to record for the Okeh Records, he recommended Hurt to Okeh producer Tommy Rockwell. JH talks about the earning from making recordings and thinks the record company tricked him.
The interviewers ask if JH has ever played at the churches nearby his home area. JH says yes.

JH says that is his own melodies. The interviews asks if people around him has any records in the 20s and 30s. JH mentions a record store near Greenwood, MS. JH says people have records of him, and other singers like Lonnie Johnson and Blind Willie Johnson."
JH talks about the opening tuning of the guitar.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Side 1: 00:31:06, Side 2: 00:32:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: This is a dubbed portion of recordings made at Coolidge Auditorium, Library of Congress. See SR068-SR069 in the
Tom Hoskins collection, 1963-1967 (AFC 2011/026)
. Joe Hickerson's voice can be heard at times. The tape box back reads: J. H. 3 or 4.
Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times.

row.entry: JH sings "Will The Circle Be Unbroken" while playing the guitar to accompany himself.

Two unidentified men mention a few songs to JH and ask if he knows those songs. Songs mentioned: "Down by the River Side," "Jack of Diamonds," "Jesus make up my dying bed," "I Know His Blood Can Make Me Whole." (The interviewer's voices are very quiet which makes it hard to hear clearly what songs they are discussing.)
JH sings an unidentified tune accompanied by the guitar.

The interviewers mention albums released by Gotham Records. One of them asks if JH remembers songs about flood and hurricanes. JH says he heard a song but he can't play it. He reflects on Bessie Smith's song "Backwater Blues."

The interviewers asks about several songs JH composed in New York and mentions "Avalon Blues" is one of them. They inquire JH about his original ideas of the song and guitar part before recording it in New York. The men then ask how JH composed the guitar part to accompany the song. JH answers he has the melody first and then makes up the guitar parts as the song develops.

JH tells stories of his encounter of a large mud snake, nicknamed "stinging snake" in the countryside. The interviewers ask if JH ever sees pythons and it prompts JH to tell more of his personal stories. JH talks about ways to deal with the snakes.
JH plays an unidentified melody on the guitar.
The interviewers says that one of the guitar strings is tight and adjust it for JH. The same unidentified melody continues and leads to a song which opens with lyrics: "Poor boy, long way from home."

JH plays and sings "Frankie and Albert," which opens with lyrics: "Frankie was a good girl, everybody knows. She paid one hundred dollars for Albert's suit of clothes. He's her man, and he did her wrong."
The interviewers discuss several song with JH. Songs mentioned include "Poor Boy Long Ways from Home," "Let the Mermaids Flirt with Me," and "Waiting for a Train."
JH sings a song which opens with lyrics: "All around the water tank, leaking in the rain. A thousand miles away from home, waiting for a train."
JH sings part of a song: "Climb above the mountain, give me a load of cane, to make me a bit lazy, sweet old life it takes."
JH sings part of the song "Salty Dog."
The interviewers mention "Blue Harvest Blues" and ask JH how his composed the song "Salty Dog." JH answers his second cousin gave him some ideas about it and another song called "The Chicken Song."
The interviewers prompt JH to sing "Funky Butt."

The interviewers and JH discuss several songs: "When That Great Ship Went Down," "Oh Mary Don't You Weep," and others. They ask JH if he remembers any party songs or cheering songs. JH thinks of the song "Sunshine" and plays it.
The interviewers and JH discuss several church services songs:" Jesus Is My Everything," Running for my life. The tape ended abruptly while they discuss the railroad songs.

row.entry: BJ says he was born in Granite, Maryland on February 25, 1906. There were 5 children in his family. He started playing guitar when he was 15 years old. He talks about learning to play. Jim fuller was his first teacher. He talks about Fuller. BJ started playing for house parties.
PW asks about the social structure and industries in Granite, Maryland. BJ responds. Most music was played at house parties. BJ talks about the music they played in the early 1920s.

They talk about Jimmy Rogers and railroad songs. BJ says that a lot of the men worked for the B & O (Baltimore and Ohio) railroad. BJ gives some examples of group railroad songs. The songs set the rhythm for the work. This extended in to the 1930s, when machines took over much of the (formally) manual work.

They talk about the song "John Henry" and speculate as to whether John Henry was a real person. B.J. talks about the song "Ida Red." He says that every work gang had a lead man who set the rhythm. They discuss the selection and role of the lead man.
B.J. says that he worked for the B & O railroad in 1921 and 1922. He started as a water boy and became a spiker. BJ says that the railroad provided living quarters for the gang.
PW asks if much music making was going on. BJ says yes, then explains. PW asks about a Maryland style of blues. BJ says there is and explains.
RJ talks about a song he wrote, "Long Steel Rail." He talks about a banjo player who wrote a song inspired by honey bees. PW says that songs of this type are like a "social chronicle."
RJ talks about the songs "Careless Love" and "Troublin' Mind."

RJ says that he's been living in his home since 1927. They talk about a situation, with his manager and a recording company. They talk about records, playing styles, and the artists who made the records.

They talk about people learning new songs from records and changing them round to suit their own musical style. PW asks if there were any people in the area who had a musical influence on other musicians. BJ responds.
PW asks if there was strong separation blues songs and sacred songs. BJ says yes, mixing the two was frowned upon. They discuss this at length.
BJ says that he expects a new interest in the blues among the younger generation. They talk about blues, blue grass, and country music. BJ talks about jazz. PW talks about jazz musicians.
