did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel : analog ; 7 in.
1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:28:30) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, quarter track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: Pete Welding conducts an interview with blues singer Mary Johnson.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Mary Johnson (MJ) where she was born and what year. She responds and says was born in Eden Station, Mississippi. She does not say the year of her birth.
MJ explains what it was like growing up and the games she played such as catching crawfish and cooking mud balls. She cannot remember the names of the rhyme games she used to play.
MJ discusses her Native American ancestry on her mother's Side 1nd Creole ancestry on her father's side.
MJ remembers listening to live jazz and blues music when she was younger such as "Rainy Day Blues."
MJ tells PW string bands used to play blues music for dance events. They played on guitars, saxophones, drums, etc.
MJ discusses how her mother was very strict and did not allow her to listen to blues music or hang out with boys.
PW asks MJ was she still in school or working when she moved here (doesn't specify where "here" is located) when she was fifteen years old.

PW asks MJ how she got into blues singing and she answered that it was through her husband. PW backtracks and asks her when she got married to her husband. She married in 1917 in Chicago when she was 17. She met him at Jazz Land, a place she used to go dancing.
MJ discusses her husband Lonnie's singing career
PW asks MJ who suggested that she start recording blues music
MJ explains she was entertainer before she started recording records in 1928
PW asks, "How did you come to write them (your albums)? What was the idea you had?"
PW asks MJ how she composed "Black Man Blues"
MJ explains where she was entertaining (night clubs) and what the entertainment consisted of (singing)
MJ discusses the environment of St. Louis when she was growing up. There were many musicians and night clubs available
PW asks MJ if she feels a member of the church should or should not sing blues music
PW asks MJ "How did you get the (nick)name signifying Mary?"
MJ explains why she believes blues music is a popular genre. She says blues music is a feeling that allows you to think about how you were mistreated.
PW asks MJ why she gave up performing and writing music in 1934 and 1935

did.unittitle:
Shorty Rogers and His Giants, live at The Lighthouse,
circa 1962
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Channel 1: 00:28:47, Chanel 2: 00:31:40) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Collector's original ID number: 67.
Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times. Channel 2 has audio break-up towards the end of the program.

Archivist's note: Channels 3 and 4 have not been digitized, and may have no content. The tape box lists two songs ("Greensleeves" and "Tadd's Delight"), and has the words "lighthouse" and "jazz." These live recordings probably were made at The Lighthouse, a jazz club in Hermosa Beach, California. Towards the end of the first program a man introduces the band members: Lou Levy (piano), Gary Peacock (bass), Larry Bunker (drums), and Gary LeFebvre (tenor sax and flute). While the band itself is not named these musicians constituted the lineup for the group Shorty Rogers and His Giants, circa 1962.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 00:48:47; Side 2: 01:23:22) : analog, 3 3/4 ips and 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: Side 1 - interview and music; Side 2 - mostly blues tracks. On Side 1, the speed changes constantly. On Side 2 the speed changes from 3 3/4 ips to 7 1/2 ips at 01:07:55:00, then goes back to 3 3/4 ips at 01:19:16:15.

row.entry: Start of the interview of LH by PW. LH says he was so small that he had to get up on a truck with his guitar in order to be seen when he performed.

LH says that he was born on March 15, 1912. He says that when he was eight years old, he left home with a guitar around his neck. He initially went to Alabama and Mississippi. He also went to St. Louis and Chicago. He left brothers and sisters behind. He says that his mother is still alive.

PW asks LH why he thought he was a good guitar player when he was right years old. LH responds. He says he played sometimes in the streets when he was a young man. He talks about some of the musicians he met, including Lonnie Johnson and Howlin' Wolf.

PW asks LH if he remembers any blues singers coming through his part of the country when he was young. LH replies Bessie Smith but not Ma Rainey. He says he spent most of this time in Houston, Texas. He developed his own guitar style. He travelled a lot.

PW ask what was it that made LH feel he wanted to play music. LH responds. He says that he cannot read music. He says all of his brothers had guitars and played. They had a family band. He says that he also played piano and organ, and a little bit of harp (harmonica).

PW asks about the records LH made in the last 4 or 5 years. LH answers. He says he first recorded in Los Angeles. He talks about his experience making records. He says that he's made about 100 records.
PW asks LH what he did when he stopped playing on the streets, how did he make his living. LH answers. He says he was in jail for a while for fighting.
They talk about a scar on LH's leg from having to wear a ball and chain. LH says he had to work on a road gang.
They talk about LH's marriages and his wives.
PW asks LH if he thinks he's made things better for people by playing his guitar. LH answers.
Portions of several unidentified songs, including "Freight Train."
"Don't Think Cause Your Pretty" - Lightnin' Hopkins [there is a short "pause" in this track, i.e., no sound]
"Life I Used To Live" - Lightnin' Hopkins

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 01:03:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: ML says that he was born in Brazos County, Texas on April 9, 1895. His father was a farmer and he was also a farmer. He talks about his youth.
PW asks about brothers and sisters. ML responds.
ML says that his father was a sharecropper. PW asks if there were other types of farming arrangements. ML answers and they discuss ML's experience.
PW asks if things got easier because of "scientific farming methods." ML answers. HE talks about the owners of large tracts (farms) of land.
They talk about Tom Moore, who is mentioned in an old song. ML first heard this song in 1938 or 1939. ML talks about the lyrics of the song.
ML's nephew, T. Lipscomb, and Lightnin' Hopkins wrote additional verses to the song. They used the name Tim Moore on the record. ML talks about the Moore brothers. He talks about Hopkins's record.

ML mentions that he was discovered by Chris Strachwitz. PW asks about the difference between a songster and a blues singer. ML says he plays many types of music in many different venues, so he is a songster.

PW asks where ML picked up the songs he has. ML says that he was born into a musical family and learned songs at home. They talk about ML's father, a fiddle player. They talk about the song "Cotton Eyed Joe."
They talk about nicknames. ML's father nicknamed him Bordy (?) Glen [his given name was Beau De Glen Lipscomb].
PW asks ML when he became interested in music. ML says that he started playing when he was about 14 years old. He played for dances.

PW asks how ML got interested in playing guitar. ML answers. He says he learned guitar from two old men. The first song he learned was "Sugar Babe." The next song was "Take Me Back." He mentions Blind Lemon and two brother from whom he learned.
PW asks how ML learned his songs. ML answers. He says the music runs in his family. ML discusses some of the songs he made up.
ML asks how ML got his first guitar. ML answers. He talks about the first piece he learned to play on the guitar, "Sugar Babe." They talk about guitar tuning. PW plays some and then ML plays.
ML talks about Mexicans coming to Texas to pick cotton. He learned some music from them. He talks about learning music via "open air."
ML says that he will not play a song in public until he has learned it perfectly. He does not change songs, he plays them the way he learned them. He talks about Lightnin' Hopkins.
ML tunes his guitar and plays a blues instrumental.
ML plays and sings "Darktown Strutters Ball."
PW asks where ML heard that song. ML answers.
PW asks ML if he was in the First World War. ML answers that he had too many dependents, six, so did not serve.
ML says that this was a tough piece to play.
PW asks how ML figures out songs like that. ML answers. He plays a little bit in several keys.
ML plays and sings; the first line is "I done had my fun."
ML performs a convict song; the first line is "I asked my Captain for the time of day."
PW and ML talk about convicts. ML learned this song from a former convict.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate; 00:22:50) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW and ML discuss why ML plays many types of music, unlike Lightnin' Hopkins who plays only blues. They agree that music has to have a feeling, a foundation. They talk about why, in the 1920s or so, only blues were recorded on race records.
ML says the "Sugar Babe" was the first old song he learned to play. He plays and sings two versions of "I'm Out and Down."
ML plays an unidentified song with a rock and roll beat.
SL plays and sings a song he calls "You Can Knock me Down, I Slow Drag Up again."
PW asks what kind of things ML would play back in Texas. ML responds by playing and singing "Ain't Gonna Do You No More Cherry Bowl" which is also called "Shake, Shake Mama, Buy You a Diamond Ring."
PW and ML talk about the dances at which ML played. ML talks about his father playing fiddle at dances. They talk about harvesting, picking, the cotton crop.
ML sings and plays, first line: "I got the dust new morning, new morning in my life."

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: A dub recording (from a sound disc) of a radio broadcast of this cantata on the time following Abraham Lincoln's assassination, and the response from various groups and individuals. Burl Ives and Pete Seeger are featured singers.
Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times, and there is significant hum from the tape.

row.entry: Song lyrics: The news has come to Washington. Abraham Lincoln's time has come. John Booth shot Lincoln dead....
Narrative: The lonesome train. President Lincoln's train traveled from Washington to Baltimore, Baltimore to Philadelphia, Philadelphia to New York....
Song lyrics: It was a strange and quiet crowd. Nobody wanted to talk aloud. Lincoln's people are waiting there...

Narrative: They tell a story of the train. They say that Lincoln was on that train. When the train started a trip that day, Lincoln was in Alabama, miles away. Yes sir. Down in Alabama, in an old wooden church. Didn't have no paint. Didn't have no floor....
Narrative: Down in Alabama, some wooden benches, and Mr. Lincoln sitting in the back.
Narrative: From Washington to New York, people are lining the tracks. Song lyrics: A strange crowd. A quiet crowd. Nobody wanted to talk aloud. Most people are moaning...

Narrative: In Cleveland, the crowd was there. They came to mourn. But a few of them went home to celebrate. They curse him every day that he lives until the day he died. The copperhead went home to celebrate.
Narrative: Until all men are equal and all are free, there will be no peace. When men are brothers, and men are free, the killing will end, the war will cease.
Song lyrics: I will be going home soon, the soldiers said. I will see you there, Mr. Lincoln said.
Song lyrics: They were his people. He was their man. Couldn't tell where these people left off. And where Abraham Lincoln begins.

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: Includes an aircheck of "Just Jazz," hosted by Ed Beach. WRVR-FM, New York. The recording is of Side 2, right track. The left track is blank.

row.entry: A narrator (N) introduces the band members. N states this recording takes place in New York between 1949-1969.
Warne Marsh (WM) plays "When Your Lover is Gone" on saxophone.

N states this audio was recorded in the band's living room. Riverside Records picked up the recordings and issued them in the 1950s and again in the late 1960s. Joe Albany (pianist) Warne Marsh (alto saxophone) and Bob Whitlock (bass and mic) were a part of Clifford Brown's album, "Daahoud."
JA, WM and BW play an instrumental selection recorded in Los Angeles 1957 titled "One Life" [?]
N explains background information about the next composition and how it is the only original in the set. N announces the musicians for the next song.
The jazz musicians perform "Background Music" by WM for Atlantic Records in 1955.
N announces the musicians playing the next piece titled "Cross Kurt" [?]. It was recorded for Capital Records in 1949.
N announces the next piece "Marshmallow" based on [Cherokee's?] harmonies recorded in 1949. The title of the set is named at 22:11.
The jazz band plays the next selection titled "Marshmallow."
N discusses the piece "Long Gone" from the set titled "Free Willing" recorded in 1955. N introduces the instrumentalists.
The announcer (N) introduces the next piece titled "Never Knew"
N announces the musicians for the next piece recorded in Los Angeles in 1956
The jazz band play an improvisation of their next instrumental piece, "I Remember April"
N announces the next piece, "Simply One March" [?] recorded by Atlantic Records in January 1958
N informs the next piece was arranged by Clare Fischer titled "Lenny's Pennies" recorded in Los Angeles 1968 by Atlantic Records
N gives a brief history of the music from this set dated between 1949 to 1969. He announces the musicians for the last time.
The final instrumental jazz selection for this recording

may all come from the same session at Clare Fischer's house that produced the album
Report Of The 1st Annual Symposium On Relaxed Improvisation
, released on Revelation Records (1973). The album was recorded on May 9, 1972.
Vendor's digitization note: There are speed fluctuations on the tape.

scopecontent.p:
LC engineer's note: The tape was reused for at least three projects, going by documentation written on the box. The box is marked as a 1970 session tape for jazz-fusion band Contraband's Epic Records LP,
Time & Space
(released in 1971); an unrelated recording by Pete Robinson and Charles Orena from 1972; and an undated session with sax player Warne Marsh. The audio appears to be Warne Marsh. No documentation on the Warne Marsh recordings exists on the box, unlike the other previous contents. The recording ends abruptly midsong. There is no evidence this recording was ever mixed and released.

on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:26:32) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: Pete Welding (PW) interview with the blues musician George McCoy (GM), who often recorded with his sister Ethel, and sometimes with his sister Ruby. McCoy and his sisters were related to Memphis Minnie, whom he refers to here as his cousin. In addition to McCoy and Welding, an unidentified man can be heard in the background, occasionally helping McCoy with answers. An unidentified woman can also be heard in the background (possibly McCoy's mother).

row.entry: [Static] GM speaking, giving the years that he and his sisters were born [Ruby 1917, GM 1921, and Ethel 1923] in Booneville, Mississippi.
[Static] GM talks about their father moving them to Mobile, Alabama, and then St. Louis, Illinois. Their father became acquainted with Big Joe Williams in St. Louis.
GM says that Joe Williams' guitar was in "that G tuning." PW then asks how GM learned to play guitar
PW asks where GM and his sisters learned their songs. This leads GM talking about how his mother would tell them riddles, and stories about witches.
PW asks about GM's father, who died in 1963.
PW asks how long it took GM and his sisters to become proficient on the guitar.
GM talks about his father learning the song "Where was the Sun on Some Old Rainy Day," from Rube [?] Marshall.
GM talks about the song "Cyclone Blues."
GM talks about writing a song called "Short Haired Woman." GM makes reference to Lightnin' Hopkins having a similar song with different words.
GM talks about learning to play harmonica after Joe Williams gave him one when he was 13.
[PW leaves the tape running while he goes to get the songs GM played "the other night." It is unclear, but seems to be a list of song titles that GM played at a previous meeting.]

PW and GM discuss the songs GM played "the other night." These songs include: "Rising Sun Blues," which GM says he learned from his cousin Oliver Jumper: "Heavy Hipped[?] Mama," which GM says his cousin Memphis Minnie "made that"; and "Childhood Sweetheart," which GM says his sister [does not specify which one] wrote with Chuck Berry.
PW asks GM about being related to Memphis Minnie, and living in Memphis during the depression.
GM talks about his sister Ruby.
GM talks about early career with the gospel group the Master Harmonizers.
PW asks GM about how he writes his blues songs.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate; 00:20:48) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Fred McDowell (FM) a series of questions, such as - his age, where he was born, when he started playing guitar and when he got his first guitar. He responds and also talks about working on a farm with his father.
PW asks FM where he went when he left the farm. He responds.
PW asks if the was anyone FM "got a lot from" while he was learning to play guitar. FM responds "Raymond Paine" (spelling?) and explains. He talks about his uncle.
FM tells how he got his first guitar. He tells about the jobs he had when he was in Memphis. He talks about moving to Michigan.
PW asks where FM learned the songs he sings. He responds.
PW asks how "Mr. Lomax" [Alan] came to meet FM. He responds.
PW asks about "other fellows" with whom FM played. He responds.
PW asks Mrs. McDowell "where are you from?" She responds and talks about her life. She says that she sings only church songs. She talks about a group with which she sings.
PW asks FM if he has any brothers or sisters. He responds.
An unidentified man asks FM about records he may have listened to and learned songs from. He responds.
PW asks if there are any other singers or guitar players from whom FM learned to play or sing. He responds. They talk about house parties.

PW asks where FM learned different guitar tunings. He responds and demonstrates "Spanish tuning" on his guitar. They discuss which songs are played in which tuning. FM demonstrates. They discuss several songs.
They discuss FM's new job, driving a tractor.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:33:12) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: This is the first part of a three-part interview Pete Welding conducted with Fred McDowell. The complete interview is on SR064,
SR065
, and
SR066
; dub copies are on
SR336
and
SR337
.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) and Fred McDowell (FM) discuss telling jokes and stories. FM heard some of them from Eli Green and different people. FM tells a few jokes.
FM tells a joke about a man on a train.
FM tells a joke about a man and dumplings.
FM tells a joke about dogs, rabbits and foxes at a dance.
FM tells a story about a man named John wrestling a bear. PW tells another story about John and a bear.
FM tells a story about John being quick.
FM tells a story about John praying for food. A mocking bird appears.
FM talks about being raised by an uncle. The uncle did not tell FM bed time stories, but he did tell him about slavery times.
FM talks about marriage and wives, on the plantation, during slavery times.
FW asks what the uncle did after slavery was abolished. FM responds.
FM talks but his grandfather, named Max Stone.
FM talks about his uncle "picking on a guitar." FM "Picks on" the same guitar.
PW asks about the time after the war when the slaves were free. FW responds and talks about a white man, named Jim Knox, giving his uncle a start.
PW asks how people "made it" after slavery. FM replies.
FM talks about the job he has now.
FM talks about his wife and his wife's mother.
FM talks about his current job in a service [gas] station.
FM talks about how he was raised, and how children are raised today. He talks about how he raised his son.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:33:16) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR064
.

row.entry: Fred McDowell (FM) talks about how he was raised, strict and loved. He talks about his aunt and uncle.
FM talks about playing music in the early days. He tells about a typical party. He discusses some "bad men" who came to parties.
FM tells a story about building a levee in Tennessee. At a party one night, there was a big fight.
Pete Welding (PW) asks about fish fries and selling food at parties. FM responds. He says they sold store bought liquor at parties when they could get it.
PW asks how it was arranged for musicians to play at a party. FM responds and tells what it was like to play at a party, e.g., no money, free drinks, play all night.
FM talks about people growing and raising what they ate.
PW asks where FM was living during the time he was playing at fish fries. FM responds.
PW asks how old FM was when he got married and how he came to get married. FM says it was "spite work." He explains, and talks about his wedding and marriage. He caught his wife cheating.

PW asks when FM stopped playing at parties. FM mentions his mother. He talks about jobs he had. He tells the story of how he found his mother. His mother's husband was good to him. They lived on a farm.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:33:16) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR064
.

row.entry: Fred McDowell (FM) continues talking about playing in the [town?] where he was living with his mother and step farther. He talks about two local brothers (unnamed) who played guitar and fiddle in the area. FM tells how he became popular to the extent that he was taking [gigs] away from other local musicians. At this time, he was being paid to play.
Pete Welding (PW) asks if the dances (e.g., parties) were different than they were in [Rockville?] FM replies. He talks about the dances the people did.

PW asks when FM gave up playing for parties. FM says he went to New Albany and stayed for about a year and a half. He worked at farming. He talks about his sister who was living in [Como]. FM moved to [Como], got married and lived there. This was 1941.
FM talks about his draft status. He did not go into the army. He spent the war years in [Como].
FM talks about how the "big white men" ran things the way they wanted to.
PW asks if FM was playing at this time. FM says he quit playing and "went to the church."
PW asks when FM resumed playing. PW asks about when Lomax (Alan) found FM in [Como] in 1959. FM replies. He talks about being recorded by Lomax.
PW asks what FM thought when he heard himself on the Lomax recordings. FM responds that it was wonderful.

PW asks if FM was still playing at parties in 1959. FM says that he had given up playing at parties. He'd just play "now and then." At the time of this recording (1968), he still picks up the guitar and plays once in a while, for himself. FM talks about the songs he likes to play.
FM says that, at home, he does not have a record player but does have a television. He talks about the television as part of the break-up with his wife. He talks about why the marriage failed.
FM says he started a new life after his wife left him.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:35:54, 00:10:25, 00:36:00, 00:32:35) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, quarter track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks if Raymond [Paine] played around there too. He also asks about [Sandy McKenna]. Fred McDowell (FM) responds. He talks about cutting records.

PW asks FM about when he was 14 or 15 years old, borrowed a guitar, learned from [Sandy McKenna] and was teaching himself to play guitar. FM responds that it did not take him long to learn to play. He talks about this and demonstrates by playing guitar.
FM plays and sings a bit of a song to demonstrate. PW calls the tune "Papa's Little Angel Child." FM continues by demonstrating different "time" on the guitar.
PW asks how old FM was when he started singing at dances. FM says that he was young. He'd have to slip out of the house to play at night. FM talks about playing at parties and dances.
PW asks how long it was after FM started to play that FM recognized that he was pretty good. FM responds. He talks about the "friends" he met through his playing.

PW asks if FM started playing at dances, even though he did not have his own guitar. FM responds and talks about the first guitar(s) he owned. He talks about, and demonstrates, how he tests a guitar before buying it.
PW asks FM if he was going to school or working in the early days of playing guitar. FM responds that he was working "on the farm." He moved to Memphis with his uncle.

PW asks FM where he was born and where he had been living. FM responds that he was born in [unintelligible] Tennessee. He talks about his parents. They died when FM was very young. He was raised by his uncle. They moved to Memphis when FM was very young. Later they moved back to "the country." His uncle was Tom McDowell. His father was Jimmie McDowell. His mother's name was [Ida].

They talk about FM moving back to the farm and learning to play guitar. They moved several times and moved back to Memphis. Then, they moved back to the country. FM moved to Michigan to live with his sister.
PW asks if FM enjoyed playing at dances and what he liked about it. FM responds that he liked to dance and to play. FM talks about playing and singing without a microphone.

PW asks if FM generally played by himself or if other instruments were involved. FM responds. He says he was paid $3 or $4 to play at a dance. This was good money in the 1920s. They talk about Charlie Patton. FM played Patton's guitar.
They talk about FM playing in Cleveland, Michigan.
FM says he picked cotton and played guitar. An unnamed man gave FM his guitar when he bought a new guitar.

In 1928, after Thanksgiving, FM left Michigan and joined the church. He "did not play guitar for no body." After about 2 years he started playing again. They talk about why you cannot play blues if you belong to the church. They discuss this. They talk about singing "church songs," i.e., spirituals.

Fred McDowell (FM) and Pete Welding (PW) are talking about a song FM learned from Perce Jackson when he was young, before he even started playing guitar. FM plays and sings the song. The first line, and most of the lyrics, is unintelligible.

FM says that Perce was an old man when he (FM) was young. Perce played the song all the time. Perce said the story was true. FM was paying the song at a caf in Memphis where a man heard him. This, unidentified man, said that the song was about his daughter. This took place in the time that FM got his first guitar (from a white man). FM and PW continue talking about the song.

PW asks if Perce did other songs. FM responds that he did not know. He says Perce played with the guitar on his lap and used a pocket knife as a slide. FM then remembers another song Perce did. They continue talking about the story in the first song.
PW asks if "this guy named Perce was considered a pretty good musician around there." FM responds that he was pretty good. They talk about him.

Fred McDowell (FM) talks about when he was 14 or 15 years old. He mentions being recorded by Alan Lomax. The person he first learned from was Vandy McKenna; says McKenna was an old man and a really good guitar player. He played a regularly strung guitar left-handed. FM says that the first song he learned was "Big Fat Mama with the [????] On Your Bones." FM bought a guitar and taught himself to play this song.

Pete Welding (PW) asks if FM has heard music prior to this. FM replies that it was spirituals and old blues that his uncle, James Shields, played. FM talks about other people his uncle played with. He mentions a song, "Poor Boy a Long Way from Home." FM says he was born in 1904.

PW asks in FM's youth at what kind of affairs would you hear music and what kind of music were you likely to hear? FM responds that it would be dance music and blues. FM talks about the songs and music he plays.
PW and FM talk about what it takes for the blues to be genuine and honest. They talk about how FM goes about creating a new blues song. They talk about FM making the guitar another voice in the song.
PW asks where FM got the idea to have "the guitar notes talk." They talk about Vandy McKenna's guitar style. FM plays some music on his guitar. They talk about guitar tunings.
FM plays a song, [the first line is not intelligible]. He says it is the second piece he learned.
PW and FM talk about McKenna. FM says he was "the best musician around there." Ed Looney always played (bass-line on guitar) back up for McKenna.
PW asks what other pieces McKenna played. FM responds and plays a song, first line - "I've been Talking all Night Babe." FM demonstrates the guitar part.
PW and FM talk more about McKenna. They talk about some of the other men who played around this time, when FM was 14-15 years old.
FM mentions his mother and says she asked him to stop playing the blues. FM talks about having to borrow guitar to play at dances and parties.
They talk about various guitar tunings the FM uses. He demonstrates. He mentions some of the songs he plays in each tuning.
PW picks a song on the guitar. He asks FM for the name of the song. FM does not recall it.
PW asks what FM liked about McKenna's music. FM replies that he likes the word and the music. FM picks another song, [the first line is not intelligible].
Pete Welding (PW) and Fred McDowell (FM) talk about blues songs and spirituals. They talk about why one can't play or sing blues in church.
PW cannot understand why one cannot play blues in church. PW says that church going people feel blues are a sinful music. FM responds. He talks about his relationship to [his] God.
PW says that he believes FM feels good when he sings the blues. FM responds.
PW asks FM how he would explain, to someone, what the blues are. FM responds.
PW asks how FM puts a blues feeling into words. FM responds. He plays guitar and sings.
PW says that FM has a gift for music. He asks if FM hears differently from other people. FM responds. He talks about practicing.
PW asks if FM went to church when he was being raised by his uncle. FM talks about growing up with restrictions. He talks about his uncle.
FM says that he has always travelled alone. This is the main reason that he has never been in trouble or in jail.

PW brings up a musician named [Roebuck "Pops" Staples?]. PW says that church music and blues use the same notes and chords. The only difference is the words. FM agrees. He plays guitar. They discuss blues and church music.

PW talks about the old church music. He says that in the 1920s and 1930s the songs became influenced by jazz and gospel music evolved. FM agrees. PW compares a James Brown concert to a gospel music concert. FM says that he feels good playing both church music and the blues.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 01:05:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: This tape was dubbed from the 4-track original. See the note for
SR064
.

row.entry: PW and FM talks about FM started playing guitar. He says he was about 14 years old. He says that he learned to play from a left-handed guitar player named Vandy McKenna.
They talk about the place FM could play when he was starting out. They talk out the kind of music FM plays and the lyrics he sings. They talk about the blues as songs of emotion.
They discuss how FM puts a song together. FM talks about how he makes his guitar sing, or talk.
FM tunes his guitar ad plays. FM and PW talk about guitar tunings. FM sings his version of "Big Fat Mama." He says this was the first piece that he learned.
FM plays and sings another song. PW and FM discuss the person from whom FM learned this song.

They talk about another song that McKenna played. FM retunes his guitar. He picks out and sings a bit of that song. PW asks about McKenna and FM responds. They talk about some other musicians. FM mentions Alan Lomax coming through, making recordings.

FM says that, when he was starting out, he did not have his own guitar. They discuss how he still learned to tune and play the guitar. They talk about several different guitar tunings. FM demonstrates.
PW asks what attracted FM to a song and playing. FM responds and demonstrates.
PW asks if Raymond [Cane] played in the area where FM played. He asks if [Cane] played with McKenna. FM replies.
PW asks FM how quickly he learned to play guitar. FM responds and demonstrates on his guitar.

PW asks how soon after he learned to play that FM realized he had a gift. FM responds. He says that he started playing at dances, even though he had no guitar of his own. He talks about how he selects a guitar. He talks about his family and growing up.

PW asks FM if he enjoyed playing at dances. FM responds at length. He says that he had a good singing voice. He says that he made good money playing at dances (especially compared to picking cotton). FM talks about being given a new red guitar.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:52:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR064
.

row.entry: FM says that he quit playing for about two years. He joined a church and so was not permitted to play the blues. He explains. FM and PW discuss this. They talk about singing church songs.

FM and PW discuss church songs and the blues at length. FM mentions Blind Lemon. FM had to give up the blues in order to be a church member. PW says that he finds this to be a very hard concept to understand. FM picks at his guitar. PW mentions several bluesmen as examples.
They discuss the blues being sinful music. FM talks about his faith and beliefs.
FM says that he feels good when he plays the blues. He explains.
PW asks FM how he would explain the blues to someone who has not heard the blues. FM does so. He plays guitar and sings.

FM says that you get to feeling good after playing. PW asks if FM hears music differently than other people. FM says "No." PW asks if FM went to church when he was a youngster. FM answers "No" and explains.

FM says that he is a loner. He never travelled with anybody, so stayed out of trouble. FM and PW go back to talking about church music and the blues. PW talks about gospel music coming into the church. He mentions Aretha Franklin.
PW talks about James Brown and the Blind Boys of Alabama. FM says that some people just want him to play guitar and not sing.
They talk about a song FM learned from Percy Jackson. FM plays and sings, falsetto, several verses. They discuss the song.
PW asks FM when he played in Memphis. FM says that he does not remember, then says that it was after he got his first guitar. They continue discussing the Percy Jackson song.
PW ask FM if heard other songs from Percy Jackson. FM answers "yes" but he can't remember any of them. FM says the names of his parents. They talk about musicians FM heard early in his life.
The recording volume drops so low that the conversation becomes unintelligible. FM plays guitar and sings but the volume is so low that the song cannot be identified.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 01:36:00) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Interview location: Chicago, Illinois.

Logger's note: Pete Welding (PW) interviews Lester McFarland (LM). A man named Harlan (H) [the rest of his name is unknown] participates in the interview. Mr. McFarland is a blind musician. He performed as half of the duo Mac and Bob {Robert Gardner]. This SR appears to be the second part of the interview; see
SR234
for the balance of the interview.

row.entry: LM discusses several people and where they are. He talks about "going on the air" in 1925. He says the he and Bob (Robert Gardner) went to school together.

PW asks LM how he got interested in music. LM says he started playing pipe organ when he was about three and a half years old. He was a church organist when he was 9 years old. He majored in music at the Kentucky School for the Blind in Louisville. After graduating, he taught music for four years. Bob Gardner (BG) suggested that the two of them make a harmony team and do some barnstorming. They started singing in schools.

LM and BG went to Knoxville, Tennessee and did a lot work in churches. They would not perform unless they were paid. They started singing on the radio in Knoxville. They played mandolin (LM) and guitar (RG). The response was so good that they were invited back and paid.

LM says he used to yodel. He learned it "from a kid in school." A talent scout heard them and asked if heh would make some records for the Brunswick label. They got $150 for their first record, October 1926, and no royalty. That record turned out to be their biggest seller.

LM says that Brunswick was "doggone nice" to them. LM and BD headlined their Hillbilly Catalog. He says that as Mac and Bob contract with Brunswick ended, other companies made them offers. Brunswick always responded with a higher offer. They stayed with Brunswick through the years.

LM says that Mac and Bob came to radio station WOS in Chicago. He talks about their contracts and how their records lead to personal appearances. He says they had wonderful success with both radio and records. PW asks about a recording session in Atlanta, Georgia. LM says it was in about 1929. He talks about cutting records to a wax master.

PW Asks about a recording of "The Royal Telephone." LM says that it is a religious song which he learned from Mrs. Pearl Hughes. They talk about other record he made, some were solo and some were with RG.

PW asks about a Joe Turner song that LM recorded. LM Says that it is an old blues, which he played on the piano. LM talks about "Midnight on the Stormy Deep" which he learned from a school mate. He say that he learned "Are You Tired of Me Darling" from the same person.
LM discusses other musicians who were on the radio. He talks about the blues and where he got some of the songs he played and recorded. He says there is a story behind most every song he recorded.
LM is asked about "Tennessee Jail Bird." He talks about George Pennington. He also talks about a song called "Black Sheep."
PW asks about a song "The Murder of J.D. Markham." LM talks about it and explains the background of the song. The also talk about the song on the flip-side of the record.
PW asks about the traditional song LM recorded. LM responds at length. They talk about a man named Charlie Oakes, who was collected by the Library of Congress.

They talk about a man named George Reneau who recorded "The New Market Rag." LM says he made some recordings with Reneau, but not under his real name. They talk about Reneau's recordings. They talk about "Blue Ridge mountain Blues." They talk about the recording LM made with Reneau.

PW asks LM how long he has lived in Chicago. LM talks about the towns and cities where he lived and the radio stations on which he played. He mentions the Linder Twins, Connie and Bonnie. He says that he came back to Chicago in 1939 and has been there ever since.

PW asks if there was much singing in LM's family as he was growing up. LM responds. PW asks if there were musicians around when LM was growing up. LM answers. LM talks about the pump organ on which he learned to play.
LM says he learned that he had absolute pitch (a.k.a. perfect pitch). They discuss this. They talk about some musicians breathing between phrases. They talk about Ernest Tubb.
They talk about a session Roy Acuff did in about 1929.
H asks about a recording session LM did in about 1928. LM says that it was 1927. He talks about other recording sessions.

LM talks about the first time he heard a mandolin on a recording. He says he is self- taught on the mandolin. He says that as a child he played old time fiddle, which is tuned the same way as a mandolin. He says that he started playing guitar when he was 9 years old. He talks about the various instrument combinations used on his records.
H asks an unintelligible question. They talk about where H learned several songs. They talk about Pearl Hughes. LM talks about composing for a recording contract.
LM asks if PW and H saved any of his old recording session. They talk about this.
LM talks about his relationship with Brunswick Records. PW asks about a specific Recording Director. LM answers.
PW asks if LM had any difficulty acclimating himself to the recording situation. LM answers at length. He says that in order to relax between recordings he'd play the piano.
PW asks about LM's musical training when he was a student. LM responds that he was considered the best musician in the school, but his deportment was the worst.
LM talks about the instruments he plays.

LM is asked what music he plays for his own relaxation. He answers and mentions that he likes Lawrence Welk's arrangements. He says he likes classical music. For himself, he plays almost anything on a piano. He talks about a music teacher.
LM talks about the songs that he likes to perform. He does a recitation from the song "Old Shep." He talks about Red Foley.
PW asks about LM's song composition. LM responds and gives some examples.
H asks Robbie Luther and other musicians LM may have worked with.

H asks bout a harmonica player who accompanied LM on a recording. LM answers. He talks about accompanying other musicians where he had to do as little as possible so as not to be recognized on the record.
H asks about LM's version of "On Top of old Smokey." LM and H talk about various version of that song. They talks about "Sadie Ray."
PW asks LM where he got "The Birmingham Jail." LM responds. They talk about "21 Years." They talk about Johnnie Oakes.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate; Side 1: 00:32:50; Side 2: 00:32:50) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: Esmond Edwards (EE) asks where and when Memphis was born. He responds Memphis in September 3, 1915, when asked when he started playing he jokes September 4, 1915. Then says he must've been 7 or 8.
EE asks if he ever took lessons, or learned on his own. He responds.
EE asks when he left Memphis, and if he worked with bands. He responds 1931, and jokes that he "never worked with bands, bands worked with him."
EE asks when he started working professionally. Memphis said he started around 1935.
EE asks who influenced Memphis and his piano style. He mentions his father, Roosevelt Sykes.
EE asks if he plays any other instruments. Memphis modestly mentions guitar and bass.
EE asks what musicians he ran into when "hoboing around." He responds.
EE asks Mrs. McDowell "where are you from?" She responds and talks about her life. She says that she sings only church songs. She talks about a group with which she sings.

EE asks how Memphis came to write his piece "Every Day," if he was the first person to record it, and what label he recorded it with. He responds and mentions a tune named "Angel Child" was the track on the flip-side of "Every Day."
EE asks what the common instrument group is Memphis likes to write for and play with. He responds.
EE asks how Memphis came to arrange his Folkways date. He responds, and mentions Alan Lomax.
EE asks what he does throughout the year musically, if he's touring frequently, etc. Memphis responds, mentions tour-mates, and places he's been recently.
EE asks if Memphis thinks blues singers are going to get more popular recently because of a boost in popularity of folk songs. Memphis responds.
EE asks Memphis to tell him about his family. He talks about his wife and children, as well as how his youngest daughter is already writing music.
EE asks how Memphis writes his songs or gets his ideas out. He responds.
EE asks how many songs he has written. He responds.
EE asks if Memphis is a member of ASCAP or BMI. He responds BMI.
EE asks if he has and plans for the future. Memphis mentions going overseas, possibly Europe, and talks about getting many offers to play internationally after playing Carnegie Hall.
EE asks what artists do in Chicago do, if there are enough clubs for people to play or if they just live there. Memphis responds, talking about the new acts he competes with there.

EE asks why Memphis thinks many musicians gravitate to Chicago. He responds, and talks about a guitar player he used to play with that started his own band but didn't really get anywhere because "he's not a leader." Memphis talks about finding musicians who get angry that the composer doesn't know how to read and write down music that went to Harvard, etc. He also talks about one of his bands always splitting money evenly and being fair towards each other.

EE mentions he thinks Memphis's audience is about to be a lot more vast, and that the best days of his musical field are ahead, and that when he started becoming known to a lot of new people because he started publishing songs through folk labels.
EE asks how far Memphis went with his education. He responds (high school), and brings up learning a lot hoboing around at a young age playing music.
EE asks if there was any segregation amongst hobos after Memphis brings it up. He responds that there wasn't any.
EE asks how long Memphis hoboed for. Memphis responds "quite some time," and talks more about it and some amusing incidents that happened while doing so.
EE mentions hoboing to places where he had heard of great piano players and he would challenge them to battles. They mention most people he played with and challenged were self-taught like Memphis.

Memphis talks about trying school and thinking it spoiled his music, so it just played and learned himself. EE and Memphis mention music seeming wrong academically, but when it sounds good it doesn't matter.
Memphis mentions he wants to make his next album on organ, playing it similarly to piano without having a background practicing on organ.

EE and Memphis talk about California being a great town for the blues scene, shortly after they mention New York not being a good town for blues singers. Memphis mentions if someone had a blues club there it would do well.
EE and Memphis talk about people not wanting to give blues a chance in New York, and the younger generation trying to push away their roots.

The two continue talking about how they think blues and jazz are very similar, mentioning Count Basie, the term soul being thrown around in between genres, modern musicians being ashamed to show they really like blues, Cannonball Adderley, blues making a comeback during a jazz era and more.
EE asks what Memphis thinks of modern jazz, Sonny Rollins, Coltrane, etc. They talk about their opinions on Jazz, Blues, Folk music, and Rock N' Roll.
EE says "Maybe there is more sincerity in the blues, rock n' roll is manufactured" etc.
EE asks the last name of a previous band member Memphis had in the 50s. He responds.

EE asks Memphis to tell him a little about his fellow musician Willy (Willie?), and if he is self-taught. He responds and talks about their band and that once they started making money the split because they began to argue.
EE and Memphis two talk for a bit about booking managers and etc. being the reasons bands fall apart.
They both talk about musicians reading reviews and finding out people really liked them on albums and etc., they go off as a solo act and don't make out as well, and that being a common issue.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:47:50) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: The tape box says August 25, and the tape log says August 29.

row.entry: PW asks some "simple questions." MW says that he was born in Rollin' Fork, Mississippi on April 4, 1915. MW talks about his family. He says that his father was a guitar player. However, he learned to play guitar from Scott Bomana. MW talks about his early family life and his early musical life. He says that he was "diggin'" the records of Robert Johnson and Son House, who he also saw in person.
MW says that he started playing harp [harmonica] when he was about 13 years old. He talks about his father. MW says he could easily see and hear other musicians.

PW asks about what MW could listen to on the radio. H replies that he listened to blue on phonograph records. He talks about listening to Robert Johnson records. He says he heard Son House live. They talk about the "Mississippi Delta sound."

PW asks when MW first got a guitar. MW says that he was about 17 years old. He expands on this. They talk about guitar tunings. They talk about the Library of Congress recordings made by Alan Lomax in 1942.
PW asks about the community in which MW grew up. MW responds. He says he did not get much schooling. He says that the best blues singers came from the church. He mentions St. Louis and Chicago.

PW asks about the circumstances around Alan Lomax's recordings made in 1942. MW responds at length. He says that Lomax recorded more of his songs then was released on the LC records. PW and MW discuss MW releasing a record of the remaining songs.
PW asks what prompted MW to move to Chicago in 1943. MW answers at length. He also talks about his experience in St. Louis. They talk about pre-was blues (old style) and post war blues.
PW asks MW if he was working on material of his own. MW responds. They talk about MW's early recordings.
MW came to Chicago in 1943. PW asks how he "found the scene" there. MW responds at length. They talk about records from that period. They talk about the musicians playing in the city at that time.
PW and MW talk about the places MW played and the musicians playing at that time.

PW asks when MW made the change to amplified guitar. MW says that he did this when he came to Chicago. They talk about this at length. They talk about a bass player. They talk about MW's recoding from this time.
PW and MW talk about making the "post-war blues sound." They talk about "the beat" and electric instruments. They talk about a MW song that is "perfect in its own way."
MW talks about touring in "the early years." They talk about changes in the music business over the years. They talk about popular music and the blues coming together.

They discuss young [black] people running away from classic blues. MW says that real blues is what he made on his fist records. They talk about MW's tours to England. He mentions The Rolling Stones. They talk about world-wide interest in the blues.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 00:42:30; Side 2: 00:24:20) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, monos ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: The audio on this tape seems to have survived by accident. It appears the tape was recorded in the half track format, but blanked over by being recorded without audio in the quarter track format. As a result, the original audio is 'between the tracks,' resulting in very low-level, very hissy audio. Also, the audio on the tape is split between tracks, with the first half of the tape recorded at 3 3/4 ips on track one, and the second half recorded at 7 1/2 ips on track two.

row.entry: PW and CM talk about CM's years as a child in Mississippi.
CM says he was raised in Memphis. He says he was interested in hill-billy music, blues and spirituals. Radio was his major source of the music he heard. He says he really liked Stephen Foster songs.
CW talks about the music he heard on both "white" radio stations and "Negro" radio stations.
PW asks CM about the first blues he heard. A B.B. King recording was (one of) the first blues songs he remember hearing.
[The audio returns, barely.] CM says his that his father gave him his guitar. His father played hill-billy music. He talks about his father's band. CM says that there was no segregation in music.
CM talks about when he first started playing guitar and harmonica. He'd go to the library and read about Memphis musicians. He talks about some of the songs he learned.

CM talks about some of the musicians who lived in his neighborhood (in Memphis). One if these people was Johnny [?]. A Negro musician he had contact with was [?] Chambers. Through Mr. Chambers he met a number of other musicians.
CM talks about buying used phonograph records.
CM talks about meeting and hanging out with Will shade. He talks about listening to music in clubs in West Memphis
CM says he moved to Chicago the back to Memphis. He talks about his (non-musician) jobs.
CM talks about going to blues clubs in Chicago. He went to see and hear musicians like Muddy Waters and Howlin' Wolf.
PW asks CM when he really applied himself to music. CM responds. He also talks about drinking and being very sick.
PW asks CM when he decided he could earn his living as a musician. CM responds. He talks about some of the musicians he met and/or played with.
CM talks about some of the clubs in which he played. He mentions some of the musicians with whom he played and/or had influence on him.
CM talks about a band he was in (with Mike). He left because Mike was holding him back. He formed a band with Ray and Johnny.
PW asked CM where he got his "stuff." CM answers. He talks about improving his technique.
PW asks what happened after CM stopped working with Johnny. CM responds. He talks about going to California. He talks about making a record for Sam charters.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester; 00:35:30) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: This SR is an interview with blues and boogie woogie piano player Iromeio "Romeo" Nelson (RN). The interview is conducted by Pete Welding (PW) and another man, whom PW identifies as "Mr. Halpner" or "Mr. Halpern" (H). Recorded in Chicago, Illinois.

row.entry: [Begins mid conversation.] PW asks RN about his early life.

H asks RN about when his interest in the piano began, and which players he remembered. A player named Wendell or Window is mentioned, referencing walking bass piano. Lonnie Johnson and Clarence William are also mentioned.
PW asks RN more background questions. RN mentions an uncle, Jim Nelson, who played music.
RN: "East St. Louis, that's where my music started."
H asks about the players RN knew in St. Louis.
H asks about the house parties/rent parties that RN used to play.
RN brings up a piano player named K.D. Red [?]. He then goes on to talk about learning to play piano in a saloon. This prompts PW to ask how long it took RN to learn how to play.
PW asks about RN's first chance to make a record. RN mentions being signed by Mayo Williams.
RN talks about recording "Dying Mercy" with Tampa Red, and then goes on to discuss his relationship with Red.
PW asks about Pinetop [Pinetop Perkins, most likely].
PW asks RN where he got inspiration for his own songs.
They discuss how RN supported himself during the depression after making two records in the late 1920s.
PW asks RN about why he gave up playing music.
PW asks RN about what kinds of songs he would play at house parties.
PW asks about other musicians who played house rent parties, Blind Blake and Lemon Jefferson are mentioned in the following discussion.
H asks how much playing house parties payed.
PW asks RN about Pinetop's playing style.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:30:06) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Copy (as per the tape box).

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Johnny Otis (JO) how he first got interested in black music. JO responds.

JO talks about Otis "Count" Matthews, a piano player, putting together a band of teenagers, the West Oakland House Rockers. JO was the drummer. He was about 17 years old at the time. He talks about Robert Johnson ant the big bands.
JO talks about a group of white kids, he knew from high school, who also formed a band. The leader was Willard Marsh. JO talks about and adult band lead by "Uncle" Ben Watkins.
PW asks how young musicians got the necessary experience to progress. JO responds. He toured with several bands in the mid-west.

JO and Preston Loved formed the Otis-Love Band. JO spoke with Nat "King" Cole. He moved to Los Angeles to play in a night club house band. After a while he formed his own band, which became the house band.
In 1941 JO went to Omaha and stayed there until 1943. He describes the band he played with. From there he went to Los Angeles. He describes the band he led in Los Angeles.
JO describes where and how he got his musical charts. PW asks about jam sessions. JO responds.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:35:11) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Copy (as per the tape box).

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Johnny Otis (JO) about the attitude of swig musicians towards the blues. JO responds. They talk about the differences between the blues and Rhythm and Blues (R & B).
JO talks about race music and black music. He talks about the difficulty getting recorded.

They talk about the genre which came to be called Blues and Rhythm. JO talks about T-Bone Walker and other musicians from Texas and Oklahoma. They talk about small, west coast record labels. They talk about music clubs in the late 1940s. Thursday night was talent show night.
In 1948 JO put together an R & B package and went on the road in California. In 1949 he went on the road nationally. He was recording. They talk about the role of radio and black music.
They talk about JO's national tours. The first one was in 1946. Jo talks about playing in tobacco warehouses.
PW asks about the effects of rock and roll and R & B on Black and White audiences. JO responds.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:21:34) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: Copy (as per the tape box). Notes enclosed in the tape box indicate a tape dubbed from various commercial recordings, but may include three selections that are improvisations. These notes may belong with another recording.

row.entry: Johnny Otis (JO) talks about recording for a white audience and a black audience.
Pete Welding (PW) asks JO what he sees as the difference between the music scene now and when he got started. Jo responds. He talks about current recording artists whose music he likes.
JO talks about commercials recording companies like Motown.
JO says that the only new musical art form for the last 300 years has been American black man's music. JO says that racism is deeply woven into the fabric of American life.
JO talks about contemporary white performers who play the blues. PW joins in with his opinions.

did.unittitle:
Johnny Otis Show - "Live from the Ash Grove," #1,
July 12, 1972
did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:30:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: "These tapes contain an 'off the mixing board,' full-stereo recording of a live KPPC broadcast from the legendary Ash Grove club in Los Angeles of a Johnny Otis R & B Revue that should be noted and listened to. The sound quality is incredibly good, as are the performances. There is no date for the show I could find, but circumstantial evidence place this recording close to KPPC's end as an "underground" rock, jazz, and pop station in 1971. On a side technical note, Johnny keeps mentioning the broadcast is being made in Quadraphonic (four-channel) sound, and while it was technically possible and was being experimented with at the time by numerous FM stations, the sound doesn't betray any evidence of SQ encoding so it's doubtful this particular remote broadcast was truly mixed and broadcast in the format."

She is asked how many new artists she has taken on in the last year. She responds.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Side 1: 00:48:29; Side 2: 00:48:29) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW asks "what is wrong with contemporary jazz right now?" PR responds. He mentions the influence of rock and soul music. He says that it is very expensive to produce a jazz record. He talks about rock and jazz at length.

PW says that "jazz has been forced to participate in the arena of commercial music." PR agrees and expands on this. He says that an artist cannot differentiate between his music being rejected and himself being rejected.
PW brings up big bands of the '40s. He says that some were quite commercial and some played real jazz. PR responds with examples from classical music, like Hayden and Bach.
PW talks about jazz, in the 1950s, paving the way for other musicians. PR replies.
PW says that the average person is not committed to music, so he will accept whatever is popular. PR responds. He says "America is not committed to good music."

PR talks about John Cage and music as sound. He talks about "new music," which does not rely on traditional areas of melody and rhythm. He says that the media is against this concept. He says that music reflects the mood of the country. He says that there are a very few people who are controlling everything.
PW asks what PR defines as the artist's predicament. PR responds at length, mostly from a personal perspective.
PW says that the dilemma of the artist is the product of a huge complex of factors. He expands on this. PR responds.
PR talks about the artist being channeled by a producer. PW and PR discuss what it takes to produce a hit record.

(continued from Side 1) PW and PR continue to discuss record producing. PR says that the person who knows most about the product you can put out is an expert in his own field. PW has a different view. They discuss this. PR says that the cost of producing a record is not a concern to the jazz artist. They discuss promotional advertising.

PW says that he believes "given enough promotion and publicity anything can be sold." PW agrees. They discuss this. They get into politics. PR talks about unemployment among people in the entertainment industry. PR talks about drugs.
PR says that this country has become plasticized. PW asks why people are not flocking to "non-plastic" things. PR replies.

PW says that his recollection of the late 1930s and 1940s are of times of innocence. Things are very different now. The discuss this. They talk about the values that existed then. PW says that television is the great destroyer of family life. PW talks about why he collects folk music.
PW asks if "art music" can be "popular music." PR responds. PR talks about pop-culture of the aristocrats.
PR says that his basic feeling on music is that when he listens to the music he gets and emotional impact to it. He explains.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Side 1: 00:48:29; Side 2: 00:35:20) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW and PR discuss "free music" as distinguished from other jazz traditions. PR talks about this at length. PR says that he feels like he is lecturing. He talks about or mentions John Coltrane, Ornette Coleman, Cecil Taylor, and Coleman Hawkins, among others.
PW asks which recording of "free music" does PR feel holds up over time. PR responds. He mentions John Coltrane, some Miles Davis and some Ornette Coleman records, among others.
PR feels that his esthetic is moving away from jazz to a broader aspect. He explains. He talks about some of the people who typify jazz to him.
PW talks about groups (i.e., bands) that have been together for a long time. PR responds. He talks about jazz and other forms of music.
PR talks about putting jazz feeling into the blues. PW talks about country bluesmen who have done this, PR talks about maximum technique and maximum emotionalism.
PR says that he is listening to a lot of ethnic music. He elaborates. He says he is interested in music as a means of communication. He is not interested in intellectual music.
PR says that the music that is knocking him out now is Korean music. He is also into Tibetan music. He explains. He talks about ascension.
PR talks about great composers listening to ethnic music. He talks about how this relates to the religious and spiritual needs of the people.
PR talks about why he no longer plays jazz. He talks about writing music. He talks about where jazz is going.
PW and PR talk about the advent of electronic music.
PW and PR discuss, at length, electronic music and acoustic music.
PR talks about the electronic piano and the piano. He talks about the synthesizer. PR says that he thinks that anything one can get electronically one could get acoustically.
PR says that, as a composer, he is interested in how to utilize a synthesizer.
PW asks about jazz being uninteresting today. PR responds.

PR says that the idolatry that used to be in jazz no longer exists, e.g., there is no longer a Coltrane or Miles Davis. He expands on this idea. PR talks about Miles Davis's recent music and recordings.
PW asks if he sidetracked PR. PR says no. He goes back to talking about artistic impetus. They talk about the economics of recording jazz music.
PR talks about young musicians coming up without the basic training to really play the music. PW talks about the blues guitarist Mike Bloomfield as an example of this.
PR talks about musicians banding together in organizations and groups like the Jazz Composers Gild and the Black Composers Association. He say the music is being pushed into mediocrity.

The final instrumental piece by PR

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 00:30:55, Side 2: 00:31:12) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Pete Robinson interview, conducted by Pete Welding. Continued on
SR157
.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) ask Pete Robinson (PR) a few questions like where and when he was born. PR answers.
PW and PR discuss audio recording machines
PW ask PR "Why did your family move to Vancouver?"
PR explains the first time he began music lessons
PR discusses how he gave a recital only six months after he began piano lessons. He tells PW how little he knew about music prior to his music lessons.
PR explains how he enjoyed listening and improvising Rock n' Roll when he was younger. He studied Classical literature in his piano lessons and was not interested in the technical aspects of music.
PW ask PR what characteristics he enjoys in R & B and Jazz music.
PR tells a story about his mother suggesting he begin learning jazz
PR explains how he worked in collaboration with John Chambers, a prominent jazz drummer, and was introduced to playing "new" jazz music
PW asks, "Were you working with other musicians through John?"
PR explains how John exposed him to another lifestyle and environment different than his personal upbringing
PW ask if PR's experience in Los Angeles was any different than his experience with musicians in San Francisco
PR talks about the challenges of playing creative music and the struggle Brian dealt with moving from Chicago to Los Angeles

PW asks, "What did you do those first couple of years?" after PR explained it was hard to meet other high school musicians in the Los Angeles area. PW also asks "What kind of music had you been exploring on your own?"
Pete Welding (PW) asks Pete Robinson (PR) how he heard about joining Don's jazz band
PW ask how many gigs PR had the opportunity to play at in Don's band
PR discusses the experience he had working with Don
PR explains the musical growth, character growth and network connections he made in Don's band
PW asks, "Was it during this period with Don that you found your own musical assumption taking shape?"
PW asks PR was he listening to any Rock music during that period and if there are any benefits of playing rock
PW asks PR when he felt the conception of his musical ideas and values solidify in his younger years
PW asks, "What was the occasion of you leaving [Ellis? - Don's band]"
PR explains what he did after leaving Don's band and how he first meet the musician Gill
PR discusses how he started working in [Shelly's] band and compares his experience there to Don's band
PW asks PR if he was approached by a major record label to record music as a solo artist

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 00:31:40, Side 2: 00:15:30) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Pete Robinson interview, conducted by Pete Welding. Continued from
SR156
.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) starts by asking Pete Robinson (PR) what he did after leaving [Shelly's] band

PR explains how he and Shelly's band prepared for the record label rehearsal. He talks about how the audio producer said the band's music would not sell because it was an all-White band playing traditional Black jazz music.
PR says music companies and bands were not interested in allowing him to play the music he wanted
PW discusses mass distribution and how companies must chose music with a broader mass appeal that does not allow for flexible kinds of musical arrangements
PR explains how he was able to play his own music with Gill, but his musical ideas did not always align with Gill's ideas
PR said when he first started playing in Gill's band, they did not use tunes but played free without a bass player
PW asks, "Are any of the other guys contributing tunes more than they did before?"
PW asks, "What do you find is the greatest problem in the band concerning music?"
PW asks PR, "How would you typically describe the music that the band plays?" and "How would you explain this to a young person..."
PW asks again, "What would you tell the young person to listen for beyond emotionality... What is behind the music and what causes it to work?"
PR explains he cannot answer PW's question. PR discusses the four elements and form of music.
PR explains when the band is creating spontaneous forms as tightly as possible, the emotional aspect for the listener can arise
PW asked PR how the music that his rock band plays, Contraband, relates to previous Jazz development. PR does not answer the question on this part of the series

Pete Robinson (PR) answers Pete Welding's (PW) question about how the music from the band Contraband relate to previous jazz development. They discuss the traditional form and musical development of jazz.
PR explains the "free bearers" concept that his band tries to follow. Free bearers break away from traditional boundaries of music, but still combine elements of traditional form occasionally.
PR and PW discuss the difference between music innovators and synthesizers.

PW asks, "Is there anything in the playing of Contraband that you feel represents a way to solving that dilemma?" (The dilemma referenced is the feeling of no uniformity or continuity in music that causes listeners to deem a piece of music or band unsuccessful.)
PR explains that the individual strengths of the band act as the catalyst to carry a piece of music through to the end and create a successful or emotional piece of music.
PR references how difficult it is for the band to play with new musicians and create a great sound if the band is not used to playing with new members.

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: The tape was reused at least once going by documentation written on the box. Box is marked as a session tape for Pete Robinson and Charles Orena from 1972; and an undated session with sax player Warne Marsh. Audio appears to be Warne Marsh. No documentation on the Warne Marsh recordings exists on the box, unlike the other previous contents. There is no evidence this was ever mixed and released. After main body of recording, there is a minute or so section of incompletely erased audio from the Pete Robinson session which is included for completeness sake.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: The sound tape reel received at AFC was received on a 7-inch reel, and during digitization was wound onto a 10-inch reel. The venue was located in Balboa Beach, California. The recording date is noted as September 2, but it may have been September 27. See
SR319
and
SR320
.
Vendor's digitization note: The program has distortion and hiss from the source tape, as well as high frequency loss. There is a high-pitched tone at the end of the program.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:48:00) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: This is the first part of an interview Pete Welding (PW) conducted with Dr. Ross (DR), a.k.a, Doctor Ross the Harmonica Boss [born Charles Isaiah Ross]. It was recorded in Flint, Michigan.

row.entry: PW asks DR to tell him about his life. DR says that he started playing harmonica when he was 9 years old. He was born in Tunica, Mississippi in 1925. He talks about his father, a farmer, his mother, his siblings, and an uncle who played harmonica.

PW ask s DR how he learned to play harmonica. DR responds. PW asks if there was much music in Tunica when DR was growing up. DR responds. He heard Walter Davis, Pine top (Perkins?), Pete Johnson, Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup and a number of Delta blues players.
PW asks DR what sort of occasions he played for. DR responds. He mentions Ike Turner. He talks about a man who played guitar, saxophone and drums at the same time.
PW asks if DR had heard Robert Johnson. DR says "only is records." He talks about Sleep John Estes, Blind Lemon, Bessie Smith, and Memphis Minnie. He talks about Sonny Boy Williamson.
PW asks DR when he started playing. DR responds that he started off playing church songs. He also played songs that he heard on the radio.

PW asks when DR picked up guitar. DR replies that it was when he was drafted into the army. He elaborates. DR says that he is left-handed so he plays harmonica and guitar backwards, i.e., left-handed.
PW asks where DR did his basic training. DR answers. He says that he volunteered to be a paratrooper. He talks about playing harmonic while in service.
DR talks about the outfit in which he served. He talks about how he got the name "Doctor." He talks about his schooling.
PW asks what drew DR to the blues. DR responds. He talks about playing in church with his brothers and a sister.

PW asks how long DR played church songs before he changed to the blues. DR responds and talks about what drew him to the blues. DR talks about where he thinks the blues came from. He talks about boogie woogie.
PW asks if DR went back to Tunica when he got out of the army. DR responds at length. He tells where Doctor" came from. He talks about two girls (women) who wanted him to go to California.
DR talks about people he played with after he got home. He played on a radio program.
DR. talks about playing in Greenwood and Greenville, Mississippi. He met Ike Turner. HE talks about some other musicians he met. He talks about other radio stations on which he played.
DR talks about making his first record, in 1949, for Sam Phillips on Sun Records.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:47:40) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR050
.

row.entry: PW and DR talk about DR's recordings for Chess and Sun. One of the musicians was "dragging the broom," another was playing the washboard. DR mentions a number of the musicians with whom he recorded.

DR talks about his band drinking and getting drunk to the point it effected their playing. He started playing with a drummer called Roosevelt Parker, He talks at length about Howlin' Wolf. He mentions a saxophone and trumpet played named David Hair (?). His nickname was Be Bop St. Louis Dave. Little Sam Jackson, Arthur "Big Boy" Crudup and Muddy Waters are also mentioned.

PW asks DR if he play all three of his instruments on the Sun and Chess recordings. DR responds. Lightning Hopkins sent for DR to play harmonica on his records. DR talks about typing letters to his girlfriends.

PW asks DR about getting out of the army and moving north. DR talks at length about a number of his girlfriends. He says he got married in 1949 even though he was engaged to another woman. He was in the army reserve for six years and spent part of the time on active duty. He was sent to the Philippines.
DR re-enlisted in the army wanting to go to Europe. However, he was sent back to the Philippines. He left the army at the end of this 18 month enlistment.
DR talks about making more records. He parted from his wife. He was working for General Motors.

After leaving Champion, Illinois, he made more recordings, in 1954 or so. He married Beatrice Tyler [? Spelling of both names]. DR came to Flint Michigan for a job with General Motors. He also invested, buying houses. He made more recordings, while he was working for Chevrolet. He still played music on occasion.

PW asks DR how he met Jack Brown and started recording for Fortune. DR replies. One of the songs he recorded was "industrial Boogie." Another was "3220," a blues. He wrote them while living in flint. They were recorded in 1958. He talks about preparing for his next recordings. He identifies the recordings he made in this period.
DR talks about the band he is working with now. He talks about picking cotton as a child. He and PW talk about the differences between the blues and rock-and-roll.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:14:37) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR050
.

row.entry: PW and DR talk at length about DR's techniques for playing harmonica. Sometimes he holds the harmonica in his right hand and plays guitar or drum with his left hand. He also sings.
They discuss how DR goes about writing a song.
PW asks if the events in DR's blues songs really happened. DR responds that sometimes the songs are based on experiences and sometimes are dreams.
An unidentified woman asks DR about Yank Rachell. DR responds. He also talks about dogs and birds "singing" while he plays. He says that he met Muddy Waters.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: Dubs of commercial recordings. the "Santa Fe Group" is a reference to a style of blues piano played by African American pianists living near the railroad line in the Houston, Texas area. Performers listed on the tape box: Rob Cooper, Son Becky [Leon Calhoun], "Pinetop" Burks (Conish Burks), Black Boy Shine, and Andy Boy. Channels 3 and 4 may be blank.
Vendor's digitization note: The programs are distorted at times.
