scopecontent.p: Master recording, as per the note on the tape box.
Vendor's digitization note: The tape begins with a test tone. Issues with the program include distortion and hiss, print-through, and the end cut off.
Welding interviewed Shakey Jake in Los Angeles.
LC engineer's note: The audio is on track two, suggesting this was recorded on a quarter-inch four-channel multitrack recorder.

row.entry: PW asks SJ about his new album.
PW reads through the song titles on the new album to understand which ones are SJ's own tunes.
PW asks about SJ's background, how he got interested in playing.
I was one of his fans. - SJ talking about the original Sonny Boy Williams.
PW asks SJ when he felt he was getting good on the harmonica.
SJ talks about seeing Howlin' Wolf when SJ was still a kid, and what songs Wolf was playing at the time.
SJ talks about playing with Muddy Waters in the early 1950s.
SJ and PW talk about the blues clubs in Chicago.
SJ talks about Little Walter and Walter's song "[The] Juke."
PW asks about Little Walter's harmonica techniques. This leads to a discussion about Walter's personality, and SJ's opinions about how much to pay band members.
PW asks how SJ got his start after the war [WWII]. SJ talks about the musicians union, which leads to a discussion of the first band that SJ put together.
PW asks about the toughness of the music scene in Chicago which leads back to SJ's opinion of the musicians union.
SJ talks about Smokey Smothers and other musicians he played with and goes on to talk about why blues musicians didn't make a lot of money from their recordings.
PW asks how often SJ performed when he was a working musician in Chicago.
PW asks what SJ thinks of "these white kids playing blues, like Paul [Butterfield] and Charlie [Musselwhite?]."
PW asks what other work SJ did to support himself when he was first starting out.
They're playing the blues too loud now. - SJ
PW brings up younger musicians, such as Buddy Guy, [Magic] Sam, Otis Rush, and Albert Collins. Collins is "cool, he knows his axe."
PW poses "an interesting question": does SJ think that the blues has changed much since he started performing? This leads to a discussion about B.B. King's style of playing.
PW asks SJ who his favorite blues artists are.
It wouldn't do [me?] any good to sing Muddy's song and put Duke Ellington's music behind it. - SJ's critique of Taj Mahal's style.
I'll tell you about Magic Sam now.
PW asks how SJ goes about writing a song.
PW asks about Little Walter's influence on SJ's harmonica playing. This leads to a discussion of SJ's opinions of other harmonica players.
PW and SJ talk about what songs SJ thinks should be on the 45 single [for his new album possibly, the context is unclear].
SJ talks about musicians moving from Chicago to California which leads to a discussion of Chess records' business practices.
End (tape is turned off as SJ is about to play a recording for PW)

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:32:56) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: LS says that he was born in 1902 in Poplar Ridge, Alabama. He talks about his family. They were all musically inclined. He made his living as a musician until he became a Christian.

LS says that he first learned to play guitar in Alabama. He moved to Memphis and learned from (an unnamed) musician there. He talks about the music that his father and brothers played, and where the played it. He talks about his father's farm.

LS says that he left the family farm when he was about 19 years old. He talks about learning to really play guitar. In Memphis, he learned from Tim Watkins. He learned to play blues, mostly songs he made up.
PW asks what the first piece was that LS learned to play on the guitar. LS responds. He talks about playing with a bottleneck or a knife. He really did not "know music" until he went to Memphis.

PW asks if LS played mostly instrumental music at the dances in Alabama. LS says he played and sang. He talks about some of the songs. He talks about his father's violin playing. He talks about his brothers. He talks about some other musicians he met in Alabama.

LS talks about leaving Alabama and coming to Memphis in 1928. He talks about playing with Tim Wilkins. He says that Tim Wilkins taught him how to really play guitar. He talks about where they played. One place they played was for a "medicine show."
PW says that, several years ago, he did an interview with Tim Wilkins. PW and LS talk about this.
PW asks who else Wilkins was working with at this time. LS responds. They talk about Sleepy John Estes and some others they played with.
PW asks if Little Son Joe ever worked with LS and Wilkins. LS responds. LS mentions Memphis Minnie. PW asks if LS knew Joe McCoy. LS says that he knew Joe and his brother Charlie.

PW asks if LS was writing songs of his own. LS responds. He talks about a man looking to make records. The man told LS that his voice was too good for the blues; he should be singing church music. LS did not make any recordings back then. He talks about a hymn he liked to sing and did record.
PW asks if LS went to church on Sunday when he was a young man. LS responds. They talk about short and long meter hymns. They talk about "Amazing Grace" as sung by black people and by white people.
They continue talking about long and short meter hymns. LS talks about hymns he'd like to record. He talks about making a record and selling copies.
PW asks how long LS and Wilkins worked together. LS responds. He talks about Sleepy John Estes and some other musicians.
PW asks LS if he ever heard of Sonny Boy Williamson, a harp player. LS responds. They talk about other musicians LS played with.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:24:42) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW and LS discuss what was going on musically in Memphis "in those days." LS mentions Ukulele Kid and several others. They talk about the kinds of places, in Memphis, where a musician could play.
PW asks about medicine shows coming out of Memphis. LS said he'd go with Dr. Hall. He explains and talks about how they set up and did medicine show.
PW asks how LS liked "that life," that is working medicine shows. LS replies.
PW asks LS what he thinks about the blues. LS answers.
PW asks "why is it impossible to reconcile the blues and spiritual songs?" LS responds. He says that any song that is not a church song is a devil's song. They discuss this at length.
PW asks what caused LS to give up the blues life. LS answers at length. He was baptized in 1936.
PW asks what LS did to support himself after he stopped playing blues. LS answers. HE says that he stayed in Memphis from 1928 to 1944. He went to Chicago and held several jobs.
LS says the when he came to Chicago he joined a church and became deacon. He sang in the church. He cut a record of church music in 1958.
LS says he is still singing in his church. They discuss church songs and music. LS talks about making a record in a church.
PW asks how church music has changed over the years. LS answers at length. He talks about Aretha Franklin and Sam Cook.
PW asks if the church is turning away from the old kind of singing. LS answers.
PW asks if there is a difference between gospel music and the old style of hymn singing. LS answers. He says that he sings in churches in addition to his own church.
PW asks what job LS is supporting himself with now. LS answers.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:32:21) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Pete Welding interviews Johnny Shines. Continued on
SR238
. While the tape box indicates the tape was recorded on both sides, only one side has content.

row.entry: Shines speaks about the musical influence of Howlin' Wolf
Playing in Memphis, after he moved there
Other musicians he heard play, and the type of music they played
Parties held by Will Wellers; gambling, drinking, women
His stay in Arkansas and the reason he moved to Memphis
His first guitar, leaving his job as choir director, and meeting other musicians
How long it took before he was proficient as a musician, shape note singing; other details about the choir
Meeting other musicians and learning from them
Willie Tango: his skill and background; the type of music he played, finger picks, tunings
Willie B: instruments he played, his skill
How Shines met other guitar players
Eddie Van's skill as a musician
Jug bands in the Memphis area; showmanship in jug bands; the quality of locations where they would play
Learning from other musicians by watching them, types of music he played
Shines names piano players who were especially good, including M & O
Playing at parties, on his own, then playing with other musicians
Shines wanted to play for the people, rather than for the money
Types of songs he played at parties
Playing slide guitar; M & O told him about Robert Johnson, and took Shines to meet him, when Johnson was playing in Helena; he was impressed by Johnson, especially his slide guitar work
Shines was born in Frayser, Tennessee, in April 26, 1915; his family, extended family, and early life
A phone rings, and shortly after the recorder is turned off

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate, Side 1: 00:33:05, Side 2: 00:33:05) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Pete Welding interviews Johnny Shines. Continued from
SR237
. While the tape box has the same date as SR237, Welding begins the interview by trying to recall where they left off "last evening," so it is possible this recording was made on March 5.

row.entry: Robert Johnson got job for Shines across the street from where he was working (continued from the end of SR237
Shines describes what a juke joint is like, where the musicians played (sitting on cane-bottomed chairs)
M & O took Shines to meet Johnson around 1934 or 1935, in the summer
Shines describes the town of Helena, and segregation, the Black population, music and musicians, getting a job as a musician

Working at the same place as M & O; spending two or three weeks where Robert Johnson was (but not spending time with him specifically); Johnson's behavior and characteristics, his ability as a musician, his background, other musicians that Johnson liked, the type of music Johnson would perform, the type of guitar he had, his singing
how songs became popular; the rarity of hearing blues on the radio, the role of vendors [jukeboxes?], and the selection of records on them; types of dances, types of songs played for a waltz
the times he met and met up with Robert Johnson
Shines describes his musical career after meeting Johnson for the first time, coming an in-demand performer and what that meant
types of establishments where he played
seasonal nature of work as a musician (better in harvest season), going back to Memphis when the work fell off
when he started writing his own songs; examples of some of the early songs he wrote; his style of playing
what happened when he met up with Robert Johnson again; Robert Johnson and Buddy Guy's physical appearance being similar
traveling with Robert Johnson; how they traveled; places they played in New York; playing in Buffalo, New York, and in New Jersey (recording cuts off)
Where Shines played, the type of audiences for which he played, musicians with whom he played
The time Shines played in St. Louis, and Robert Johnson
When Shines heard Johnson had died, and the cause of his death
Playing music and also keeping a daytime job
When he moved to Chicago, the places he lived before that time, and the jobs he had; continuing to play music; the musicians with whom he worked
Working with guitar players and piano players; he names several and talks about them; not recalling all the musicians with whom he played
Getting involved in the Chicago music scene; he speaks about Memphis Minnie, Lester Melrose, Big Bill Broonzy, Big Maceo, Memphis Slim, and others
He started playing at Jerry Johnson's place, with Eddie Boyd; getting an electric guitar after coming to Chicago, as well as a mic and amplifier; where he played; piano players with whom he worked
The blues scene in Chicago at that time
Whether the money was good for musicians playing in clubs at that time
The Dukes of Swing (band); what they played; the big recording artists of the day
Making records for Columbia; who played on the sessions and details about them; where the sessions were recorded; preparations for the sessions
The unreleased sides made for Columbia
Big Bill Broonzy told him the recordings had been released in Europe; Shines had to buy him a bottle of whiskey to get the details, but later Shines found out the recordings hadn't been released

When Shines recorded for Chess--how the opportunity came about; Jimmy Rogers introduced Shines to Chess--he invited him to the Muddy Waters session; Shines went over his songs with Little Walter, Muddy Waters, Jimmy Rogers, and with L.G>on drums; the record supposedly wasn't issued but it was assigned a number and listed in the Chess catalog
Cutting records for J.O.B. (Joe Brown)--how they came to work together (the recording ends abruptly)

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: Pete Welding conducted a six-part interview with Son House in 1964.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Son House (SH) to tell him about Charlie Patton. SH replies. He mentions Willie Brown and son Patton.
SH talks about Willie Wilson and James McCoy. Willie Wilson was an early musical influence on SH.
SH talks about buying his first guitar and starting to play. SH tells the story of his early life.
SH talks about his father and his uncles being an early musical influence.
SH talks about the difference between a "songster" and a "bluesman." He talks about the blues as parable and about the "real blues."
PW and SH talk about understand the meaning behind the blues lyrics.
SH explains how he got a job working on the railroad and the work he did.
PW asks SH how his father earned his living. SH replies that he was a blacksmith, working for a white man, T.F. Keating, on his plantation.
PW asks about musical life on the plantation. SH talks about Saturday night "balls." He also talks about house parties, dances and picnics. He talks about legal whiskey and corn whiskey.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:32:00) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR015

LC engineer's note: The start of this tape is in the half track mono format and the left track contains a 26-second snatch of the start of the album
The 2000 Year Old Man
, by Carl Reiner and Mel Brooks while the right channel contains reversed audio of a fragment of an unidentifiable Bob and Ray bit, likely an aircheck of some kind. The reversed Bob and Ray audio has been made forward for the listening file.

row.entry: Son House (SH) and Pete Welding (PW) talk about a church event called "Feast in the wilderness." One of the activities is "Fish in the wilderness."
SH says he was a regular church goer, Wednesday night for choir practice and on Sunday. He talks about choir practice and the rudiments. [This may have been "shape notes."]
SH talks about the Coahoma County Union Singing Convention. PW and SH talk about "church songs" and singing in church.
PW asks if there was a school that SH attended as a youngster on the plantation. SH replies.
PW asks how old SH was when he began working in the fields. SH replies. They talk about crops and seasons on the farm.
They talk about SH's schooling, i.e., education.
They talk about SH working and making a living.
They talk about when SH started singing the blues and how he got started.
SH says that he been married 5 times. He talks about his first wife and marriage.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:49:11) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR015
.

row.entry: SH says he started preaching in 1921 and preached for years. He talks more about his marriage.
SH and his first wife leave Louisiana and move to Centerville, Michigan. SH leaves his wife and move back to Clarksdale, Michigan.
Pete Welding (PW) asks SH when he got into singing the blues. SH talks about Willie Wilson, church songs and the blues. He talks about the nature of the blues.
SH talks about preaching and the blues. He talks about Christianity and being Christian. He talks about the hypocrisy of religion.

SH says that he can't hold God in one hand and the devil in the other. He let the church go and went to playing the blues. He listened to Willie Wilson and James McCoy and learned from them. He learned natural tuning (fingers) as well as open tuning (medicine bottle).

SH says he bought his first guitar for $1.50. Willie Wilson helped get it into playing condition. SH taught himself two songs, in two weeks. They were "Hold up Sally, Take Your Big Legs Off'a Mine" and "Black Mama." He played at a dance for James Wilson. He started writing songs - "Clarksdale Moan" and "Preachin' Blues."

PW and SH talk about tuning his guitar in natural tuning and open tuning. They talk about other songs that SH wrote. They talk about Charlie Patton, his family and a woman named Bertha. SH played at Bertha's caf in Lula, Michigan.

SH says that Charlie Patton earned money playing music and was also recording 2 or 3 times a year. Charlie Patton introduced SH to A.C. Labley (sp?) a [talent scout]. SH started recording. There was also a gospel group, The Delta Big Four, recording at that time, 1930.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:47:47) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR015
.

row.entry: SH talks about the recording session in Grafton. The session was over three days. Each of the four musicians recorded separately.

PW asks about A.C. Lablay. SH describes him and how he ran the recording sessions. SH discusses the four recordings he made. He talks about some of the other musician's recordings. He talks about a song he recorded called "Mississippi County Farm," a prison farm in Tunica, Michigan.
SH talks about how he got to prison and his time there.
PW and SH talk about voter registration, segregation, and social changes in Mississippi. SH reflects on the life of a southern Negro.
PW and SH talk about "Dry Spell," a recording SH made after a dry spell (a period of no rain). They talk about another SH song called "What Am I to Do?"

(resume) SH talking about "What Am I To Do." SH says he was paid $40 for the four songs he recorded in Grafton. About a year later, he got a call back letter from Paramount to record again. He could not take the time off from work to do the session, which was in New York City.
PW and SH talk about Charlie Patton, his songs and his recording session in Grafton.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:35:13) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR015
.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) and Son House (SH) talking about Charlie Patton. He played slide guitar sitting, with the guitar on his lap and used a pocket knife as the slide. SH played slide guitar standing with a bottleneck on his finger.
PW asks where Charlie Patton learned to play; SH responds. PW asks several other questions about Charlie Patton; SH replies.

SH and Willie Wilson stayed with Charlie Patton in Holly Ridge, Michigan in 1932. They made recordings in Jackson, Michigan for H.C. Spears Phonograph Company. They three of them made one recording together, "I Had a Dream Last Night, Troubled Me." The three of them also played together for parties.
Charlie Patton made a recording with Son Sims, a fiddle player. PW and SH discuss this. They discuss several other musicians.
PW and SH talk about Willie Wilson and Charlie Patton. They talk about Charlie Patton's marriage and his daughter. SH says that Charlie Patton dies in the summer of 1932.
PW asked about Willie Brown. SH responds at length. He says they played together from about 1932 to 1942.
PW and SH talk about a SH song called "The Death Letter."

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:23:42) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
See the note for
SR015
.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Son House (SH) about Robert Johnson (RJ). SH replies at length discussing things like: how he met RJ; RJ plays the harmonica and learns to play guitar, songs, and RJ's early death.
PW asks SH about some of the other bluesmen he knew. SH talks about Blind Lemon, Frank Stokes and Jim Jackson.
PW asks SH about the records he heard growing up. SH says he had a Victrola and tells about the records he bought.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:34:17) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Logger's note: Pete Welding (PW) conducts an interview with Son House (SH). They discuss his songs and personal life experiences, including his first two marriages. This is part one of a two-part interview. The recordings ends abruptly. Continued on
SR229
.

row.entry: At 00:12, PW and SH talk about the local artists in Clarksdale
PW and SH talk about how he came to be involved with Alan Lomax and how Lomax paid him with a "nice and cool" Pepsi to record some songs.
SH explains that he's waiting on some money from the Library of Congress and some other places because they were selling his music in their stores.
Tape cuts out, and then starts again in a new conversation with SH talking about Joe Martin, also known as Fiddlin' Joe.
PW and SH discuss his song about General MacArthur ("This Song Will Last You For Years") and how he got the idea for that song.
They discuss a song that goes, "was I right or wrong?"
They discuss the song "Country Farm Blues"
They discuss SH's song, "Sun Goin' Down"
They discuss the song, "Train Time Blues" and how a relationship inspired that song
PW asks SH about his song, "My Black Woman"
PW asks SH about his songwriting process
They talk about a song called, "Brokenhearted and Downhearted." ["Downhearted Blues"?]
They talk about a song SH wrote about working on the levee and a relationship he had that influenced the song. I think the song is called, "Levee Camp Moan."
They discuss why they think there are so many blues songs about "women problems" and relationships.
PW asks SH why he thinks there haven't been very many good women blues singers. SH talks about some of the women blues singers he has performed with.
PW brings up SH's five marriages. SH briefly mentions his first wife, and then talks about what happened with his second wife.
SH talks about how he was accused of killing a guy one Saturday night. His uncle got shot in the foot and it broke his ankle. The other person was shot by another guy and killed.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:18:00): analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: A letter from Tommy Vig, dated September 2, 1962, accompanies the tape. It is possible Welding reused the tape to record the interview with Son House.

Logger's note: Interview conducted by Pete Welding with Son House on November 21st, 1964 about his third, fourth, and fifth wives, some of the music he wrote and played, and some of his experiences in Rochester. This interview is continued from
SR228
.

row.entry: At 00:08, PW asks Son House how taking his uncle to the doctor for his foot led to him getting rid of Cornelius (his ex-wife).
Interviewer asks SH about his fourth wife and SH answers
SH talks about his fifth wife - his current wife at the time of the recording - Evie [Garff McGown?].
SH how he brought Evie to Rochester
Interviewer asks SH what music means to him
They discuss the song SH wrote, "Don't Mind People Smiling in Your Face"

Son House says he's going to play a "little Christian song"
Some unintelligible talking and notes playing

did.unittitle:
"Songs of the Death of Presidents," #1,
circa 1964
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:24:48) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times.

Archivist's note: See
SR530
Logger's note: The SR consists of a special memorial program, "Songs of the Death of Presidents," hosted by Oscar Brand and produced by RKO General Broadcasting.

row.entry: Oscar Brand (OB) makes an opening remark.
OB introduces the song "The Vacant Chair."

OB introduces a ballad, titled "Booth," about President Lincoln's assassination, in the collections of the Library of Congress. The song was sung by Bascom Lamar Lunsford, South Turkey Creek, North Carolina.
OB writes the lyrics and sings his own version of the Lincoln assassination to the tune of "Wabash Cannon Ball."
OB reads excerpts of Carl Sandburg's writing about Lincoln's funeral journey.
OB introduced "The Lonesome Train" by Millard Lampell and Earl Robinson, inspired by "The Lonesome Train Cantata" Sung by Burl Ives.
OB talks about President Garfield's assassination and introduces the song "Mr. Garfield" by Bascom Lamar Lunsford.
OB introduces another version of the "Mr. Garfield" by Casey Anderson.
OB sings the song "The Story of Charles Guiteau"

OB talks about of the 3rd US president who got assassinated. President William McKinley was killed by Leon Czolgosz, an anarchist. The song "White House Blues," also known as "Buffalo, Buffalo," sung by Charlie Poole, described the event.
OB talks about the funeral train of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and introduces the musical poem "The Lonesome Train" by Norman Corwin.

did.unittitle:
"Songs of the Death of Presidents," #2,
November 27, 1964
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:19:45) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times.

Archivist's note: See
SR529

row.entry: OB presents a song "Ballad For FDR" by Tom Glazer, from a radio show.

OB talks a Broadway musical in which there are songs about President Roosevelt. He introduces a song "The Face on the Dime" which was sung by Lawrence Winters, from the musical "Call Me Mister," music and lyrics by Harold Rome.
OB introduces a song about President John F. Kennedy's assassination on Dallas on November 22, 1963.

OB talks about a song written for a special program for the British Broadcasting Corporation: "That Was the Week That Was." The song was sung by Millicent Martin. OB also talks about the song "That Was the President," sung by Phil Ochs. OS then sings the song himself.
OB talks about Jim and Fannie Brewer, blind street singers in Chicago, wrote a song "I Want To Know Why" about President Kennedy, which later published by Testament records.
OB introduces an Ireland song "We Shall Remember" by Martin Crosby.
OB made a closing remark for the radio program.

SA begins one of their songs, but then stop before the song is finished

Archivist's note: Part 1 has a few false starts. It is an edited version of a more complete recording (the edits are audible). Parts 3 and 4 have not yet been digitized.

row.entry: Roebuck "Pops" Staples (RS) talks about the history of the Staples' singers. The groups is consist of two of his daughters, Cleotha and Mavis, and his one son, Pervis. At first, Roebuck was inspired by his older sister's singing in the choir and remembered hearing the rehearsal at the house. About 12, RS started singing and neighbors would come to listen.

RS's family moved from Mississippi to Chicago. He worked in steel mills and meatpacking plants, until age 41, while providing for his family of four children. Then he worked in a construction company until age 45. That was about the time he started his singing group.
RS talks about when Mavis was 7; she was rough in carrying a tune. He waited 3 more years to teach her. She sounded good and in tune.
RS sings and demonstrates the first song their family sang. The family got invited to sing at a church. They started singing publicly around 1951.
The family signed their first professional contract in 1952 for the United label. They continued to sing at different churches.
RS tells the story of Mavis's appendicitis and surgery, which was a hard time for the family.

RS talks about the time they did recording with Vee-Jay Records. Mavis was sick during a recording session. Subsequently they recorded more and more, traveled a lot and were making fames. They appeared on TV, and at Carnegie Hall, etc.

Mavis Staples (MS) talks about background, ages (22 years old), her education and hobbies. She loves meeting people, seeing different things and learning new things. She used to sing in school and never expected to sing professionally. While singing, she puts all she can into the singing. MS mentions that she did not enjoy singing rock and roll because she is a Christian. She would rather sing for God because she feels close to God. Her greatest ambition is to save someone's soul, which is the main reason for her singing.

Yvonne Staples mentioned that she sang baritone and replaced her brother when he was drafted into the U.S. Army. She enjoyed traveling during the concert tours and singing with the family. She studied business during school and hoped to continue singing and working in the business field as well.

RS talks about expressing God's message through their singing. He says: "if you are close to God, you can always get it through." He doesn't mind singing in a club but would not change the repertoire of the gospel songs.
Oceola Staples mentions that she prays her family continues to stay together and sing about God's grace.
RS talks about the accidents they experienced on the road.
RS continues to talk about the incident that they experienced on the road. He talks about owning a horse, named Mike, when he was young, and winning races.
RS and his wife chat about the concert tours going to Dallas, San Francisco and other places, and the things that happened on the tour.
RS and his wife chat about some random topics such as their childhood, old friends, cooking, bowling, and boxing. RS mentions that he is a singer, not a preacher.

row.entry: PW and SS talk about SS's time in Belgium. They talk about a record of Robert Johnson songs; the performers are not identified. They talk about a person called Robert Johnson, Jr., not the biological son of Robert Johnson. He is Robert Junior Lockwood, a stepson of Robert Johnson.

They talk about SS playing with RJ Lockwood. SS got RJ Lockwood into the union, Local 208. They also played with Tampa Rad. SS mentions Muddy Waters and Big Bill (no last name). PW says he promoted concerts back in the '40s called People's Songs.
They talk about Studs Terkel doing a touring show with Bill. The talk about Bill.

PW asks if Robert Junior Lockwood (RJL) did many church songs. SS replies and also mentions Bobby Bland, B.B. King, T-Bone Walker, Blind Lemon, and Lonnie Johnson. SS talks about some of the songs that RJL sang. SS talks about playing with RJL.
PW asks about the time SS and RJL played together. SS sings part of a song. SS talks about another occasion where they played together. SS talks about parties at which they played.
SS talks about a record RJL made. PW asks what RJL was like. SS replies. He then talks about a restaurant that made the best creole gumbo. PW asks how old RLJ was when SS first met him. SS replies.
SS talks about RJL's mother. She is still alive, living in St. Louis. RJL also has a sister in t. Louis. PW asks is RJL played any other instruments. SS replies.
SS says he made records with RJL for Mercury in about 1952. SS talks about different places in which he played. He says he came to Chicago in 1933, but did not stay.
SS says that he would like more work than he now has. He explains. He says he stated out with HighTone Records. They discus other record labels.
PW asks about Robert Johnson's personality. SS replies at length. SS talks about a musician named Sonny Boy [Williamson?]. He talks about how musicians dressed.
PW asks about Robert Johnson's appeal to women. SS responds. PW asks about musicians getting rides. SS responds. PW asks about relations between black musicians and white people. SS responds.
SS talks about his early years as a musician, about 1924. He talks about his first job. He learned to play organ and piano. PW asks SS when he first started in music. SS replies at length.
SS says caught a freight train and ran away to Memphis. He worked on the railroad. He'd ride a train, in the caboose, to get to the places he would play.
SS mentions meeting Fats Waller, Bing Crosby, Teddy Wilson, and Count Basie in about 1931 or 1932. This is about when he met Robert Johnson.
PW asks if Robert Johnson always played his songs the same way. SS replies. SS talks about Bessie Smith and Roosevelt Sykes. SS talks about other piano players.

PW and SS talk about the opportunities they've missed and those they had. Again, PW asks if Robert Johnson always played his songs the same way. SS responds. SS talks about not having money. He talks about Jerry Lee Lewis.

PW talks about a record producer (probably Chris Strachwitz, Arhoolie Records) who told him that it was most important to have the rights to a song. SS talks about songs, rights to songs, and making money.
PW says that you've got to look out for yourself. SS agrees and talks about his experience. SS says he played with Miles Davis in 1963. He talks about other musicians he played with.
PW asks about how Robert Johnson acted with his audiences. SS replies. He says that Robert Johnson made "it possible" for other guitar players. SS talks about people he played with at his house.
SS says he is drawing Social Security. PW offers to make a meal. SS declines.
SS gets back to talking about Robert Johnson. He talks about food. SS and POW talk about SS playing in Europe. PW says that what he wants to hear from musicians is "what is life to you?"
SS talks about his real experiences. He talks about playing overseas. He talks about a number of musicians he's played with. He mentions playing soul, rock-and-roll, and the blues.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (01:33:59) : analog 3 3/4 ips, half track ; 7 in.

row.entry: SS talks about playing boogie, blues and church songs. PW asks about the performer having to be honest in his playing. He uses classical music as an example. PW talks about a person called Pete (no last name).
SS talks about Robert Johnson and his songs. One song is "Dust My Broom." He sings parts of several songs. SS discusses what some of these songs are really about and what they mean.
SS talks about a pretty woman he saw at a party. He talks about Lonnie Johnson. She was the inspiration for his song "Brown Skin Woman." He talks about the blues telling a story.

SS talks about playing in a club and talking with other blues musicians. He talks about playing in England and other places in Europe. He talks about playing for an all-white audience. He talks about playing with Robert Johnson.
SS talks about the keys in which he plays. He talks about recording for BMI. He talks about drinking "hard wine." He talks about copying [dubbing] songs from a collection of tapes.
PW and SS talk about Memphis Minnie's recordings. SS talks about a recording session. He talks about a new song he wrote that he will not record unless he can retain the rights to the song.
PW offers drinks and dinner to SS. SS declines as he has another commitment. They talk about standing up for themselves.

PW asks if SS knows where Robert Johnson went after he was last associated with SS. SS answers. SS talks about Robert Johnson and women. They talk about Model A and Model T Ford cars. SS rambles about cars, trucks, food and people.
PW and SS talk about having perfect pitch. They talk about a song called "Some Stack Light." SS talks about Howlin' Wolf and Bukka White.
SS talks about sharing money from a performance. He talks about travelling by truck, car, train, and Greyhound bus. He talks about the last time he played with Robert Johnson.

PW asks if Robert Johnson travelled by himself or with other people. SS responds at length. He says that Robert Johnson travelled only with his guitar. HE talks about Sonny Boy [Williams?]. He talks about several songs.

PW asks if Robert Johnson ever talked about his past life. SS answers. PW asks about "King Biscuit." SS says that it was a radio station and flour. SS talks about Robert Junior Lockwood and several other musicians.
PW asks if Robert Johnson talked about the artists he admired. SS replies and mentions several musicians.
PW says that it is hard to judge the age of the performers. SS responds. HE talks about playing with Ma Rainey. He talks about working for a circus. He talks about learning to play in many keys.
SS and PW talk about a medicine call "66." PW asks if Robert Johnson ever mentioned how he got started in music. SS answers.

PW asks if Robert Johnson ever talked about the artist he liked. SS responds. He mentions several musicians. PW asks if Robert Johnson always sand his song the same way or if he changed them around. SS replies.

PW asks how SS met Robert Johnson for the first time. SS relies that he was an electrician for Arkansas Power and Light. He talks about this at length. Eventually he says where he first met Robert Johnson.

PW asks what first impressed SS about Robert Johnson. SS replies. He talks about a number of musicians he played with. He says the piano players and the guitar players normally did not hang out together

PW says that to him Robert Johnson seems unusually poetic or literary. HE asks of SS noted that. SS says he did not pay much attention to that. However, Robert Johnson's slide guitar playing did touch him. They talk more about Robert Johnson's lyrics.
PW says that some people say the blues men are the modern poets. He expands on this idea. SS talks about a song he wrote with a person called Dixon. The title is "I Am the Blues."
PW says that he hopes they can get together again for another interview. SS replies, "The pleasure is all yours." PW laughs.

PW says that Little Brother (Montgomery), a piano player, is dong a new record and he (PW) has been asked to write the liner notes. HE asks SS about Little Brother. SS says that Little Brother is his best friend. They met in 1924.

row.entry: "You Came Back to Me" - Weaver Brothers ("At last have you come back to me, since the time I'd like to set you free, and you offer me again your heart") (Columbia 15487-D)
"Prison Sorrows" - Weaver Brothers ("It is hard to be locked up in prison") (Columbia 15487-D)
"This World of Sorrow" - Panhandle Pete ("I would give this world of sorrow...if you'd only stand by me") (Decca 5599)

"The Gambler's Dying Words" - Panhandle Pete ("I'll tell you of a poor young man who gambled night and day, and he was taken very sick; he tried but could not pray; his friend all left him one by one, and he began to cry") (Decca 5599)
"The Old K-C" - Jess Young's Tennessee Band ("I thought I heard that old K-C blow, yes Lord...and she blowed like she never blowed no more") (Columbia 15431-D)
"Lovin' Henry" - Jess Young's Tennessee Band ("Has anybody seen my lovin' Henry, has anybody seen my lovin' man") Columbia 15431-D)
"I Cannot Call Her Mother" - Charlie Poole And The North Carolina Ramblers ("The marriage ride is over") (Columbia 15307-D)
"What Is Home Without Babies" - Charlie Poole And The North Carolina Ramblers ("All alone in a mansion, no one to love and caress") (Columbia 15307-D)
"The New Market Wreck" - George Reneau ("The Southern Railway had a wreck, at 10 o'clock one morn") (Vocalion 14930)
"The Bald-Headed End of the Broom" - George Reneau ("Now it is a very funny thing, catching the young and old") (Vocalion 14930)
"Bury Me in the Hillbilly Way" - Billy Cox and Cliff Hobbs ("One evening a young man lay dying, beneath the root there lay in the rain") (Vocalion 05055)
"Old Pinto and Me" - Billy Cox and Cliff Hobbs ("Oh pinto someday there'll be a great change, but I love my old home way out on the range") (Vocalion 05055)
"Frankie Silvers" - Byrd Moore and His Hot Shots ("...My sun goes down, my days are past...I am gonna see this world at last...why did you take my life away") (Columbia 15536-D)
"The Hills of Tennessee" - Byrd Moore and His Hot Shots ("On one bright and merry May") (Columbia 15536-D)
"Want My Black Baby Back" - Walter Couch and Wilks Ramblers ("Hambone's sidetracked, ain't that a shame, why don't you get your lady of your own") (Bluebird B7095)
"Lonesome Trail" - Walter Couch and Wilks Ramblers ("...There's just one thing I wanna hear you say before I say goodbye, now come to me my little girl, and say you love me true") (Bluebird B7095)
"I'll Be All Smiles Tonight" - The Reed Children ("I'll deck my brow with roses...though my heart will break tomorrow, I will be all smiles tonight") (Columbia 15525-D)

"I Once Did Have a Sweetheart" - The Reed Children ("I once have a sweetheart, a sweetheart brave and true...he was like most other boys...when he came to say good bye, my heart did overflow") (Columbia 15525-D)

"It's Hard to Love and Can't Be Loved" - Buster Carter and Preston Young ("Don't you see that lonesome dove, ...he's mourning for his own true, just like I mourn for mine") [cuts off abruptly] (Columbia 15690-D)

"I'll Roll in My Sweet Baby's Arms" - Buster Carter and Preston Young ("Ain't gonna work on the railroad, ain't work on it long, lay around my shack till that mail train comes back and I'll roll in my sweet baby's arms") (Columbia 15690-D)
"A Lazy Farmer Boy" - Buster Carter and Preston Young ("Now I'll sing a little song, but it ain't there long about a lazy farmer...that young man was always well") (Columbia 15702-D)
"It Won't Hurt No More" - Buster Carter and Preston Young ("Hello doc, I've got a bad tooth, I want you to look and see what to do") (Columbia 15702-D)
"Casey Jones" - Gid Tanner ("Train going south, Birmingham, the first stop, come all you rounders if you want to hear, story told about a brave engineer") (Columbia 15237-D)

"Just Make My People Think You Care" - Dewey and Gassie Bassett ("Oh, won't you come my little darling, won't you come and bathe my brow, before they tell me I am dying, won't you come and say goodbye") (Bluebird B8235)
"Sympathy" - Dewey and Gassie Bassett ("You are all I have but now I feel so bad, all that I'm asking is sympathy") (Bluebird B8235)

"The Man Who Wrote Home Sweet Home Never Was A Married Man" - Charlie Parker and Mack Woolbright ("Man gets up early in the morning and leaves his wife in bed...he never had no loving wife to beat him with a frying pan, she'll meet you at the door when you [...] come in") (Columbia 15236-D)
"Ticklish Reuben" - Charlie Parker and Mack Woolbright("My name is Ticklish Reuben from way down in old Vermont") (Columbia 15236-D)

"Little Frankie" - Roba Stanley and Bill Patterson ("Frankie woke up one morning...he's my man but he done me wrong") [poor sound quality] (Okeh 40436)

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:32:43) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: This is the first part of a two-part interview Pete Welding (PW) did with Henry Townsend (HT), conducted in St. Louis, Missouri. Most of the interview is about Robert Johnson (RJ). A third person, called Joe, was present, [not Big Joe Williams]. (Note: It is difficult to hear and understand Joe, as he does not have a microphone.)

row.entry: PW asks about HT meeting RJ. HT says they met at a house party, where they were both to perform, in the early to mid-1930s. They talk at length about RJ. HT also mentions Roosevelt Sykes and Booker T. Washington.
PW asks about the music RJ was playing that night. HT's response includes that RJ was playing slide guitar.
PW asks how the people responded to the slide guitar. HT says, "they were wild about him." HT talks about playing with RJ.
PW asks about the numbers (songs) that RJ performed. HT responds and talks about playing with RJ.
PW asks if RJ was fairly well paid. HT responds and then talks about where RJ was living.

PW asks what kind of impression RJ's music made on HT. HT replies that he was interested both RJ's guitar and his singing. They talk about what made RJ's Mississippi Blues different from other musicians. HT responds at length.
PW asks about HT picking up RJ's music. HT responds that he was mostly trying to learn execution. He says that RJ was an easy going guy.
HT talks about other people RJ hung out with. He talks about playing in the Harlem Club in Illinois.
They talk about Robert Lockwood Jr. and Roosevelt Sykes. They talk about how to contact Robert Lockwood and RJ.
They talk about RJ's travelling and old Mississippi musicians RJ may have known. HT says that RJ supported himself just playing music on his guitar.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:25:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: This is the second part of a two-part interview Pete Welding (PW) did with Henry Townsend (HT), conducted in St. Louis, Missouri.

row.entry: PW, HT and Joe are talking about RL. They mention Honeyboy Edwards. They talk about Johnson as a "ladies man." They talk about RJ's age at the time he died.
PW asks about RJ's working on songs "when he was here." HT responds. He says the RJ was able to work on inspiration and could put a song together "just like that." He explains.

HT says that his acquaintance with RJ was brief. RJ was a "pretty nice guy." PW asks why HT thought RJ was young when he died. HT thought RJ was young when they met. HT explains and talks about RJ's character.
PW asks if HT got the impression that RJ took a lot of pride in his music. HT replies at length.
PW asks HT if he and RJ rehearsed together. HT responds.

PW asks if there were any other musicians around town (i.e., St. Louis) that RJ worked with in that period. HT responds. They talk about Jimmy Yancey, a piano player. They also talk about Alonzo Yancey.
PW asks HT if there is anything else HT can tell him about RJ. HT responds.

PW asks about Hi Henry Brown. Joe responds. They also talk about Ike Rodgers. PW asks about Henry Spalding. HT responds, as does Joe. They mention Nick Bones, Clifford Gibson and Roosevelt Sykes. They discuss Clifford Gibson at length and talk about his dog.
PW asks what other musicians were around in the 1920s and 1930s. He mentions Pinetop Sparks. PW asks about Pinetop Sparks and his sister.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (Side 1: 00:54:54; Side 2: 00:06:00) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW ask JT bout his background. JT responds. He was born in Altheimer, Arkansas. His father was a sharecropper. At age 12 his family moved to Little Rock. He started listening to music when he was young. JT tells who he heard. He was interested in playing the harmonica; this was around 1954 or 1955.

They talk about modern blues that JT heard on the radio. He listened to King Biscuit. JT talks about learning to play the harmonica. He started playing when he was about 9 years old. Later he stared playing the guitar.
JT says he made a guitar out of a board and wire. It was called a "post guitar." They talk about musicians who played this kind of guitar.
PW asks JT when he got a hold of a real guitar. JT responds that it was after he moved to Little Rock. He started playing a real guitar using a neighbor's guitar. He played a lot of Jim Reed's music.

JT met Fen (Fenton) Robinson who showed him a lot. He had already started recording. They talk about Fen Robinson. JT played bass guitar with Robinson. It was a solid-body instrument with unusual strings and tuning.

PW ask JT how long he played with Fen. JT says that it was for a couple of years. His skill as musician improved during this time. He also played with other musicians. JT talks about a female singer called Sweet Lorraine.

PW asks what music JT was listening to. JT responds that he listened mostly to the radio. He listened to blues, and rock and roll, like Little Richard. JT says that he played both blues and rock and roll. They talk about what JT listened to on the radio. They talk about black radio stations and white radio stations.

They talk about black jazz on the radio. However, JT listened mostly to blues and rock and roll. JT says the only records he would buy were B.B. King and Jimmy Reed. JT learned to play B.B. King songs note-for-note, but could not get King's feel.

JT talks about getting jobs (gigs) on his own. Only the best musicians played during the week. Everyone got work on the weekends. JT talks about playing with musicians who came through town (Little Rock).
PW asks JT when started playing with Fenton Robinson. JT says he was 15 or 16 years old and played with him for several years. In 1965 JT moved to California. He talks about a band The Blue Notes.
JT got work in a club in San Pedro, California. He then worked with Joe Houston and went back onto the road. There was not a market for blues in California, so they played mostly soul music.
They talk about JT's trips back to Little Rock. There was less interest in the blues than "back then." They talk about making recording in Little Rock.
JT says he made several records in little Rock before he moved to California. He does not know if they were issued. He made them for A & M Records.

PW asks JT to describe the music scene in California. JT says "this is difficult." People in California go to clubs, very much on the weekends. A lot of former blues singers are now singing soul. Tyrone Davis is big.

They talk about a place called Home of the Blues. JT says that her recorded there. They talk about Larry Davidson. Hey talk about a blues band, Blues With a Feeling. JT talks about Big John [who joins in this interview].
They talk about blues styles that JT plays. They talk about JT developing his own style.
JT talks about what he did to develop his own blues style. JT started studying music. He wanted to get away from the B.B. King style. He learned a lot playing with a saxophone.
JT says that the last time he went back to Arkansas he found that the same songs sounded differently in Little Rock than they did in Louisiana. They talk about horns being added to a band

PW and JT talk about a band called Blues with a Feeling. JT moved to Pasadena. The band has been together for about two years. They talk about the band and some of the places they played. They talk about people's nicknames.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate, 00:59:36) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) and Robert Wilkins (RW) are discussing the differences between blues and sacred songs and how RW believes you can only sing one genre or the other at a time.
PW and RW say blues songs are the songs of the body and sacred songs are the songs of the soul. RW states, "The body is the temple... only one spirit can dwell in that body at a time."
RW explains blues songs are evil songs and of the devil because they often deal with songs of mistreatment between a man and woman.

PW asks, "What do you feel makes a blues, a blues? How is it different from other songs?" RW responds by saying blues is an inward feeling that has occurred to you and causes you to become sorry or grievous. It results in a blues singer singing about the feeling and others can relate to the same feeling.
RW explains the only way to get relief from the spiritual soul is to praise the Lord
PW reiterates that by singing the blues you can only relieve yourself from bodily and emotional troubles
PW ask RW if he thinks about the other people involved when he creates his rhymes and PW wants to know RW's process of writing blues songs. RW mentions his song "The Auction Day Blues."

PW ask RW where he was born, what year, how he got interested in playing and singing and was any one in his family musical. RW answers by saying he was born in Hernando, Mississippi in 1896 and none of his family members were musical except his grandfather on his mother's side who played the fiddle.

RW explains the different types of songs the teenagers used to play on his porch and in the community when he was around 7 years old. He says they used to play blues, ragtime and hillbilly songs on the guitar. RW mentions the teenagers would play "The St. Louis Buck" and would buck dance (referring to tap dancing) while performing the songs.

RW explains he received his first guitar from his mom when he was fifteen years old and no one taught him how to tune or play his guitar. He began to learn "Alabama Blues," "The Buck Time Blues," and other blues songs were mentioned.
PW asks RW if there were any musicians in the area that people used to say were great blues men when he was young. RW mentions Aaron [Tiller?].
PW ask "What kind of occasions would you play music for?" RW responds with picnics and Saturday night fish fries at people's houses.
RW discusses his father, step-father and mother
PW ask RW if he played the same style of music for Black and White audience members. RW mentions the "Rain Dance" and describes how often he played and how much money he made.
RW discusses how he knew he had a gift of playing music
RW tells PW the guest musicians he remembered coming to play at Fall each year such as Jim Jackson and Elijah [Averret or Avern?] who would dance, do black face and crack jokes.
RW says he moved to Memphis on January 1, 1915 when he was almost 19 years old because his mother was tired of farming. During that time, he was not playing at events.
RW discusses how he began to play music again after Rev. Macintosh asked him. During this time, he recorded "Jail House" and "I Do."
PW asks RW how he came to perform music two years later with people like Sonny Boy and Spoon.
RW discusses the album he made in 1935 and why he is called Tim. RW later mentions that the 1935 album was the last album he made until recent.
PW asks RW why he quit music in 1936, why RW decided to stop playing blues music and begin playing religious music, and his experiences practicing medicine and church work.
PW asks RW if he has written any religious music. RW responds saying he has written religious music and how 2/3 of music in the blues form comes from religious music.
PW asks RW who were some of the big blues musicians working when RW was still in Memphis. RW says Jim Jackson and Frank Stokes were big names playing normally at houses and for parties.
PW and RW discuss how blues songs are considered sin songs.
RW explains the way he plays guitar is not different when comparing blues and religious songs.
PW asks RW what he does as a musician now. RW says he plays at different churches.

did.unittitle:
Big Joe Williams interview #1,
circa June 1964
did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:47:20) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: The tape box indicates this is Thomas A. Dorsey interview #3, but it is the interview with Big Joe Williams #1. SR032 and SR036 include the same recording. It is unclear which is original and which is the duplicate.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) asks Poor Joe Williams [a.k.a. Big Joe Williams] (JW) where and when he was born and about his family. JW replies at length. He was born in Crofton, Mississippi on October 16, 1898 (or so). His father was a sharecropper.
JW says built his first guitar when he was 5 or 6 years old. He explains how he tuned it and made music.
JW talks about the songs he was playing on his first home made guitar. He talks about where he heard these songs. He talks about picnics and parties.
JW says that his nickname was "Poor Joe" A girl friend gave him this name.
PW and JW go back to discuss playing music in his childhood days. He first played on the bottom of a water bucket.
Joe talks about other people in his family who made music.
Joe talks about the racial mix of his grandparents. They were part American Indian.
Joe talks about making a cigar box guitar.
PW asks if other people were playing bottleneck or slide guitar. JW responds that some people used a knife instead of a bottleneck.
PW asks if there were any really good musicians down around where he lived. JW responds.
PW and JW talk about JW's first real guitar. It was a 12 string he got when he was 15 or 16 years old.
PW asks if any of Joe's brothers or sisters were musicians. JW answers that, then talks about his mother and his father.
PW and JW talk about JW "roaming around" the country. They discuss the music he played (on the street) to earn money.
PW asks JW where he learned his songs and also about the songs JW wrote.
JW talks about returning home after a period of "tough luck."
JW talks about the first record he made, about 1921. He talks about other recordings.
JW talks about how he earned his living in the 1920s. He talks at length about picnics, dances, women and whiskey.
JW talks about the tunes he played in those days. He talks about getting payed for playing.
PW asks JW if he ran into any trouble with the law. JW responds.
JW talks about the kinds of places he played and some of the people he played with.

did.unittitle:
Big Joe Williams interview #2,
circa June 1964
did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:44:25) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: JW talks about the mules owned by his grandfather. One of the mules was named Joe. He talks about the other mules He also talks about Christmas and drinking whiskey.
JW talks about his great-grandmother, Mae (?). She told him about praying during slave times. She came from Africa when she was about 16.
JW talks about both of his great-grandmothers on his father's side. One was named Roxie.
PW asks if JW's father was a musician. JW answers. PW asks where JW first heard the blues. JW responds
PW asks if JW got to hear phonograph records when he was a kid. JW responds.
PW asks JW if he ever played in a whore house. JW says "Sure, indeed," then talks at length about the experience.

PW asks how many records JW made in 1927 when he was recording for Vocalion Records. JW responds and talks about recording in Atlanta, Georgia. JW explains how he prepared for a recording session. He talks at length about a musicians club.

JW says he would go and play "where ever the money wuz (sic)." He talks at length about Blind Lemon Jefferson. He mentions the song "Mean Snake Blues" and Victoria Spivey who recorded it in about 1921. (Note: It was actually recorded in 1926.) He talks about Lonnie Johnson.
PW asks about Piano Willie. JW responds. He mentions a Blind Willie. More talk about Blind Lemon - the way he tuned his guitar and his finder picking style.
PW asks about Jack White. JW responds. More talk about Blind Lemon, including how and where he died.
They talk about JW's records, songs and labels. He recorded under several different names.
PW asks "who else did you record for in the late 20s and early 30s." JW replies.
PW asks when JW came across Mayo Williams. JW answers.
PW asks when JW stopped recording for Bluebird. JW responds and says he moved to Columbia records. He also recorded for Trumpet records.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:47:51) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: JW talks about the first things he remembers from when he was a little kid.
JW sings a religious song He learned from his grandmother. He talks about the song. He also talks about his grandfather being a sharecropper and how sharecropping worked.
JW talks about the sharecropping system. He also talks about the rental farming system.
JW talks about when he was a little kid, running away from his grandfather's place.
JW talks about his mother and his father. JW and PW talk about teen years then and now, and community standards.
JW talks about his parents growing up together. He talks about his step-father. He sings a song called "Mean step-Father."
PW asks about John Williams, JW's father. JW talks about his parents, grandparents and step-father. His mother and father were not married.
JW talks about staying with his aunts, uncles, and cousins when he was growing up. He says his full name is Joe Lee Williams.
JW talks about going to school (or not). HE talks about running away from home.
JW talks about playing a bucket. He talks about his grandfather's whipping belt.
JW sings a hymn "As Long As I Can Feel the Spirit." He learned this from his grandmother. He talks about his grandmother and grandfather.
JW talks about his suit and outfit. HE talks about his grandfather's mare. He talks about a family (Gilmore) he lived with until he was about 21 years old.
JW talks about a saw mill in Macon Mississippi where he worked.
JW talks about how much money the saw mill workers were paid. He talks about living in saw mill camps.
JW talks about music and musicians in the saw mill camps.
PW asks, "How old do you think the blues are?" PW answers.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:47:46) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: JW talks about catching fish, cooking them and making corn bread.
PW asks about the kind of music played at a fish fry. JW replies.

PW asks about medicine shows. JW replies. The shows came to towns, not lumber camps. JW talks about the kinds of acts/performances in the shows. JW started travelling with medicine shows when he was 9 years old.
PW asks how medicine shows were put together and how did they travel. JW replies.
JW talks about his performing - dancing while playing the guitar.
JW talks a jug band he played with and recording with them.
JW talks about a "bad man" called King of the M and O Bottom, from Tuscaloosa, Alabama. (Note: JW said this person's name is something like "Toxie Cane")
JW talks about a week long picnic and hay ride in the wood in the late 1920s. He talks about the band that played.
PW asks when the "J.C. Collins thing (?)" was recorded. PW replies that it was 1927. JW then discusses this in some detail.
JW talks about his time playing and travelling with minstrel shows. He talks about how he was paid.
JW talks about some of the musicians who were part of the shows.
PW asks how JW got to make his first record. JW replies.
JW talks about King Solomon Hill. It was both a place in Alabama and a record label. JW talks about Bullet Williams and several other musicians.
JW talks, at length, about a harp player called George "Brother" Williams.
PW asks JW about when he was starting out as a musician, how did he know where to go to play music. JW replies.
PW asks JW when he knew he had a gift for music. JW answers and talks about some of the earliest songs he heard.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:48:00) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: JW tells a story about looking for treasure in 1943 or so.
JW tells another story about hunting for treasure with a money needle made of baling wire. He also talks about money diggers.
PW asks about ghosts. JW tells a story about a picnic and a ghost.
JW talks about a sharp shooter named Kenny Wagner.
JW talks about Joe DeMoorehead (?), Kid Washington (?), and someone called Blue Steel.
JW talks about Kid Washington being a gambler. He talks about what Blue Steel is doing now.
PW asks JW who were some of the other guys from about that time? JW talks about people called Good Buddy, Corn Bread, Joe DeMoorehead, Zoo Lawrence (?), and others.
JW talks about living in St. Louis. He talks about stealing turkeys.
JW talks about playing a dance in the country.
JW talks about the man named Corn Bread. His real name was Kid Douglas. He also talks about Red Lawrence.
JW talks about Blue Steel and shooting a Sheriff. He mentions Sleepy John Estes.
JW talks about his friend Blow Mouth, who could imitate any musical instrument with his mouth.
PW asks JW when he met Memphis Minnie. JW responds.
PW asks about Lead Belly. JW replies and also talks about playing with the Reverend Gary Davis.
PW asks about Mama Law. JW replies. He also talks about Horsehead Lulu and Stavin Chain.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:48:20) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW asks JW to talk more about the man called Blue Steel and his powers. JW tells the story of Blue Steel selling his soul to the devil.
PW asks JW what Blue Steel looked like, what kind of guy he was. JW answers.
More talk about the things Blue Steel did.
PW asks about Mama Law. JW says she was a conjure woman, a hoo-doo. He also talks about a lucky root, a John McConker (?) root.
PW asks about a mojo hand. JW responds. He also talks about lucky numbers.
PW asks JW if he was ever much of a gambler. JW responds. He talks about a card game called Georgia Skin.
JW talks about betting on cards.
JW says he basically earned his living from music, but he also had other jobs. He talks about quitting jobs after he became proficient at them.
JW talks about working in a grit mill, a mill that grinds corn. The miller would take a toll of corn for his fee. JW worked on mud slides driving teams of oxen.
PW asks where Mama Law got her special powers. JW says that she got her power from the devil, like a witch.

JW met a witch named Mama Mary. He tells about his time with her. She knows all about his family. He goes home with her and has a number of mystical experiences, including ones with a pet snake, a pet alligator, and a pet black cat.
PW asks from where Mama Mary got her money. JW answers. He saw exciting things and cures.
JW talks about Mother Williams, a woman preacher. She was JW's wife, and was a healer. JW sings a bit of "When I did the best I can, I want my crown."
PW asks where JW met Mother Williams. JW says he met her in the 1920s in Missouri. She travelled all over the world. He says they married around 1959. JW talks about his children.
PW asks about the first woman JW loved. He answers that her name was Malvina.

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:47:00) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: JW talks about playing with two women: Malvina and Shilk (?), and his cousin, Thomas Styme (?), he played the "bazooka horn," the jazz horn. Malvina was a cook for white people. She and JW fell in love and traveled together.
Malvina could sing the blues. JW sings "I'm gonna get up in the mornin', walking down the lonesome line." He talks about Malvina and how he left her.
PW asks what kind of a woman was Malvina. JW says Malvina was a mean woman. He says she killed a man. JW talks about their relationship.
JW tells the story about he and Malvina at a dance. Another woman, named Amanda (Mandy), is involved. He was cut taking away a knife.
JW talks about his first wife, Ella Mae. They met in about 1921 and stayed together for about a year. He left her and went back on the road.

JW says he was making a living playing music and working. He borrowed $500 to buy furniture. To pay it back, he took a job but plowed only when he felt like it. This did not repay the loan. He took another job and finally did repay the loan.
PW asks about a record, "Stack of Dollars," the JW recorded in 1935. JW says he first recorded it in the 1920s. They discuss this.
PW and JW discuss JW's early recordings. PW consults a (unidentified) book. They talk about the songs and who performed them.
They discuss recording sessions for Blue Bird Records in 1933 and 1935. They discuss the performers on these and other recording sessions.

PW asks JW when he came across Sonny Boy Williamson. JW says it was about 1922. He talks about Sonny Boy at length. He also talks about a number of other musicians he travelled with. He talks about a guitar contest he won.
JW talks about Sonny Boy's recordings. JW says Sonny Boy's first hits were "Sugar Mama" and "School Girl."

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (00:47:10) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, full track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: JW talks about some of the musicians with whom he played including Charlie Patton. He talks at length about Patton, his early recordings and his death.
JW talks about a contest he was n with Charlie Patton.
JW talks about Brother James, James Harding. He talks about Grant Malone, an organ player. He talks about a car wreck in which several people were killed, including Brother James.
PW asks "What kind of guy was Charlie Patton like?" JW responds.
PW asks JW if he ever met Son House. JW says he knew Son House well. He talks about him.
JW talks at length about Robert Johnson.
JW talks about Robert Johnson playing bottleneck guitar.
JW talks about Blind Willie McTell, who also played bottleneck guitar.
JW talks about Peetie Wheatstraw (William Bunch). He played guitar and piano. He was killed in a car wreck.
JW talks about bluesmen living in St. Louis. He talks about Walter Davis. JW and PW discuss some other musicians including Tommy Johnson and Ishman Bracey.
PW asks about Skip James. JW responds. He also talks about Chief, a one arm guitar player.
PW asks about other good singers from down in Mississippi. JW responds and specifically talks about Tom turner and Blind Teddy Darby (Theodore Roosevelt Darby).

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: Pete Welding (PW) interviews Robert Pete Williams (RPW). Other people are present in the room. It seems that the SR begins in the midst of an ongoing conversation. There may be a recording that precedes this one.

row.entry: PW and RPW talk about playing blues and spirituals. RPW talks about being a Christian. He says the blues followed him all the time. He says he made his first guitar out of a cigar box at age 18 or 19. Later, he bought a used guitar.
PW asks when RPW first became aware that he had a gift for music. RPW responds.
PW asks what RPW thinks the blues are. RPW answers at length.
RPW says he walked away from Christ and stepped into trouble.
RPW talks about getting into trouble because he was carrying a gun. He talks about drinking wine.

PW says that it seems that the blues strongly pursue ROW. RPW replies. He says he feels good when he plays the blues. He tells a story about having the blues so bad that he could not sleep. They talk about a song.
RPW shows the 12 string guitar that he played on a song. PW asks how he learned to play. RPW answers at length.
PW asks RPW how old he was when he made his cigar box guitar. RPW responds. He talks about his home.
RPW talks about his parole from jail. He worked in dairy.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 01:05:10; Side 2: 00:29:00) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, half track, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: PW and AW talk about the forming of AW's band, Canned Heat, in November of 1965. AW talks about the turnover of band personnel. He commends the band's management.

AW attributes Canned Heat's early success to the absence of the word "blues" in the band's name. He talks about being part of another band, for a short period, before Canned Heat came together again in early 1967. He talks about some of the band members and their interest in specific forms of music.

AW says that the makeup of Canned Heat now is 100% committed to the blues. PW and AW talk about the appearance of the band and the music itself. AW talks about the coffee house and college circuit market. AW discusses various blues bands and where they stand in the market. He says he's concerned that the popular interest in the blues will not last more than a year or two.

PW asks if AW considered the blues as something distinct from the larger body of rock, folk rock and experimental rock. AW answers and explains his answer. He says that there is a blues buying public.
They talk about Canned Heat's audience and other performers with a similar audience.
PW asks what Canned Heat set out to do when the band was formed. AW answers in detail and at length.
PW asks about changes as the band has been working over the last year and a half. AW responds.
PW asks about translating older style blues to Canned Heat's repertoire. AW responds.
They talk about the liner notes PW wrote for Caned Heat's first album. They talk about the modal approach to playing the blues and the harmonic approach. They talk about the 12-bar blues structure.
PW asks how large a repertoire the band has now. AW responds and explains how songs are dropped and added.
They talk about adapting old-style blues to electric instruments. They talk about taking "licks" from old recordings.
PW asks where most of the band's material comes from. AW replies and gives examples.

PW asks about the kinds of places the band has been working in the last few months. AW responds: clubs, psychedelic spaces, and one-night concerts. He explains. They discuss the audiences at these venues.

They talk about how long the listening public will be interested in the blues. They discuss if there will be an audience for black blues singers (and bands). They discuss black blues players and white blues players. They discuss old blues players and young blues players. They talk about singing the blues.
AW continues taking about blues singers and recordings. He says Canned Heat added brass for its recordings.
PW asks about other working groups that AW finds interesting. AW replies and discusses several performers and bands.
AW abut Taj Mahal, the tuning(s) he uses, and his style of playing the blues.
PW asks if AW has encountered any interesting bands while he has been on the road. AW responds and gives examples.
PW asks if Canned Heat has played in New York. AW answers. He says they had a better reaction at Club 47 in Boston, than they did in New York.
PW asks about the problems playing amplified blues versus acoustic blues. AW responds. He talks about sounds available to amplified music. They talk at length about writing new material.
PW asks how much of the band's repertoire is original material. AW answers. He discusses the language of song lyrics. They discuss the transition from speech to song.
AW talks about using new instruments and new sounds. He specifically mentions the Fender Bass. He talks about rhythm sections and the blues.

"Kid Man Blues" (Young, vocal, mandolin; John Lee Granderson, guitar; John Wrench, harmonica)
"Forty-Four Blues" (Young, vocal; Little Walter Jacobs, harmonica; Jimmy Walker, piano)

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (backcoated polyester; 00:32:30) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, quarter track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: The interview was conducted by Franois Positif (a jazz journalist), in Paris, France, at the Hotel d'Angleterre. The tape is in stereo, but the audio is itself mono. This copy is dubbed from the source, which is a longer interview.

row.entry: [several false starts] LY says that he was not born in New Orleans; rather he was born in Woodville, Mississippi.
LY says that he was raised in New Orleans. He talks about his mother and his family. He talks about trucks advertising dances.
LY talks about his father who played trumpet. LY went to Minneapolis. He started as a drummer then switched to alto and tenor sax.

LY says that he played in Salina, Kansas. He asked Art Bronson, "the boss man," to buy him a tenor sax. As soon as he played it, he knew it was the right instrument for him. FI and LY discuss playing the tenor sax. LY talks about Count Basie.
FI asks LY about his start with the Count Basie Band. LY responds. He talks, with a great deal of anger, about being a colored person.
FI asks about the tenor play who influenced LY. LY talks about Frankie Trumbauer. FI asks about Bert Freeman. LY answers.

FI asks LY his opinion about the Blues. LY responds. He talks about his father and his sister. He says that early on he could not read music. His father forced him to learn to read music. He says that he did not like being constrained by written music.
LY says that he does not like to read music. He says that someone in New York is composing music for him. He talks about Norman Granz.
FI asks about LY's last recordings. LY says he played clarinet on them.
LW talks at length about when he first came to New York in 1934.
FI asks about the music LY is playing now. LY answers.
FI asks why LY left the Count Basie Band. They talk about his recordings with Basie.
LY says that he stays by himself and is a private person.
FI asks if LY prefers playing with a trio, quartet or band. LY answers that he prefers the quartet. He says that he wants his music to be "sweet."

FI asks when LY began to get his songs. LY says they came naturally, in 1934 or 19 35. He wanted to see and hear Coleman Hawkins. He talks about the Count Basie Band. He talks about Fletcher Henderson wife, who played trumpet.
