did.unittitle:
Big Horn Jazz Festival: Soprano Summit, first set, May 30, 1976 (Side 1), Bud Freeman and Vic Dickenson, May 27, 1974 (Side 2),
May 27, 1974
,
May 30, 1976
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (graphite-backed polyester Side 1: 01:37:08, Side 2: 01:37:11) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, quarter track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: See
SR213
for performances from the 1975 festival.
LC engineer's note: The tape side were recorded out of relative phase. This was corrected in the transfer.

Logger's note: Performers include Marty Grosz on guitar, [unintelligible name on the recording] on drums, Milt Hinton on bass, Kenny Davern on clarinet, and Bob Wilber on clarinet. This audio log includes some of the band members' banter with each other in between songs, and jokes they make about Marty Grosz.

row.entry: Sydney Bechet's "Swing Parade" begins to play. Song from Soprano Summit's first album.

Bob Wilber announces the musicians and which instruments they are playing. He announces that next they will play an original song from their upcoming Chiaroscuro album called, "Grenadilla Stomp." He explains that his clarinet is made from grenadilla wood, and jokes that Kenny Davern's clarinet is made of hard rubber. The audience laughs. He says, "Everyone to their own tastes." You can hear Davern in the background say, "I'll get you for that, Wilber."
Bob Wilber (presumably) announces next song - "Black and Tan Fantasy" by Duke Ellington

Bob Wilber [presumably] says, "The reason we stand up after each number is not to acknowledge your applause as so much as to air off certain areas of the body which happen to be sticking to the seat due to incredible humidity here in Chicago." Someone from the audience asks when Marty will sing. Wilber responds, "Marty sings soon. He has a couple of numbers where we turn him loose."
Bob Wilber [presumably] says that the next piece called "Song of Songs" is probably the most requested piece they have in their library.
Song ends and Wilber says, "And now we'd like to present our lovely vocalist, Chicago's own, Marty Grosz ... otherwise known as 'send in the clowns.'"
Wilber announces that the next song is one from Thomas Fats Waller called "How Can You Face Me Now?" sung by Marty Grosz. Song begins to play.
Wilber announces that they will be playing "Milneburg Joys" next. He makes some jokes about the song and their concerts.
Wilber announces the name of the drummer again - Freddie Stohl. He also goes through the names and musicians in the band again.
Wilber announces the next song is "Chalumeau Blue" (as well as the title of their next album). "Chalumeau Blue" begins to play.
Wilber says, "Now it's time once again ladies and gentlemen for our lovely vocalist, Miss Grosz ... wending her way to the bandstand into the hearts of hundreds."
"A Porter's Love Song to His Chambermaid"
"I Wish That I Were Twins" begins to play. (Before they start to play this song, Marty Grosz [I think] tells a joke story about how Paul Newman is his famous movie star twin.)
"Meet Me Tonight in Dreamland" [tapes were changed at about this point in the recording]
Announces that they are going to do a song that they don't have an arrangement of - they just sort of do it off the tops of their heads, but the recording cuts out.
"Deed I Do" begins. People talk and laugh throughout the track.
"Things Ain't What They Used to Be" begins. People talk and laugh throughout the track.
Some unintelligible talking. Sounds like the recording got cut off.
Someone announces that they will play a song composed by Bud Freeman - "The D-Minor Thing."
"I Can't Believe That You're in Love With Me"
Someone announces that Vic Dickenson has a request to do "In A Sentimental Mood."
Someone announces, "This piece is in reverence to The Duke, who is buried today and we [unintelligible] would like to give something to Duke."

did.unittitle: Sub-subseries 4: Drum Talk Coast To Coast

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (acetate; Side 1: 00:41:14, Side 2: 00:16:35) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, quarter track, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p:
Archivist's note: In 1964
Down Beat
magazine held three discussions with drummers, at three locations. This recordings seems to be the third discussion, held in
Down Beat
's Chicago office. Elvin Jones and Joe Morello are interviewed by Don (no last name given). The event was covered in the magazine's March 26, 1964 issue.

LC engineer's note: This file contains audio from the left track of the tape, which was in reverse (highly unusual). This was corrected in both preservation and access files. This suggests the tape was recorded in the half-track mono format and later altered on a quarter-track stereo machine. The audio is almost completely inaudible from 00:24:50 to the end of the file but there is audio. It sounds like poor erasure.

row.entry: The interviewer asks about a what a young drummer: what studies should he seek and should he study another instrument. The drummers reply.
[office noise, including a typewriter, and contruction noise, including hammering, makes the interview even more difficult to understand.]
One of the drummers says that it would be good for the young drummer to study mathematics.
The interviewer asks: "What is the most important thing for a drummer to know or for a drummer to do? The drummers reply.
The interviewer asks: "How much do you practice and how?" The drummers reply.
Blank until the end of recording.
The interviewer asks: "Some drummers swing and some drummers don't. What is swinging and what is not swinging?"
Discussion of various time signatures, like 3/4, 4/4, 5/4 etc.
Discussion of other rhythms, such as African and Indian.
The interviewer asks. "How does big band experience help a drummer?" The drummers respond.
Wrapping up the interview with social talk.

odd.p: LC engineer's note: The tape appears to have been initially recorded on a quarter-track stereo machine at 3.75 ips on one side only and later reused on a half track mono machine recorded on both sides and running at 7.5 ips. This file is Side 1 of the half-track format recording on the tape.

odd.p: Side 1 (right channel in the quarter-track stereo format; 01:35:42)

LC engineer's note: The tape appears to have been initially recorded on a quarter track stereo machine at 3.75 ips on one side only and later reused on a half-track mono machine recorded on both sides and running at 7.5 ips. The audio in this file corresponds to what would be the right channel of Side 1 in the quarter track stereo format. Because of the incomplete erasure, one can hear backwards audio of what would be Side Two of the half-track mono rerecording bleeding over the audio as the file progresses. This makes the file very hard to listen to, but it was transferred for completeness sake, as well as historical interest as the audio is an air check of Boston radio stations WBCN-FM for the first 3:45, then WJIB-FM when it was a beautiful music station.

did.unittitle:
Air check from WBAI-FM, New York, during a pledge drive,
June 1977
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester; Side 1: 01:00:50, Side 2: 00:58:00) : analog, 3 3/4 ips, quarter track, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: Undated aircheck from WBAI-FM, New York during a pledge drive. The presence of the Bob Marley tune "So Much Things to Say" on the tape mentioned as being a brand new release (June 3, 1977) places the aircheck from early June 1977.

odd.p: Logger's note: The first part of the recording is Brazilian music. The second part has reggae music.

row.entry: An unidentified woman DJ, called only Mildred, introduces a song written by the Brazilian composer Benito Repala, "Charlie Brown."
The DJ introduces a second song by Benito Repala, "Maria Baina Maria."
An unidentified man makes a pitch for donations to the radio station.
The DJ introduces a song by Vondoo, "Mega Obaluway [Obaluaye?]."
An unidentified man makes a pitch for donations to the radio station. The DJ introduces a song by Marcus Vanesius [?], "Et cetera and Other Things."
An unidentified man, and the DJ, make a pitch for donations to the radio station.
The DJ asks for pledges. She announces a Brazilian band playing in Soho. The unidentified man asks for pledges.
Start of reggae portion of the sound recording.
"So Much Things to Say" - Bob Marley and the Wailers

Roger Chilling, the DJ, introduces the Reggae program. An unidentified song plays in the background. He discusses the original makeup of the Wailers, the breakup of that group, and the formation of Bob Marley, Peter Tosh and Bunny Wailer.
"Get Up, Stand Up" by Tosh and Marley
"Downpresser Man" - from a new album by Peter Tosh
Chilling talks about reggae, Buddhism and the Bible. He talks about the Wailers.

Chilling introduces the nest two songs from the Bunny Wailer album
Blackheart Man
.

odd.p: Logger's note: The DJ is Mildred Norman. All of the music is Brazilian.

row.entry: The announcer introduces WBAI 99.5 FM in New York City. He says that coming up is Mildred Norman (MN).
MN introduces the song playing in the background. It is a carnival samba "Tanyo Tanyo" She introduces the next song. It is a samba, but not a carnival samba.
MN talks about Brazilian composers recoding their own songs. She plays 'Musai Abruzzo" again.
MN introduces the next song, a samba, "Apesar de Voce" by Chico Buarque. She says that when the song came out there a problem with censorship.
MN introduces the next song, "Mas Que Nada" [More than Anything] by Jorge Ben.
"Africa Brazil" by Jorge Ben, from the album of the same name.
"Chico do Silva" [Xica da Silva] by Jorge Ben, from the "Africa Brazil."
MN tells a story about Jorge Ben. She then asks for donations to the radio station.
MN talks about Milton Nascimento. She introduces the next song which Nascimento recorded with Wayne shorter on the "Native Dancer" album. The song is "Ponta de Areia."
The same song, "Ponta de Areia." This version was recorded in Brazil.
A third version of "Ponta de Areia."
MN discusses the two previous songs. She asks for donations to the radio station.
MN gives the correct information about the previous song.
"Canta Canta Minha Gente" a samba by Martinho da Vila.
"Disritmia" [rhythm that is not rhythm] by Martinho da Vila.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel : analog, 7 1/2 ips, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Collector's original ID number: 226.

Logger's note: Notes on the tape box indicate the following: Band 1 - introduction. Play Side A of enclosed LP. Band 2 - Play at conclusion of Side A (Starting identification, etc.). Band 3 - Introduction to part 2 of show. Play side B of enclosed LP. Band 4 - Conclusion.
Archivist's note 1: Pete Welding's radio show "Blue Monday Blues" was a one-hour show on WXFM, Chicago, Illinois. The show featured blues recordings as well as live interviews and performances.
Archivist's note 2: Pete Welding may have made this tape to reflect introductions to the LP, and not recorded the LP itself.

row.entry: An unidentified man speaks: "And I walked right in and I sat right down...and I put the ticket in the brim of my hat, the wind blew it on the ground..."
An unidentified fragment piece of instrumental music performed by the banjo and the harmonica.
An unidentified man speaks: "Had no chicken and she has an wooden leg. That old hen can really lay an egg..."

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:27:54) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times, and there is significant hum.
Logger's note: Johnny Young is the featured guest.

row.entry: PW made an introduction: Tonight's program is an extensive interview and excerpts of Johnny Young, one of the finest guitarists, singers and mandolinists in the modern blues in Chicago.
"Keep Your Nose Out of My Business" by Johnny Young and his band
PW asks: How do you got started with playing mandolin?

JY answers that he was born on Vicksburg, Mississippi. In his childhood, he was influenced by his uncle who was a musician. At around nine years old, he was experimenting making a mandolin out of a cigar box.
JY mentions his uncle would play with his band members in the suburbs.
An unidentified blues song. Lyrics: "I am leaving, Baby I ain't gonna be around no more..."

JY mentions that the band plays more blues than waltz around 1926. He then talks about playing on his home-made mandolin about a year before he plays on a real one. He particularly remembers the songs played by the group "Mississippi Sheiks" in Rolling Fork, Mississippi. JY mostly plays songs composed by other people. He also talks about the musician Walter Vincent who plays country blues with the group.
JY talks about the musician Charlie [inaudible] who plays instruments like a clown.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:33:04) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: Johnny Young is the featured guest.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage.

PW: The interview with Johnny Young, guitarist, singer, and mandolinist, continues. The first part of the show is about his Mississippi years. The second half is about his life in Chicago. Johnny Young (JY) mentions that he moved back from Chicago to Vicksburg, Mississippi, at the age of 21, in 1941 when the war began. While he stayed in Chicago Heights area, he met many musicians such as Big Bill, who played electric guitar. In those years, JY and Muddy used to follow Sonny Boy around. JY mentions that Muddy played the blues with his trademark bottle-neck style. Later JY played in the Maxwell Street market in 1946, along with Moody Jones and Snooky Pryor. After playing on the street for some time, finally JY recorded a record under his name.
"Money Taking Woman" composed and performed by Johnny Young, on the Ora Nelle label
PW asks about JY's cousin, Johnny Williams, who was featured on the same record. JY says they started playing at the age 10.
"Worried Man Blues" composed and performed by Johnny Williams.

PW asks about JY's other record after 1948: "Let Me Ride Your Mule" and "My Baby Walked Out On Me." After that JY stopped making records until he met Pete Welding, who produced
Modern Chicago Blues.
The record features one of JY's songs "My Baby Walked Out In 1954."
PW asks about JY's collaboration with the harmonica player John Wrencher.
"I'm Going to Detroit," guitar by John Lee Granderson, mandolin by Johnny Young, vocals and harmonica by John Wrencher.

PW ask about JY's recent participation in several recording sessions for various labels. One of them is a Vanguard label record
Chicago/The Blues/Today!
, in which Samuel Charters asked nine different blues artists to record songs. JY mentions that Samuel Charters loved his performance.
"Tighten Up on It" by Johnny Young's South Side Blues Band
JY talks about his recording for Arhoolie Records.
"Wild, Wild Woman" by Johnny Young and his Chicago Blues Band

PW ask JY what he thinks the blues are. JY answers blues are songs of low down when people feel low down way back from the slavery time. Blues are something that would hit you, make you sorrow, and make you think of things.
PW made a closing remark for the program.
"I'm Having A Ball" by Johnny Young and his Chicago Blues Band.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:28:56) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage.
"Red Headed Woman" by "Baby Face" Leroy Foster. Performers: Leroy Foster, vocal and guitar; Muddy Water, lead guitar; Harmonica solo by Little Walter.
PW presents another song from the same record as above - "Moonshine Baby" by "Baby Face" Leroy Foster. Performers: Muddy Waters, lead guitar; Leroy Foster, 2nd guitar.

PW mentions Muddy Waters' recorded several novelty blues such as "Tiger in Your Tank" and "Got My Mojo Working." The following selection doesn't go farther, which features a superb chromatic harmonica solo by Little Walter.
"Don't Go No Farther" by Muddy Waters.
PW introduces another blues artist from Chicago, Kokomo Arnold.
PW mentions that Georgia Tom (Thomas A. Dorsey) is a noted gospel song performer, and introduces his "Levee Bound Blues" on a 1930 Decca label.
"Levee Bound Blues" by Thomas A. Dorsey
PW introduces a post-war recording by Jesse Thomas: "Gonna Write You A Letter" (1949).
"Gonna Write You A Letter" by Jesse Thomas (vocal, guitar)
PW talks about a later Mississippi blues singer and guitarist: Johnny Temple, who is well known for the song "Louise Louise Blues."
PW introduces "Traveling Man Blues": very fine vocal and guitar playing by Tony Hollins, recorded in Chicago in 1941.
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:30:54) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.
Logger's note: This show features discussion of the development of the blues style in Chicago.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. In this episode he will introduces several blues works developed out of the Muddy Waters' band.
PW introduces the song "Last Night I Lost The Best Friend" by Little Walter, which features a magnificent harmonica solo.
"Last Night I Lost The Best Friend" by Little Walter

PW talks about Little Walter successful recordings that features his fine harmonica performance. The blues song "Off The Wall" was included in one of his best records called
The Best of Little Walter.

PW introduces another harmonica player Walter Horton, known as Big Walter (Horton) or Walter "Shakey" Horton. He was a very fine harmonica player from the Memphis, Tennessee are. He succeeded Little Walter in the Muddy Water's band.
"Hard Hearted Woman" by Big Walter Horton

PW talks about harmonica player Junior Wells, who recorded a beautiful blues song "Hoodoo Man Blues" with Junior Wells on vocal, Big Walter on guitar, David Miles on 2nd guitar, Henry Gray on piano, and Fred Below on drums.
PW introduces a great harmonica piece performed by Junior Wells.
An unidentified instrumental harmonica piece by Junior Wells.
PW mentions about another great blues artist in Chicago, though born in Mississippi - Johnny Shines.
PW introduces a blues piece composed by Johnny Shines - "Brutal Hearted Woman," featured Johnny Shines and Big Walter's magnificent performance on the harmonica.
PW introduces a final selection by Johnny Shines, also featuring Big Walter's harmonica playing.
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:27:31) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.
Logger's note: This show features discussion of the development of the blues style in Chicago.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. PW: The evolution of the modern blues style can be suggested by comparison of three Muddy Water's recordings from different periods of his recording career. This number - "Walking Blues" - is from his early onset of his recording activities.
"Walking Blues" by Muddy Waters, accompanied by the bassist Big Crawford.
PW introduces the mature style of Muddy Waters - an exciting ensemble style in which all the instruments were amplified.
PW talks about Muddy Water's later development of blues. "Walkin' Through the Park" has a brisk exciting momentum of the rhythm that is much more important than the lyric content of the song.

PW mentions that the leaders of the new blues style came from the Muddy Water's bands such as "Baby Face" Leroy Foster. Foster's "Boll Weevil" dealt with country theme, with which the audience was familiar.
PW talks about Little Walter Jacobs, a harmonica player, started from Muddy Water's band and set out on his own.
"Muskadine Blues" by Little Walter Jacobs, accompanied by Muddy Walter on guitar
PW talks about how in early 1950 Little Walter Jacobs formed his own band and recorded a few records.
"Blues with a Feeling" by Little Walter Jacobs
PW: The biggest success of Little Walter Jacobs is the remake an old spiritual which was called "This Train." Little Walter gave it a more secular lyrics and called his version "My Babe."

PW: Little Walter Jacobs is best known in the modern blues for his brilliant playing on the amplifier harmonica. Perhaps one of his finest harmonica solo is the instrumental song "Juke" from "The Best of Little Walter" album.
PW makes a closing remark of the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:29:46) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.
Logger's note: This show features discussion of the development of the blues style in Chicago.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. PW: The modern style of blues was developed in a small Chicago club in the year following World War II. But to understand the genesis of the style, one must go back to 1941. McKinley Morganfield [Leadbelly] was recorded on Stovall plantation near Rolling Fork, Mississippi, by a mobile recording team from the Library of Congress, led by Alan Lomax.

PW: "Country Blues" is country style performance of old Mississippi Delta style, and was patented on an album called
The Walking Blues,
recorded by a Delta bluesman, Robert Johnson, a gifted poet and musician of blues.
PW compares the modern urban style of blues and the original southern style.
"I Can't Be Satisfied" by Muddy Waters.
PW talks about a new form begins to emerge, in which the 2nd guitar line of Little Walter Jacobs was added to Muddy's lead guitar and Big Crawford's bass.
PW discusses Sonny Boy Williamson's influence on Little Walter for his harmonica solo voice style.
"Louisiana Blues," harmonica by Little Walter, lead guitar by Muddy Waters, and bass by Big Crawford

PW presents an example that represents the sound of the modern blues. In the band numbers, the roles of the instruments - guitar, second guitar, harmonica, piano, bass and drums, have been simplified individually so the totality of produced would be strong and brilliant as a whole. The electronic sound of the instruments further demands its simplification.
"I Just Want To Make Love To You" by Muddy Waters
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:28:35) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. PW: Today's program will focus on Rice Miller (Sonny Boy Williamson II), an influential post-war artist. Here is one of his early influential songs, "Nine Below Zero," recorded in 1950.
"Nine Below Zero" by Rice Miller (Sonny Boy Williamson II)

PW: Considerable confusion exists about Rice Miller. He claimed to be the original "Sonny Boy Williamson." This is to distinguish him from the performer John Lee Williamson, who recorded extensively in the late 30s and 40s as Sonny Boy Williamson. Here is a moody and introspective performance recorded in Rice Miller's early years.
"Mighty Long Time" by Rice Miller (Sonny Boy Williamson II), guitar and harmonica
PW mentions that Sonny Boy Williamson II is such a unique performer and quotes a description of style written by a British Blues critic Paul Oliver.
"Eyesight to the Blind" by Sonny Boy Williamson II
PW talks about Sonny Boy Williamson II's excellent ability as a blues poet.
"Don't Start Me to Talkin'" by Sonny Boy Williamson II
PW introduce another Sonny Boy Williamson II's song notable for the lyric content.
"Fattening Frogs for Snakes" - Sonny Boy Williamson II
PW: This next piece has a good rocking background. It is very much in the modern style of instrumental work developed in the Chicago area in the post-war years.
"Checkin' Up On My Baby" by Sonny Boy Williamson II
PW introduces one of his most sensitive performances.
"Sad To Be Alone" by Sonny Boy Williamson II
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:29:41) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.
Logger's note: This show features discussion of the development of the blues style in Chicago.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. PW: This evening we will focus on the recorded music of Elmore James and his cousin Homesick James Williamson.
"Dust My Broom" by Elmore James; Sonny Boy Williamson II on harmonica.

PW: In "Sunnyland," Elmore James's electric guitar is more of a Chicago style, a more modern approach. The riff pattern and very heavy, explicit rhythm are much more in keeping with the Chicago modern styles of blues that became quite prevalent in the middle 50s.
PW: In "Blues Before Sunrise," the guitar accompaniment pattern on this number is almost exclusively on Robert Johnson.
PW: Now another number by Elmore James, in the more modern style of the Chicago blues. The guitar playing is much more in line with the jazz approaches.
"I Was A Fool" by Elmore James

PW: Tonight's final selection is Elmore's remake of Robert Johnson's "Standing At The Crossroads." Several horns have been added to the rhythm section. The band picks up the phrases following Elmore's guitar, echoing in a call and response pattern. This format becomes the trademarks of Elmore's blues in the 50s.
PW: Let's hear Robert Johnson's original "Crossroad Blues" recorded in November 1936. We will see how much Elmore got from it, and how much he parted from it.
PW: Homesick James Williamson was also a man who was influenced by Robert Johnson and his powerful music. We hear a recording titled "Homesick" made by Homesick James in 1952.
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:33:23) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.
Logger's note: This show features discussion of the development of the blues style in Chicago.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. Tonight's program continues the discussion of the modern blues style with selections by Chester Arthur Burnett, better known by his stage name Howlin' Wolf. This selection, "Crying At Daylight," is notable as much for his powerful singing as it is for his interesting harmonica playing.
PW: This next number is influenced more by jazz guitar. It is much more in line with the kind of blues that were being recorded during the mid-40s and right after the war years.
PW: In early 1950 Howlin' Wolf left Memphis and moved to Chicago. Here is a segment of his recording before the move.
"House Rockin' Boogie" by Howlin' Wolf, with comments by Howlin' Wolf
PW: Before moving to Chicago in 1952, Howlin' Wolf recorded a few numbers in Memphis. Here is one example.
PW: Wolf continues to record a number of traditional tunes, one of most interesting is "Forty Four," recorded after he moved to Chicago.

PW: Howlin' Wolf's singing of "Forty Four" was very similar to Charley Patton, the great Delta Mississippi blues man. The phrasing is remarkably alike. The next number is recorded in Howlin' Wolf's Chicago era.
PW: Now we hear another example of Howlin' Wolf's use of traditional Mississippi materials and modern blues context. "Spoonful" was originally recorded by Charley Patton.

PW: "Spoonful" by Howlin' Wolf was recorded in 1960. Since that time Wolf's music has gone to a decline as he is concentrated on the performance of rather cheap material that have been manufactured for him by professional blues writers. However Howlin' Wolf was still one of the most powerful and strongest of all Chicago blues man.
"Three Hundred Pounds of Joy" by Howlin' Wolf
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:29:26) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Vendor's digitization note: The program is distored at times and has significant hum.
Logger's note: This show features discussion of the development of the blues style in Chicago.

row.entry: Pete Welding (PW) makes an opening remark and advertises the Big John's club in Old Town Chicago where featured bands perform live on the stage. Tonight's program will be about a few numbers about 78's music from PW's collection. Junior Wells achieved a great deal of success, commercially and artistically, after leaving the Muddy Water's band.
"'Bout The Break Of Day" by Junior Wells

PW: We will hear artists who achieved great fame before the pre-war years, but who happened to record after World War II. Their style changed in order to accommodate the prevalent Chicago sound. The first selection is music by Walter Davis, who is an expressive singer and pianist.

PW: Another artist who tried to make the switch from the pre-war style to the modern post-war style was Big Bill Broonzy. He was a prolific recording artist, and was identified as the "Chicago sound" before World War II.
PW: Now, another artist who scored success in the pre-war years, Hudson Whittaker (Tampa Red), a very fine singer and guitarist. He also recorded a few successful numbers in the post-war years.
"But I Forgive You" by Tampa Red, with vocalist and pianist Johnny Jones
PW: The final pre-war artist we hear with post-war transformation is Roosevelt Sykes from Louisiana. He is artistically the most successful of the four artists we hear this evening.

PW: Now we will hear one of the best zydeco players, Clifton Chenier, a singer and accordionist. Zydeco is a combination of French music and Negro blues, and it's associated with the Gulf coast region around Louisiana and Texas.
"Where Can My Baby Be" by Clifton Chenier
PW: Andrew "Smokey" Hogg is one of the finest of the Texas bluesman.
PW makes a closing remark for the program.

did.unittitle:
"Preachin' The Blues" - radio show on KPFK-FM, Los Angeles; hosted by Frank Scott - Johnny Shines, guest,
January 5, 1974
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:52:24) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, half track, stereo ; 7 in.

odd.p: Archivist's note: The interview was featured on Frank Scott's show, "Preachin' the Blues," broadcast on KPFK radio. The tape box indicates this is interview #3, but this is probably Shines interview number 3 in this collection. The interview is interspersed with songs sung by Johnny Shines, accompanying himself on guitar.

row.entry: recording begins with laughter; discussion about blues and church songs; his family history and a story about Ann Roman [sp?]

how Shines came to Chicago: his life in Arkansas, his work as a farm hand, performing as a musician on weekends, Howlin' Wolf, trying to live and work in St. Louis, plans to go to Chicago and get a job and what he'd do if he didn't get a job, desire to visit Africa, being told that people in Africa have his Vanguard record and want him to visit, his strong feelings about going to Africa, speaks about slide guitar playing

the interview continues: discussion of Shines's slide guitar style, credits his return to the music business to Frank Scott and Mike Rowe, Shines pawned his guitar and equipment and sore off playing guitar again, Scott and Rowe renting a guitar for him; Scott and Shines discuss photos Scott shows to him, reasons he gave up playing guitar, playing jazz instead of blues, taking care of his children and grandchildren, the need to have a living income, dealings with record companies, dealings with Al Benson, trouble with the union (playing for under scale), losing his union card, issues resolved, leaving Chicago to live in Alabama

the interview continues: how Shines changes traditional songs and keeps his interest in the music, playing gigs in the Los Angeles area, mention of Big Mama Thornton and T-Bone Walker, forthcoming albums by Shines, playing solo vs. with a band, songs he learned from Robert Johnson, Johnson's personality, when other people play Johnson's songs
"Kind Hearted Woman" (a song by Robert Johnson)
where Shines will play next (locations and events), taking his family around the U.S. and Canada to see other places
Scott thanks Shines for taking the time to do the interview, plugs the gig Shines had currently with Albert Collins at The Ash Grove.

Lyrics: "You're the cutest thing in my life that I've ever witnessed to/when the woman I love [?] out there too/I told her to take it easy baby"

Lyrics: "I know a gal, her name is Betty Hobbs [?]/make good money on all her jobs/just cutting them clothes/she never did hurry, she just kept on cutting them clothes/day in and day out, she didn't want for a thing, she didn't use nothing but an easy swing"
Lyrics: "Early one morning when the possum left his den/[?] my baby came creeping in/[record skips here] mama tell me what's the matter now"
Lyrics: "I ain't nothing but a hobo, won't somebody help me carry my load/...I have been in the jungle three long nights and days"

Lyrics: "Ain't it a shame, ain't it a shame, low down dirty shame/my baby wrote for me [?] won't let me ride this train/goodbye old Memphis, goodbye to the state of Tennessee/I'm going home to my baby"

row.entry: "New Two Sixteen Blues" - Little Hat Jones; Okeh 8712 (Lyrics: "I got a woman in Dallas, got one is San Antone too/I figure this one in San Antone don't know what this poor girl in Dallas gonna do/she's got nine good teeth people, all that wavy hair")

"Two String Blues" - Little Hat Jones; Okeh 8712 (Lyrics: "I said listen baby, honey, I can't move no more/all these blues crawl up my window and travel up underneath my door/some women weep like a willow and some mourn just like a dove")
"Hurry Blues" - Little Hat Jones; Okeh 8735 (Lyrics: "I know this eagle's on the dollar, other side in God We Trust/Well, a woman loves a man, but I know this dollar's first")
"Corpus Blues" - Little Hat Jones; Okeh 8735 (Lyrics: "I remember one time people it was in nineteen and twenty-four/something that happened that year that I never want to see no more")

"Penitentiary Moan Blues" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8640 (Lyrics: "Mama, she told me to stay at home and I wouldn't/you told me to stay at home and I said I couldn't/but now mama, Bud Russell has got me and lord have mercy/if I had a listen, mama, when you was telling me these things I wouldn't have to worry with these old rusty chains")
"Blue Devil Blues" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8640 (Lyrics: "I heard a mumbling deep down in the ground/said it must been the devil turning them women around")

"Double Crossing Blues" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8745 (Lyrics: "Some men like dogging, I just declare I don't/baby if you think I'm going to stand you mistreating me I declare I won't/there is something about foolishness, they even try to settle down")
"Some Day Baby You Troubles Is Gonna Be Like Mine" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8771 (Lyrics: "Someday woman your troubles gonna be like mine/I'm gonna to break your heart just like you broke mine")
"Awful Moaning Blues, Part 1" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8731 (Lyrics: "I've been moaning, moaning ever since you've been gone/but I find a new of moaning to bring my woman back home")

"Awful Moaning Blues, Part 2" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8731 (Lyrics: "I've been moaning woman, ever since you've been gone/since I went back home and looked up on the shelf/since I'm getting mighty tired sleeping by myself")

"Johnny Behren's Blues" - Texas Alexander; Okeh 8745 (Lyrics: "When I was a sailor sailing on the deep blue sea/said I learned all the women man them ocean ways/I learned the way that every woman craves/said there must be a new way that really won't behave")

"Hambone Willie's Dreamy-Eyed Woman's Blues" - Hambone Willie Newbern; Okeh 8693 (Lyrics: "I got a dreamy-eyed woman live down on Cherry Street/and she laughs and talks with every brown-skin old man she meet/says I told her last night and all the night before/said, "If you don't quit so much runnin', baby, you can't be mine no more")

"Stomp Down Rider" - Georgia Bill; Okeh 8936 (Lyrics: "When I first met you mama you was so nice and kind/you done got reckless and changed your mind/now you stomp down rider, now you stomp rider/now you stomp down rider, but you're 'most too drunk for me")

"Devil Blues" - Sylvester Weaver; Okeh 8534 (Lyrics: "I had a dream while sleeping found myself way down below, my Lord/couldn't get to heaven, hell's the place I had to go/devil had me cornered, stuck with his old pitchfork/devil had me cornered, stuck me with his old pitchfork/and he put me in an oven, thought he had me for roast pork")

"Black Spider Blues" - Sylvester Weaver; Okeh 8534 (Lyrics: "Saw a big black spider creeping up my bedroom wall/finds out he was only going to get his ashes hauled/say if that black spider bit you it would be too bad Jim/give your heart to the devil and your hips would belong to him")

"Rough Alley Blues" - Mary Willis (vocal) and Blind Willie McTell (vocal and guitar); Okeh 8921, Magnolia 502 (Lyrics: "Pull down your window and let all your blinds/so your next door neighbor baby won't hear your best friend cry/take it low down an easy, don't let you best friend [inaudible]/so the next door neighbor doesn't hear you grieve and groan")

"Low Down Blues" - Mary Willis (vocal), Blind Willie McTell (guitar), Curley Weaver (second guitar); Okeh 8921, Magnolia 502 (Lyrics: "I ain't gonna be your low down dog no more/I've been your dog [inaudible] since I've been in Georgia/I've been your dog ever since I've been your gal/I ain't gonna be your dog just to be your pal")

"Heart Is Right Blues" - Snitcher Roberts; Okeh 8781 (Lyrics: "Blues and trouble seem to be my best friend/when my blues leaves me then my troubles begin/I'm down and out and can't nobody find me/nobody in town baby got more blues than me")

unidentified (Lyrics: "Oh you talk about your shuffle, talk about your [?], you got a new dance they call the Georgia skornch [?]/now they're skornchin'/now it's a brand new dance and it's sure is all right with me/now the way they shake it just won't do/young folks do it and the old ones too")

unidentified (Lyrics: "Oh these old blues [inaudible]/[?] oh sweet mama, what a fool I've been/trying to love a woman and she's got four other men/oh what a fool I've been/if you take me back sweet mama I'll never take back sweet mama I'll act a fool again")
unidentified (Lyrics: "Hula, hula [inaudible]/hula, hula, hula, hula/yes sir, I'm [inaudible] an old man crazy about young gals, [inaudible] oldest son, that made me be crazy too"
unidentified (Lyrics: "I got a gal, nice and mean/meanest gal I've ever have seen/she ain't good looking but she [inaudible]/ah baby don't pick on me")

unidentified (Lyrics: "You got a good woman, treat her right today/don't wait til tomorrow she may be gone away/don't put off til tomorrow things you can do today/you'll look for your sweet mama she'll be a thousand miles away")
unidentified (Lyrics: "Moaning in the morning, moaning all through the night/when you hear me moaning you know things ain't going right/now you can't sleep at nighttime, you can't stay awake at day")

row.entry: Charlie the Collector (CC) announces that the talk will focus the prominent small groups and how they adapt to this jazz music forms to their musical portfolios.

CC introduces Lionel Hampton, a talented pianist/vibraphone player/drummer, who started his career with Benny Goodman in 1936, then started his own band 1940. He played and recorded albums with King Cole Trio and drummer Al Spieldock. In the recording of "Central Avenue Breakdown," Nat King Cole does all bass piano work, while Hampton develops his two-finger piano style with gusto.
An unidentified instrumental piece of boogie woogie.[Very likely performed by Lionel Hampton.]

CC talks about Count Basie: Although he did not really need it, Count Basie is another talented pop musician who lets the popularity of boogie woogie help vault him to fame. Probably because of the most relaxed style of jazz pianists, it is often said that "he was famous for the notes that he did not play." In 1938-39, he recorded, in Decca label, only the rhythm sections of the big band music. In its entirety, it is a showcase of his early relaxed piano style. This song "Oh! Red" is from this series.

CC talks: Louis Jordan, alto sax player, was a byproduct of the Chick Webb orchestra. In 1938, He left the orchestra to form a group later known as the Tympany Five. Louis Jordan, a very talented showman and musician, completely dominated the group with either his saxophone or vocalizing. His trademark is a shuffle rhythm based on boogie woogie. Probably sensing the overexposure of boogie woogie, he recorded this song "Boogie-Woogie Came to Town" in 1941 in lieu of Will Bradley's great success of this form.

CC talks about Erskine Butterfield, pianist, was from Syracuse New York. He hit it up with various groups in very early of 40s and faded from playing the boogie woogie after WW2. He died in New York in 1961, but left an interesting legacy of boogie woogie, featuring his piano work, and many vocals. His style, like Count Basie, is relaxed and easy-going. In going over his list of recordings, it almost seemed as if he is obsessed with food, starting with his own name (Butterfield) to his more outstanding recordings he called "Salt Butter," "Chocolate," and "Blackberry Jam." Let's hear this last one in 1941, Erskine and His Blue Boys, playing "Blackberry Jam."

CC talks: There is Mary Lou Williams again sitting at her piano. Last time she played with Andy Kirk. This time she is accompanying singer, Mildred Bailey, as a rhythm group called Mildred Bailey and Her Oxford Greys. Here is a good example of a song done in a boogie woogie van, where the vocalist is dominant, Mary Lou William's piano mainly serves as a backup. Mildred Bailey is telling us a dim lighted tavern in Birmingham, where laughing water coming out from a strange fountain. She calls this "Barrel House Music"

CC talks: Wingy Manone, trumpeter and vocalist, was another jazz artist and showman. When he lost his arm in a street car accident in New Orleans when he was only 8 years old, back in 1922, learned to play the trumpet with his left hand. In his 30s and 40s, he was a prolific recording artist, recording with people like Teddy Wilson, Jelly Roll Morton, Artie Shaw, Bob Crosby and others. 1941, Wingy finally decided he better capture the growing boogie woogie market and recorded "The Boogie Beat'll Getcha."

CC talks: One of my favorite pieces is Harry James's fast pace boogie woogie he did in 1939. Albert Ammons was doing the piano work. What an interesting interplay of early blue playing of James, and piano virtuosity of Ammons. A tremendous combination. And this is called "Woo-Woo."
Charlie the Collector ends the show.
An unidentified person announces there are more talks about Big Band Boogie-Woogie Anthology.
The start of another episode of talk with Charlie the Collector on boogie woogie.

CC talks: This is program #6 in the series on boogie woogie. After 1942, boogie woogie started its decline, primarily due to the overexposure and devastation of WW2. However its demise was not sudden nor complete, it was just begin to fade and change nature. There were still many excellent boogie woogie performances into the 60s primarily by the old-timers who managed to survive that long. This time we are going to explore piano boogie woogie made after 1942, by some of the more famous pianists, some of whom have been around since the 20s. First on our list is a 256-pound pianist, Big Maceo Merriweather, whose recording career was all too short. His most outstanding recording is probably the one in 1945: "Chicago Breakdown." The piece was praised by a jazz critic as one of the best boogie woogie piano solos in the complete history of jazz.
"Chicago Breakdown" played by Big Maceo Merriweather

CC talks: Little Brother Montgomery, a blue singer and pianist from Louisiana, persisted in playing the original form of the blues. Not primarily a player of boogie woogie, but he did do it and the results are excellent and original. Here is an example of his uniquely idea of the boogie woogie, a recording he did with drummer Frank "Sweet" Williams, in 1951, called "Shreveport Farewell."
"Shreveport Farewell" played by Little Brother Montgomery and Frank "Sweet" Williams.

CC talks: In the mid 40s, a young pianist, Harry "The Hipster" Gibson, used to play in various clubs in New York on 52nd street. Praised by jazz critics in 1944 as a jazz sensation, he quickly faded in obscurity by 1957. He was talented and left a legacy of piano virtuosity. Let's hear this piece recorded on the Musicraft label in 1944, which presents some good right hand work: "Barrelhouse Boogie" with John Simmons (bass) and Sid Catlett (drums).
"Barrelhouse Boogie" played by Harry "The Hipster" Gibson with John Simmons (bass) and Sid Catlett (drums).

CC talks: One of the most outstanding piano boogie woogie piano number is a piece recorded by Cow Davenport in 1927, which rises with "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" recorded a year later but never received the wide spread fame. Davenport called it "Cow Cow Blues," but not to be confused with Cow Cow Boogie Woogie. The best rendition of Cow Cow Blues is the one played in 1961 by "Memphis Slim" Peter Chapman who is the most authentic blue artist of his generation. Since this piece was recorded in 1961, it was done with new hi-fi technology.
Memphis Slim Peter Chatman dedicated his playing of "Cow Cow Blues" to Cow Cow Davenport.

CC talks: Now a boogie woogie in the low register. The recording is done by "Cripple" Clarence Lofton in 1943. Lofton is another old-timer, born in Tennessee in 1896, recorded on the old Paramount labels as early as 1930, died in 1956. He spent his productive years in Chicago and his unusual style influence many young pianists. He called this one "Southend Boogie," an obvious reference to the fact that his left hand was about as far left as he could get on the 88 keyboard.

CC talks: Russia also made a valuable contribution to the American jazz world. pianist Art Hodes, whose family moved to Chicago in 1905. Hodes was always a crusader for traditional jazz, and played a simple blues style. His style was highly influenced by Jelly Roll Morton and James Pete Johnson. Here is a recording he did with bass player Truck Parham: "Pinetop's Blues" which was originally played and recorded by Pinetop Smith in 1928. Hodes' version of "Pinetop's Blues" has a duo advantage and more advanced piano technique.
"Pinetop's Blues" played by Art Hodes and Truck Parham
CC talks about Hodes' definition about boogie woogie and ends the show.
An unidentified man made a closing remark about Charlie the Collectors' passion about boogie woogie and his show.
An unidentified man makes an opening remark about Charlie the Collector's show: Boogie-Woogie anthology program #7.
CC talks: We will listen to big band boogie in this episode-Teddy Powell and his orchestra plays Teddy's Boogie Woogie in 1939.
Teddy's Boogie Woogie played by Teddy Powell and his orchestra.

CC talks: Teddy's Boogie Woogie is one of Teddy Powell's 7 big band boogie pieces from 1939 to 1941, which was followed by Teddy Bear Boogie, Boogin' On The Downbeat, Bluebird Boogie-Woogie, Straight Eight Boogie, Jungle Boogie and In Pinetop's Footsteps. The CC talks about Woody Herman, clarinetist and a band leader, who made it big and stayed with all the trends of jazz music. They were known as The Band that Plays the Blues. One of the popular songs of 1940, was this hybrid rhythm of rhumba and boogie woogie, called "Simply Rhumboogie."
"Simply Rhumboogie" performed by Woody Herman and his band, pianist Tommy Linehan, and vocalist Dillagene.

CC talks: Meade "Lux" Lewis wrote and recorded a boogie woogie piece to honor his mentor Jimmy Yancey in 1936, called "Yancey Special." On March 10, 1938, Bob Crosby and his big band recorded this piece featuring Bob Zurke displaying his immense skills on the piano. Interestingly it was arranged by Dean Kincaide, who also did Tommy Dorsey's boogie woogie.
"Yancey Special" performed by Bob Crosby and his orchestra with Bob Zurke on the piano.

CC talks: Bob Zurke, left the Crosby band to form his own group called the Delta Rhythm Band. Like many of the leaders of the band, Zurke also capitalize on the fame of boogie woogie. Using his own piano talents but somehow it just didn't go over commercially. Bob Zurke did an arrangement of "Cow Cow Blues" in 1940 for the big band.
"Cow Cow Blues" by Bob Zurke and his Delta Rhythm Band.

CC talks: Johnny Long, a left-handed violinist, never featured himself in any recordings. He only recorded one boogie woogie and it was a good one. He most famous recording is "A Shanty In Old Shanty Town" in 1940. Just like many band leaders in the 30s and 40s, Johnny felt compelled to make recordings of boogie woogie, "The Boogie Man."
"Boogie Man" by Johnny Long featuring Paul Harmon on vocal.

CC talks: We don't usually associate Bing Crosby with boogie woogie, but he did make a good one. Bing Crosby and Lionel Hampton did a version of "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" in 1947. In several recordings Crosby talks rather than sings, and Hampton is in grand style with his two-finger approach in his keyboard style.
"Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" by Bing Crosby and Lionel Hampton.
CC made a closing remark about the program.
An unidentified man made a closing remark about Charlie the Collector's show.

The above episode ends abruptly. A new episode of the boogie woogie anthology show starts. Charlie the Collector talks about variations of boogie woogie, such as how boogie woogie blended with other musical forms, and how it was handled by instruments other than piano. Will Bradley in the late 40s made a boogie woogie recording called "Bob and Boogie," Garland [Bartol] put it to a cha cha, and there is Rhumboogie. And Will Bradley also did a boogie woogie conga, Joe "Fingers" Carr did a waltz boogie, [Hosea Turby] with his boogie woogie etudes, and Spike Johns once got into the act.
"The Yellow Dog Blues" by Eddie Condon and his Orchestra featuring pianist Ralph Sutton

CC talks: This is a boogie woogie performance based on the human voice, a vocal quartet that form the regular figuration of the bass and right hand melody normally associated with piano. The song is "Gospel Boogie," in 1940s, on an off-brand label called the White Church, performed by Leroy Abernathy of the Homeland Harmony Quartet. The beautiful walking bass is performed by the human voice, generating the 8-bar gospel message.
"Gospel Boogie" by Leroy Abernathy of the Homeland Harmony Quartet.

CC talks: Boogie woogie also has its contemporary and modern aspects. Mary Lou Williams 1947 did a smooth and polished performance reflecting her tremendous harmonic sense, "Hesitation Boogie," an example of an invasion of an early contemporary jazz to the realm of boogie woogie.
"Hesitation Boogie" performed by Mary Lou Williams

CC talks: Here is a single instrument doing the boogie woogie. In the 50s, the evolution of tape recording allows artists to accompany themselves, by successfully record themselves and by playing back indefinite times. Jack Marshall done probably in the mid-50s a piece solely of his guitar, playing in different registers doing of the bass figuration, as well as the breaks and the melodic lines. It's called "Tremolo Boogie." You will also recognize that it is the arrangement of the original Pinetops.

CC talks: Country and Western music also sees boogie woogie as a suitable theme, they are a little late in the game and some of the results are monstrous. But these two forms are certainly not incompatible. Most incompatibility probably comes from lack of proper instrumentation, notably a piano. Here is a piece in 1940 done by a group called The Village Boys, a Western swing band of piano and strings in the Houston area. This piece is called "A Boogie Woogie in the Village." It is an example of boogie woogie in the country and western van, or, is it western and country in the boogie woogie van?
"Boogie Woogie in the Village" by The Village Boys.

CC talks: Milt Herth was a pioneer of the Hammond electric organ, popular in the late 30s. He recorded with the Milt Herth Trio, which usually included the piano and drums, in addition to his Hammond organ. Before he died in 1969, he left us a shining example of how boogie woogie could be handled on an electric organ, with the aids of the piano keyboard on some of the right-hand boogie riffs. Here is a piece recorded in 1947. Euday Bowman would be proud that "12th Street Rag" would be played in such a grand style.
"12th Street Rag" played by Milt Herth and the Milt Herth Trio

CC talks: Rock and roll found some of its roots in boogie woogie. Rock and roll artists like Piano Red, Jerry Lee Lewis and Amos Milburn framed their early music into boogie woogie format. Here is Amos Milburn in 1949, doing an early rock and roll version of the original "Pinetop's Boogie Woogie."
"Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" played by Amos Milburn
CC made a closing remark of the show.
CC talks about overview of boogie woogie.
"Pinetop's Boogie Woogie" performed by Pinetop Smith

CC talks: One of the pioneers of boogie woogie was Jimmy Blythe, an early Chicago pianist, He made several recordings in the mid-20s with some of the famous musicians such as clarinetists Johnny Dodds. The first boogie woogie was probably done by Jimmy Blythe in 1924, a piano solo called "Chicago Stop." Here is piano duet he made with Jim "Buddy" Burton in April 1928, about six months before Pinetop Smith recorded his milestone. This is an example of an early boogie woogie style before it even acquired its name. They called this "Block and Tackle," referring a type of moonshine, selling for $25 a half pint that would make you walk a block down the street to tackle any kinds of automobile.
"Block and Tackle" played by Jimmy Blythe and Johnny Dodds.

CC talks: Let's hear a piece of a sample in the 40s of what I call the boogie woogie era. The big three successful pianists Pete Johnson, Albert Ammons, and Meade Lux Lewis. Here is a piece duet of Johnson and Ammons, which also includes a drum accompaniment, constituting boogie with another related but different piano style, called barrelhouse.
"Barrelhouse Boogie" by Pete Johnson and Albert Ammons.

CC talks: In the late 30s, many big bands adapted to perform boogie woogie. Here is an example of the best big band boogie woogie. Red Nichols leads several of his bands, recorded with pianist Billy Maxted doing some fast finger work in 1940. This piece is called "Meet Miss 8 Beat."
"Meet Miss 8 Beat" performed by Red Nichols and Billy Maxted

CC talks: Small groups play boogie woogie and they are jazzy, exciting and like chamber music, or like bar room music. Sam Price, from Honey Grove Texas, used to lead a small group that he called Texas Bluesicians. During the 1940s they made a bunch of records for Decca. Their music is primarily in the blues format dominated by Price's piano. Here is what they sound in 1940, co-composed by Sam Price, called "How 'Bout That Mess."

CC talks: Boogie woogie finds its way into other format of musical expression. That's exactly what happens when boogie woogie reached its heyday in the 40s. Let's hear it how it influenced the early rock and roll music. Here is "Swanee River Hop" by Fats Domino in 1953.
CC made a closing remark on the boogie woogie program.

The start of another boogie woogie program. Charlie the Collector (CC) talks about the early pioneers of boogie woogie. First on the list is Romeo Nelson. Very little is known about this man. He lived in Chicago and only did a few records. "Head Rag Hop" was probably his best recording, made in September 1929. The influence of the Pinetops is obvious in the talking and dancing instructions.

CC talks: Boogie woogie seemed to evolve during the early 20s, blending the early ragtime and the blues piano. It is a form that retains both the basic blues played bu the right hand and resounding excitement of ragtime, usually doubled in tempo played by the left hand. One of the most interesting of this blending on 1927 recording made by James P. Johnson called "All That I Had is Gone."
"All That I Had is Gone" by James P. Johnson.

CC talks: One of the early boogie woogie artist who disappeared in the 20s, and did not surface again until rediscovery in the late 40s was pianist Charlie Spand, who was also known as a fine blues singer. In 1929 he made a Paramount record with guitarist Blind Blake, called "Hasting Street," on which there is a rhythmic background, and distinguishable xylophone, rattles, and tom toms. Throughout the records, there is a dark, ominous quality, not usually not associated the quality of boogie woogie. Blind Blake is doing the talking.
"Hasting Street" by Charlie Spand and Blind Blake

CC talks: Hersal Thomas, another one of the early boogie woogie and blues artist, was sort of a child prodigy at the piano. His most famous composition, "Suitcase Blues," which he recorded in February 1925, was commented by some critics to be the first boogie woogie ever made. Now we know Jimmy Blythe beat him by ten months with his "Chicago Stomp." But "Suitcase Blues" was a milestone in the art, because it was played and remembered by many other boogie woogie players.

CC talks: The Pinetops' boogie woogie was made in 1928 in which the jazz style was given its name. The most significant milestone in the history of boogie woogie was probably a 1927 recording made by Meade Lux Lewis called "Honky Tonk Train." Lux was born in Chicago in 1905, started to learn violin when he was 16. After hearing Jimmy Yancey's playing he switched to blues piano. In 1927 he recorded for the old Paramount label, one of the most phenomenal boogie woogie piano solos of all time and one that sent jazz promoter John Hammond on a two-year search for the composer.
"Honky Tonk Train Blues" by Meade Lux Lewis

CC talks: Boogie woogie basses are quite varied and infinite in numbers. Many artists took pride in inventing new ones. By far the most popular is the simple walking bass, an eight-to-the-bar figuration in which the name implies. Another bass also popular in boogie woogie, called the rocks, it sort of conveys the feeling of back and forth. We are going to listen to a rock bass performed by Montana Taylor. In 1929, he made a recording called "Detroit Rocks" featuring the unique rocking bass figuration.
CC made a closing remark of the show.

The start of new episode of the boogie woogie program on the radio. Charlie the Collector talks about the boogie woogie era, 1936-1942. The really big three were Albert Ammons, Pete Johnson and Meade Lux Lewis, left us a truly fine legacy, and many recordings of duets and trios. Pete Johnson got his start in Kansas City, playing solo piano in clubs in 1926-1938 until he started to get national exposure. Here is an example of Pete Johnson did in 1941 for Decca, called "Pete's Mixture."

CC talks: Albert Ammons, who does our theme song "Shout For Joy," was a Chicago man. Here is an example of his style, a dynamic recording he did for Blue Note in 1942, he called this "Bass Going Crazy." And it is a departure from the normal boogie woogie pattern. In it the left hand does not allow to pursue the repeating pattern for very long, and develop with melodic pattern usually associated with the right hand.

CC talks: Mead Lux Lewis's "Honky Tonk Train" was first discovered by John Hammond after a two year search. Lux rose to the height after his discovery and continued to adapt boogie woogie to the trend of the changing taste. Let's listen to his performance in 1936 on "Mr. Freddie Blues," a piece written by Freddie Shayne.
"Mr. Freddie Blues" performed by Mead Lux Lewis

CC talks: Let's hear how Lewis sounded in 1962, advancing with the trend of the day, he recorded this moving honky tonk piano piece, with the mashed potato beat building on all his boogie woogie expertise he accumulated since the mid-20s. Let's call it "When The Saints Go Shufflin' In."
"When The Saints Go Shufflin' In" by Meade Lux Lewis
CC talks: Jimmy Yancey left a legacy of recordings of outstanding blues style and variety of basses he invented in his lifetime. Here is a recording he did in 1940, "Old Quaker Blues."

CC talks: Let's turn to Kansas City and see what they have to offer. Besides Pete Johnson who was born and trained there as a boogie woogie pianist, Kansas City also produced other boogie woogie pianists like Mary Lou Williams, Count Basie, Joshua Johnson and a band leader by the name of Jay McShann who got his fame because Charlie Parker got started playing in his band in the late 30s. McShann, whose nickname is Hootie, was an accomplished musician, specialized in blues and boogie woogie. Here is something that he did in 1941, called "Hold 'Em Hootie."

CC talks: The best piano player of the Boogie Woogie era is Maurice Rocco, was another child prodigy, invented a style called rocking rhythm. He was a jazz artist of the highest caliber. Let's hear his "Donkey Serenade" he did in 1940 when he was only 16. Near the end of piece, he performed another neat trick unique to boogie woogie by switching the melody of the right hand and incorporated into the walking bass.
CC made a closing remark of the show.

The start of another episode of Boogie Anthology in which Charlie the Collector is the host. CC talks: We will listen to big band boogie woogie and hear how big group capitalizing this captivating musical style that swept the country in the late 30s and early 40s. Let's start out by listening to Harry James' "Back Beat Boogie."

CC talks: A more challenging way for the big band to adapt to the piano-dominated nature of boogie woogie, is to let other instruments play the boogie bass figuration, usually the wind instruments. A notable example of the big band boogie is the arrangement of the original Pinetop's boogie woogie made by Tommy Dorsey in 1938, simply under the name "Boogie Woogie."

CC talks: Many of big bands tried at least one boogie woogie in the 30s but some of them were miserable failures. The greatest explorers of boogie woogie were probably Woody Hartman, Andy Kirk, Harry James, Count Basie, Bob Crosby, Lionel Hampton, Teddy Powell, Gene Krupa and Bob Zurke. And one band in particular that owe its short life success to its treatment of boogie woogie was that of Will Bradley, a trombone player from New Jersey. With the aid of drummer, vocalist Raymond McKinley, pianist Freddie Slack, later replaced by Billy Maxted. The Will Bradley orchestra turned out 16 boogie woogie numbers by Columbia in 1940 to 1941, achieving amazing versatility. The most boogie of these numbers is "Rock-A-Bye The Woogie."
"Rock-A-Bye The Woogie" by the Will Bradley orchestra featuring Ray McKinley

CC talks: Andy Kirk's orchestra, known as Twelve Clouds of Joy, jumped on the boogie woogie wagon rather early. Kirk's recording of Foggy Bottom made in 1936 with 13 band members may have been the first every made for big band boogie woogie. However Gene Krupa made a recording with a smaller group in 1935. One of the smoothest boogie woogie by the big band was the song called "Little Joe from Chicago," recorded by Andy Kirk in 1938.
"Little Joe from Chicago" performed by Andy Kirk's orchestra, composed by Mary Lou Williams who was featured as the pianist in this recording.

CC talks: We don't usually associate Duke Ellington with boogie woogie but he did contribute a few original ideas. Here is a recording he made with Johnny Hodges back in 1939. He came up with a new bass figuration to go with this slow, draggy, and beautiful blue number called "Dooji Wooji."
"Dooji Wooji" by Duke Ellington and Johnny Hodges

CC talks: I hear critics that the original idea of boogie woogie goes to 1800's Johann Sebastian Bach because of the repeated figure he used in his music. That's really stretching the point I am afraid. But it was inevitable that some bands would do a boogie woogie in allusion to Bach's music. And it turned out to be Larry Clinton. Here is another arrangement replied on the instrument rather than the piano to carry the bass. And this time it is not the others but the bassoons. Larry Clinton who wrote this one called it "Bach to Boogie."

CC talks: Because of the driving nature of its rhythmic basses, boogie woogie lands itself rightly with any theme that suggest repetitions. A good example is Meade Lux Lewis' Honky Tonk Train. There is one Abe Lyman orchestra recorded in 1941. It does convey the hustling image of a "Horse 'n' Boogie."
"Horse 'n' Boogie" by Abe Lyman and his orchestra.
CC made a closing remark of the program.
An unidentified boogie woogie music played by the pianos.
Some chatting. An unidentified boogie woogie music played by the pianos.
Musicians chat about their performance. [The spoken part is not very audible.]

did.physdesc: on one side of 1 sound tape reel (polyester, 00:25:07) : analog, 15 ips and 7 1/2 ips, quarter track and half track, stereo and mono ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: The recording is misidentified on the tape box as "Joe Albany, #4."

LC engineer's note 1: Track 1 and track 2 are identical except for speed. Track 1 is 15 ips and track 2 is 7 1/2 ips. They are also half-track stereo. The performers and song title are unknown and sound like an advanced experimental demo, not a finished product. Cuts 3 through 6 are in quarter-track stereo format and are from a Ted Hawkins LP project dating from the early 1970s but not released until 1986. The mixes are different to what was issued in 1986. They are also in mono sound.

LC engineer's note 2: Side 2, while not technically blank, contains no audio information. It appears the tape was poorly bulk erased before use, with only Side 1 subsequently recorded. Side 2 contains nothing but loud hiss and a high frequency whine.

Logger's note: The SR consists of an interview of David Edwards by Alan Lomax. Tape no. 1 of 4. LWO 5433, AFS 06610 A1 and A2, AFS 06610 B1-B5, AFS 06611 A1, and AFS 06611 A2-A4.

row.entry: DE talks about his childhood and playing some games in the neighborhood when he was 12. He mentions an old-time song called "Satisfied."

The interviewer asks DE to sing the song "Satisfied" but DE said he couldn't remember. The interviewer: Do you play "Walking in the Green Grass"? DE says he plays some other songs such as "Careless Love," etc.
The interviewer: What is the first song you ever learned to sing? DE said he remembered "Spread My Raincoat Down" and sang the song. Lyrics: I am going to Dallas, please spread my raincoat down....

DE talks about his youth life at the plantation and hearing blues songs. The interviewer: What do you think blues really mean? What do you say that is when you say "I got the blues"? DE: You feel lonesome, worries and think of a good girl, something like that. The interviewer: What's the 1st time you had the blues? DE: When I was a small kid, singing with a guitar.
AL asks DE to some cornfield songs without the guitars. DE sings "You Got to Roll"
DE sings "You Got to Roll" again with his own guitar accompaniment.
DE talks about the "Chain Gang Song (Levee Camp Song)." The interviewer asks about more cornfield song DE remembered.
AL asks if DE remembered Big Joe Turner. DE talks and plays "Just A Spoonful"
DE sings "I Love My Jelly Roll"
DE talks about his father's job as a farmer, and he would like to be musician like his father. DE's father gave up his music career when he was older.
DE demonstrates and plays some chords and harmony on the guitar, and talks about playing blues is a devil's business.
DE talks about memories of his church Sunday school, and his first guitar.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:30:56) : analog, 7 1/2 ips, mono ; 7 in.

row.entry: DE talks about his traveling experience on a freight train.
DE mentions the blues guitarist Joe Willie Wilkins.
DE talks about the musicians he met in Memphis. He talks about them smoking cocaine and making good money in making records. The musicians mostly play blues.
DE talks about the musicians teach him music and show him new chords. He demonstrates some chords on the guitar.
DE mentions he traveled down to the south states.
DE talks about how he composed "Water Coast Blues."

an episode of talk on the radio: "Conversation at Chicago"

RL asks Prof. Gibson Winter (GW) about the main point of the book. GW answers that we created a high technology culture, people are given the status by belonging to it. To be free is first to belong, to be counted in, to have a guaranteed income, or some kind of assurance to belong to that society. This is a starting point.
RL asks, so there are two different senses of freedom. The old one is lack of freedom.
An unidentified female voice says "I don't see young people today see freedom as a goal. In the process of being free, we should be careful we don't take on another yoke under the name of freedom."
GW says he sees two levels of the problems: organizational level of freedom, and cultural meaning of freedom in the society.
All guest speakers continue to discuss about organizational level of freedom. GW says there are two aspects of what we need to be free. We need to belong, and we need to have a voice.

An unidentified man asks why is there change from the old sense of freedom to the new freedom. He speaks of John Adams as an example to explain the idea. GW and guests continue to discuss the issues of freedom.
The discussion ends abruptly at the end of the tape.

row.entry: Singing and preaching the gospel of an unidentified song #1. The style is strong improvisation and reciting. Lyrics: "Jesus Son of David, the seed of Abraham, so kind and true, do you know him..."
Talking about the seed of Abraham and the reason why Jesus is the Son of David
Singing and preaching the gospel continues
Singing an unidentified song #2. Lyrics: "Lord, I am doing all the good I can, I praise your name all I can, I lift up your name all I can..."
Talking and preaching about God should to be lifted up and honored.

Singing an unidentified song #3. Lyrics: "This victory shall be mine, this joy shall be mine, this happiness shall be mine, this peace shall be mine, this holiness shall be mine, this love shall be mine."
Singing an unidentified song #4. Lyrics: "If I labor God's gonna give me a crown."
Singing an unidentified song #5. Lyrics: "Let Jesus fix it for you. Whenever you pray, let Him has His will."
Preaching the gospel. Jesus fixes all your trouble. Jesus was born the man to do it all. He died on Calvary, sin was drive out.
Singing an unidentified song #6. Lyrics: "Lord, I am running for eternal life. I am praying for eternal life. Lift up your name for eternal life. I am teaching for eternal life."

Preaching the gospel. The passage from Scripture is John 6:47: "Very truly I tell you, the one who believes has eternal." God said, I am the bread of life. He is God of the day, God of peace, God of living.
Singing an unidentified song #7. Lyrics: "I know the Lord will make a way. Yes. He will."
Singing an unidentified song #8. Lyrics: "The Lord got a hold of my hands and He leads me. The Lord is in my mind, and He leads me. Lead me Jesus."
Preaching the gospel: 1 Corinthians 15:51 "Listen, I tell you a mystery: We will not all sleep, but we will all be changed."

Singing an unidentified song #9. Lyrics: "There is rest, sweet rest, at the Master's feet. There is favor now at the mercy seat. We may call on Him ev'ry grief and care. There is always a blessing, a blessing in prayer."
Singing an unidentified song #10. Lyrics: "Go down, Moses. Way down in Egypt's land. Tell old Pharaoh. Let my people go."
Singing an unidentified song #11. Lyrics: "I am the living bread. I am the bread that came down from heaven."
Talking and preaching the gospel. The passage from Scripture is John 1:1 "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God."

scopecontent.p: Logger's note: An unidentified female singer performs eight songs before live audience. She [probably] accompanies herself on guitar. The timeline for Side 2 (a duplicate of Side 1) is slightly different.

LC engineer's note: The tape appears to have been recorded on a four-track (multitrack) machine due to the way the tracks are organized. As a result all files from this tape were from one side of the tape, as opposed to a true quarter-track tape, which would need to be flipped to play back the other side. Both files contain the same content; it is not a mistake in the transfer.

scopecontent.p: The tape box indicates this should be a dub of "Comedy from the Second City" (Mercury - OCS 6201), released in 1961. Instead, this recording includes dubs (not all in order) from The Mamas and the Papas LP.
Vendor's digitization note: The program is distorted at times.

did.unittitle:
"I Met A Man Last Night" (rough version with time guide vocal),
circa mid-1970s
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:04:44) : analog, 15 ips, stereo ; 7 in.

scopecontent.p: Archivist's note: An unidentified woman sings a Christian pop song, with a voice reminiscent of an early-career Olivia Newton-John.

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel (00:19:39) : analog, 15 ips, four track ; 10 in., 1/2 in. wide

scopecontent.p: LC engineer's note: The contents and artists listed on the box and inner box flap do not match the recording on the tape. The actual recording is of an unidentified singer with guitar accompaniment; recording date unknown. Multiple partial takes of the two songs. The last tune is a remnant of a Pete Robinson session as noted on the inner box flap.

row.entry: unidentified tune #2 [includes false start; Pete Welding speaks just before the false start]

did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel : analog ; 10 in.

did.unittitle:
Master session tape with backing tracks (and no vocals) for
Presenting Dion and The Belmonts
(unconfirmed),
1959
did.physdesc: 1 sound tape reel : analog ; 10 in.

scopecontent.p: The title was supplied by the archivist.
LC engineer's note: This is almost certainly the original master session tape for the first album recorded by Dion and The Belmonts. Some speaking can be heard, but no singing.
